questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Adenylyl cyclase

Explanation:

  • Adenylyl cyclase mediates β2-adrenergic receptor action by increasing cAMP, which activates PKA, driving glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis for hyperglycemia or enhancing glucose uptake for hypoglycemia.

β2-Adrenergic Receptor Actions: Hyperglycemia and Hypoglycemia Mechanisms

Key Signaling Pathways

Pathway

Mechanism

cAMP/PKA Pathway

Activation of β2-AR by catecholamines or β2-agonists couples with Gs protein.Increases cAMP and activates PKA.PKA phosphorylates proteins regulating glucose metabolism.

mTORC2 Pathway

Chronic β2-AR stimulation promotes glucose uptake via mTORC2.Enhances GLUT4 translocation to the muscle cell membrane, independent of insulin signaling.

Effects on Glucose Metabolism

Condition

Effect

Mechanism

Hyperglycemia

Acute β2-AR stimulation increases blood glucose levels.

Promotes hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.Stimulates insulin secretion from beta cells.

Hypoglycemia

Chronic β2-AR stimulation lowers blood glucose levels.

Increases skeletal muscle glucose uptake via mTORC2-mediated GLUT4 translocation.Improves glucose tolerance.

Counterregulatory Mechanism

Restores glucose during hypoglycemia or fasting.

Stimulates hepatic glucose production.Inhibits insulin action in peripheral tissues.

Acute β2-AR Stimulation: Elevates blood glucose via hepatic glucose release and insulin secretion.

Chronic β2-AR Stimulation: Lowers glucose by enhancing GLUT4-mediated uptake in muscle.

Counterregulatory Role: Maintains glucose homeostasis during stress or fasting.

 

Incorrect Options:

Guanylyl cyclase (Option B): Primarily involved in cGMP signaling, unrelated to β2-adrenergic receptor-mediated glucose metabolism.

Phospholipase C (Option C): Activates in Gq-coupled receptor pathways, not associated with β2-adrenergic receptor signaling for glucose regulation.

Phospholipase A2 (Option D): Involved in arachidonic acid metabolism, unrelated to glucose homeostasis or β2-adrenergic receptor pathways.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) SGLT 1

Explanation:

  • Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1 in the small intestine facilitates glucose absorption via sodium co-transport, critical for ORS effectiveness.

Glucose Transporters:

Glucose Transporter

Location

Function

GLUT 1

Various tissues, including brain, erythrocytes, and placenta

Basal glucose uptake in various tissues (constitutive glucose transporter)

GLUT 2

Liver, pancreatic beta cells, renal tubules, small intestine

Facilitates bidirectional glucose transport in liver, pancreatic beta cells, renal tubules, and small intestine

GLUT 3

Brain, placenta, testes

Facilitates high-affinity glucose uptake in neurons and other glucose dependent cells

GLUT 4 (Option C ruled out)

Adipose tissue, skeletal muscle

Insulin-regulated glucose transporter. Facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin

GLUT 5

Small intestine, testes, kidney, adipose tissue, skeletal muscle

Facilitates fructose transport (also transports glucose to a lesser extent)

SGLT 1

Small intestine, kidney

Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter. Facilitates active glucose absorption in the small intestine

SGLT 2 (Option B ruled out)

Kidney

Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter. Facilitates glucose reabsorption in the kidneys


Na-Ca transporter (Option D): Involved in calcium homeostasis, not glucose absorption in the gut.

questions.text: Calculate the sodium deficit in a 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg with a sodium level of 120 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 840 mEq

Explanation:

Sodium Deficit Calculation:

  • Formula: Sodium Deficit (mEq) = (Desired Sodium - Current Sodium) x Total Body Water (TBW)

Factor

Value

Desired Sodium

140 mEq/L

Current Sodium

120 mEq/L

TBW for Male (70kg)

42 L

Sodium Deficit

840 mEq
  • Total Body Water (TBW):
    • 60% of body weight (for males)
    • 50% of body weight (for females)
  • Therefore,
    • For a 70 kg male: TBW = 0.6 × 70 = 42 L
    • Desired sodium: 140 mEq/L (average range: 135-145 mEq/L)
    • Current sodium: 120 mEq/L
    • Sodium Deficit = (140 - 120) × 42 = 840 mEq

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied with Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, Cl: 4 mEq/L. Identify the compartment from which the fluid has been obtained.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intracellular fluid

Explanation:

  • The low sodium (Na+) concentration (10 mEq/L) is typical of intracellular fluid and contrasts with higher extracellular concentrations (135-145 mEq/L).
  • The high potassium (K+) concentration (140 mEq/L) is consistent with intracellular fluid levels.
  • The low chloride (Cl-) concentration (4 mEq/L) also aligns with intracellular fluid. Thus, the sample composition is characteristic of intracellular fluid.

questions.text: Which cells are impacted in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oligodendrocytes

Explanation:

  • Multiple sclerosis (MS) primarily affects oligodendrocytes, which are responsible for producing and maintaining the myelin sheath in the central nervous system (CNS).
  • In MS, the immune system mistakenly attacks the myelin, leading to demyelination and impairing nerve signal transmission.

Incorrect Options:

Microglia (Option A) are the resident immune cells of the CNS, and while they may be involved in the immune response in MS, they are not the primary targets.

Astrocytes (Option C) support neurons and maintain the blood-brain barrier, and while they may be reactive in MS, they are not directly impacted in the disease.

Ependymal cells (Option D) line the ventricles of the brain and produce cerebrospinal fluid, which are not directly involved in MS pathology.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation:

  • Young male with lower backache and morning stiffness are suggestive of Ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Idiopathic; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Clinical tests:

  • Schober/ Modified Schober test (for lumbar spine)
  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

  • Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Dagger sign

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors/IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

 

Incorrect Options:

Tuberculosis of the spine (Option A): Tuberculosis of the spine also known as Pott's disease, is a potential differential diagnosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is endemic. However, in this case, the patient's age, chronicity of symptoms, and the absence of constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and night sweats make ankylosing spondylitis more likely.

Disc prolapse (Option C): Disc prolapse can cause lower back pain and radicular symptoms radiating down the leg due to nerve root compression. However, the presence of morning stiffness and bilateral heel pain in this patient suggests an inflammatory condition such as ankylosing spondylitis rather than a disc prolapse.

Mechanical Pain (Option D): Mechanical pain resulting from musculoskeletal strain or injury, can certainly cause lower back pain. However, the chronicity of symptoms, morning stiffness, and the involvement of sacroiliac joints and heels make ankylosing spondylitis a more likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child who visited the pediatrician due to bilateral knee joint pain, normal bone mineral density, and the provided X-ray image of the joints?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scurvy

Explanation:

  • The child's symptoms of leg pain with normal bone mineral density and x-ray showing White line of frenkel involving metaphysis, suggest a diagnosis of scurvy.

X-ray Findings of Scurvy

  1. Characteristic Lines: Specific radiological lines indicative of scurvy are observed.
    • White Line of Frankel: Dense line between epiphysis and metaphysis. Due to calcification.
    • Scurvy Line: Dense line within the metaphysis.
    • Weinberger’s Ring Line: Dense line within the epiphysis.
  2. Trümmerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  3. Pelkan Spurs: Bone spurs from the lateral border of the metaphysis.
  4. Ground Glass Appearance of the bones.
  5. Subperiosteal Fractures: Fractures may occur beneath the periosteum.
  6. Epiphyseal Fracture Separation.

Incorrect options:

Rickets (Option B): Rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency or impaired metabolism, leading to impaired mineralization of growing bones. It typically presents with skeletal deformities, including bowing of the long bones, widening of the wrist and ankle joints, and rachitic rosary (enlargement of the costochondral junction). The X-ray findings in rickets include cupping and fraying of the metaphyses, known as "cupping and fraying" or "squared-off" appearance.

Metaphyseal dysplasia (Option C): Metaphyseal dysplasia is a group of rare genetic disorders that primarily affect the metaphyseal regions of long bones. The X-ray findings in metaphyseal dysplasia show characteristic metaphyseal changes, including irregularity, sclerosis, and fragmentation.

Pycnodysostosis (Option D): Pycnodysostosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired osteoclast function, leading to increased bone density and brittle bones. The X-ray findings in pycnodysostosis include increased bone density, thickened cortices, and shortened, stubby fingers.

questions.text: The following test is done to assess?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Median nerve

Explanation:

  • Image shows Pen test, done to test Abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is a test of Median nerve.

Clinical tests for Median nerve:

Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy, presented with a mild painful swelling over the scalp since 3 months, as depicted below. Additionally, the patient confirms having a pet dog in his household. What is the most appropriate diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Kerion

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Painful inflammatory swelling on the scalp.
    • Chronic duration (3 months).
    • Associated with a pet dog, suggesting a zoophilic fungal infection.
  • Classic Appearance:
    • Boggy, pustular mass with crusting and hair loss.
    • Purulent discharge.
    • Seen in tinea capitis (Trichophyton species, Microsporum canis - from pets).
  • Most Likely Diagnosis: Kerion (inflammatory tinea capitis)

Kerion and Tinea Capitis Variants

Feature

Kerion (Inflammatory Tinea Capitis)

Non-inflammatory Tinea Capitis

Cause

Zoophilic fungi (Microsporum canis, Trichophyton mentagrophytes)

Anthropophilic fungi (Trichophyton tonsurans)

Appearance

Boggy, pustular, inflammatory swelling

Dry, scaly patches with black dots

Hair loss

Yes, scarring alopecia if untreated

Yes, but non-scarring

Pain/Discharge

Painful, pus-filled lesions

Painless, no pus

Diagnosis

KOH mount, Wood’s lamp (fluoresces with Microsporum)

KOH mount, culture

Treatment

Oral griseofulvin or terbinafine, topical antifungals

Oral antifungals, ketoconazole shampoo

Furuncle (Option A): Incorrect because it is a bacterial infection (S. aureus) and lacks hair loss.

Epidermoid cyst (Option B): Incorrect because cysts are non-inflammatory, firm, and do not drain pus.

Folliculitis (Option D): Incorrect because it presents as multiple small pustules, not a boggy mass.

questions.text: A 28-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteoclastoma

Explanation:

  • Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

 

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

 

Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phrynoderma

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • History of night blindness (suggests vitamin A deficiency).

    • Follicular hyperkeratotic papules, typically on extensor surfaces.

  • Classic Appearance:

    • Resembles "toad skin" (hence, phrynoderma).

    • Associated with malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

  • Most Likely Diagnosis: Phrynoderma (Follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency).

 

Phrynoderma (Vitamin A Deficiency)

 

Feature

Details

Definition

Follicular hyperkeratosis due to Vitamin A deficiency

Causes

Malnutrition, fat malabsorption, chronic diarrhea

Clinical Features

Keratotic papules on extensor surfaces, rough skin, night blindness

Diagnosis

Clinical, serum Vitamin A levels

Treatment

Vitamin A supplementation, improved nutrition

Keratosis pilaris (Option B): Incorrect because it is a benign genetic condition without a history of vitamin A deficiency.

Darier disease (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with greasy crusted papules, not vitamin A-related follicular hyperkeratosis.

Follicular eczema (Option D): Incorrect because eczema is associated with itching, scaling, and lichenification, not night blindness.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident, complaining of pain around the left hip joint, and is found to have a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated affected limb with noticeable shortening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior hip dislocation

Explanation:

  • The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip, which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened.

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B)

Anterior dislocation of hip (Option A)

Central fracture-dislocation of hip (Option C)

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

questions.text: As the intern on duty, your responsibility includes attending to patients involved in a road traffic accident. Identify the patient from the options below for whom you would promptly contact the orthopaedic resident on call.

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractured arm with a 10 cm long incision over the arm
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

Explanation:

  • Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers is a critical choice because a capillary refill time of 5 seconds indicates potential circulatory compromise, which is a medical emergency. Such a delay in capillary refill suggests that the blood flow to the fingers is inadequate, possibly due to vascular injury or severe swelling, necessitating immediate orthopaedic evaluation and intervention to prevent further complications, such as limb ischemia

Orthopedic Emergencies:

  • Open fractures and dislocations
  • Hip dislocations (risk of AVN)
  • Neural compromise, especially with spinal injury
  • Symptoms or signs of neurovascular injury (numbness, paresis, poor perfusion)
  • Acute septic arthritis and osteomyelitis
  • Compartment syndrome (eg, pain out of proportion to injuries, pallor, paresthesias, coolness, pulselessness)
  • Vascular injuries (e.g., knee dislocation)
  • Exsanguinating pelvic fractures

Incorrect Options:

The patient with recurrent shoulder dislocation (Option A) may require follow-up but does not represent an acute emergency.

The patient with a fractured arm and capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds (Option B) indicates adequate perfusion and does not require immediate intervention.

The patient with a fractured arm and a 10 cm long incision (Option C) may need attention but does not exhibit signs of circulatory compromise as severe as the fourth option.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old patient who has presented with flaccid bullae on her skin that are prone to easy rupture, with the biopsy showing a suprabasal split?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Flaccid bullae (easily rupturing blisters).
    • Mucosal involvement is often present.
  • Histopathology Findings:
    • Suprabasal split (acantholysis within the epidermis).
    • Row of tombstones appearance (basal keratinocytes remain attached to the basement membrane).
  • Confirmatory Test:
    • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): IgG deposition in an intercellular pattern.
  • Most Likely Diagnosis: Pemphigus vulgaris (PV).

Pemphigus and Other Blistering Disorders

Condition

Blister Type

Histopathology

Immunofluorescence

Pemphigus vulgaris

Flaccid bullae, oral lesions

Suprabasal split, acantholysis

IgG in intercellular spaces (fishnet pattern)

Pemphigus foliaceus (Option B ruled out)

Superficial, crusted lesions

Subcorneal split

Similar IgG deposits

Bullous pemphigoid

Tense bullae, no mucosal involvement

Subepidermal split

Linear IgG at BMZ

Dermatitis herpetiformis

Grouped vesicles, pruritic

Neutrophilic abscesses in dermal papillae

IgA at dermal papillae

Pemphigus vegetans (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with verrucous plaques rather than flaccid bullae.

Erythema multiforme (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with target lesions, not bullous formations with acantholysis.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea. What is the likely deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinoic acid

Explanation:

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1. Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    1. Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    2. Difficulty adapting to dark places .
    3. Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      1. Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      2. WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.
  •  
    • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
    • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

2. Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4. Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency typically manifests as oral and ocular symptoms, such as cracked lips, inflamed tongue, and sensitivity to light (photophobia).

Option C) Niacin: Niacin deficiency, also known as pellagra, primarily presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

Option D) Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid, or vitamin B5, deficiency is rare and not commonly associated with eye-related symptoms. It is involved in energy production and plays a role in various physiological processes.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with paronychia, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amoxiclav

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • The image shows paronychia, an infection around the nail fold, characterized by redness, swelling, pain, and pus collection.
  • Most Common Cause:
    • Acute paronychia: Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Streptococcus species.
    • Chronic paronychia: Candida species.
  • First-line Antibiotic:
    • Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) covers Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus, and anaerobes, making it the best choice.

Paronychia Management

Feature

Acute Paronychia

Chronic Paronychia

Cause

Bacterial (Staph aureus, Streptococci)

Fungal (Candida)

Onset

Rapid, painful swelling

Gradual, less painful

Pus Formation

Yes, common

Rare

Treatment

Drainage + Amoxiclav

Antifungals (topical clotrimazole)

Metronidazole (Option B): Incorrect because it mainly covers anaerobes and protozoa, which are not the primary cause of paronychia.

Amikacin (Option C): Incorrect because it mainly targets Gram-negative bacteria, while paronychia is mostly due to Gram-positive organisms (Staph aureus, Streptococci).

Norfloxacin (Option D): Incorrect because it is a fluoroquinolone with poor Staph aureus coverage, making it ineffective.

questions.text: Which type of alopecia is commonly associated with inflammatory alopecia in a 30-year-old male patient who presents with tinea capitis infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Favus and Kerion

Explanation:

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp caused by dermatophytes (Trichophyton & Microsporum).

  • Inflammatory variants of tinea capitis include:

    • Kerion: Severe inflammatory reaction with pustules, abscesses, and hair loss.

    • Favus: Chronic infection with yellow crusts (scutula), leading to scarring alopecia.

Types of Tinea Capitis and Alopecia Patterns

Type

Causative Organisms

Hair Involvement

Clinical Features

Ectothrix

Microsporum species

Outside hair shaft

Fluoresces under Wood's lamp

Endothrix

Trichophyton tonsurans

Inside hair shaft

No fluorescence

Kerion

 

Trichophyton verrucosum

Inflammatory, patchy alopecia

Boggy swelling, pustules

Favus

Trichophyton schoenleinii

Permanent scarring alopecia

Honeycomb scutula

Endothrix and Favus (Option A): Incorrect because Endothrix does not cause an inflammatory response like Kerion or Favus.

Ectothrix and Endothrix (Option B): Incorrect because Ectothrix is non-inflammatory, and Kerion is missing.

Kerion and Endothrix (Option D): Incorrect because Endothrix infections are typically non-inflammatory, whereas Favus is a classic inflammatory type.

questions.text: A patient presented with joint pain and on evaluation, urine turns black on standing. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Homogentisic acid 1,2-dioxygenase

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described, including darkening of urine upon standing and joint pain, is characteristic of Alkaptonuria, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase.

Garrod's tetrad in alkaptonuria

1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to a bluish-black discoloration.The image shows Osler’s sign.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

 

 


 

Reaction

Enzyme

Associated Disorder

Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Tyrosine transaminase

Tyrosinemia type II

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase

Tyrosinemia type III

Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase

Alkaptonuria

Maleylacetoacetate isomerase

-

questions.text: What would be your next best course of action when a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) exhibits deterioration of preexisting lesions and nerve involvement?

choices.text: Stop MDT thalidomide Continue MDT, start thalidomide

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

Explanation:

  • Deterioration of preexisting lesions + nerve involvement in a patient on MDT suggests Type 1 Lepra Reaction (Reversal Reaction).
  • Type 1 Reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction in borderline leprosy due to increased cell-mediated immunity.
  • Management:
    • Continue MDT: The reaction is due to immune response, not drug failure.
    • Start systemic corticosteroids (prednisolone) to reduce inflammation and prevent permanent nerve damage.

Lepra Reactions

Type

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Management

Type 1 (Reversal Reaction)

Increased cell-mediated immunity (CMI)

Worsening of existing lesions, erythema, edema, nerve pain

Continue MDT, start systemic steroids (prednisolone)

Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL)

Immune complex deposition (TNF-α mediated)

Painful nodules, fever, neuritis, systemic symptoms

Continue MDT, start thalidomide or steroids

Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids (Option A): Incorrect because MDT should not be stopped; the reaction is due to immune response, not drug toxicity.

Stop MDT, start thalidomide (Option C): Incorrect because thalidomide is used for Type 2 reaction (ENL), not Type 1 reaction.

Continue MDT, start thalidomide (Option D): Incorrect because thalidomide is ineffective for Type 1 reactions; steroids are preferred.

questions.text: A farmer presented with loose stools and rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Careful diet history reveals a diet rich in maize. Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Niacin

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of Diarrhoea, rashes over sun exposed areas (Dermatitis) and a history of maize based diet indicates Pellagra, seen in niacin deficiency
  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis
      • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
      • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)

 

  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia

The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis.

Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.


Incorrect Options:

Option B) Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it is not associated with specific skin rashes or gastrointestinal symptoms like loose stools.

Option C) Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Option D) Biotin deficiency is rare and usually occurs in individuals with a genetic disorder or those consuming large quantities of raw egg whites, which contain a protein called avidin that binds to biotin and impairs its absorption. Biotin deficiency can lead to symptoms such as hair loss, skin rash, and neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with itchy lesions as shown in the image. He also has a red-colored beefy tongue. Which of the following histories would you like to ask/elicit in this patient additionally?

choices.text: Ask for diarrhea and a history of memory loss
Ask for diarrhea, thiamine deficiency features, and detailed dietary history

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ask for diarrhea and a history of memory loss

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of Alcoholic, Red beefy tongue and Casal’s necklace (Dermatitis) in image indicates niacin deficiency
  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis
      • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
      • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)

​​​​​​​

  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia

The patient's symptoms, combined with a diet high in maize and sorghum, both known to contribute to niacin and tryptophan deficiencies suggest pellagra as the most likely diagnosis.

Sorghum has high leucine content which inhibits the QPRTase enzyme required for synthesis of Niacin from tryptophan. Additionally, Maize is low in tryptophan.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Ask for diarrhea, thiamine deficiency features, and detailed dietary history: While thiamine deficiency is a potential concern in alcoholics,it features (muscle weakness, fatigue, cardiovascular symptoms).

Option C) History of allergy: Allergies can cause skin manifestations, including itching, the specific symptoms mentioned in this case are indicative of a condition associated with alcohol abuse and thiamine deficiency.

Option D) Ask for diarrhea and conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (pink eye) and diarrhea are symptoms that can be associated with certain infections.

questions.text: You are conducting an experiment on mitochondrial respiration. You add malate/pyruvate and respiration is normal. You add succinate and respiration is normal. When you add another substance in the presence of pyruvate/succinate and malate, respiration is blocked. Which of the following substances is most likely added?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Oligomycin

Explanation:

Electron Transport Chain:

  • ETC complexes are present in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • There are 5 protein complexes in ETC: Complex I to V

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone (Option A)

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

(NADH dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex I to ubiquinone​

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone)

Carboxin

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A (Option B)

BAL

Complex III

Cytochrome bc1 complex

Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to Cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

Prevents electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen​

Blocks the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis​

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn’t block respiration entirely.

questions.text: Which of the following glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are responsible for corneal transparency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Keratan sulphate

Explanation:

  • Keratan sulphate is involved in the transparency of cornea

Locations of Various Mucopolysaccharides

Mucopolysaccharide

questions.text: In this scenario, what is the origin of the blood glucose measured at 7 am the following morning for an individual who had dinner at 8 pm the previous night?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hepatic glycogenolysis

Explanation:

During fasting:

  • After 4-16 hrs, the primary source of glucose is glycogenolysis
  • After 16-48 hrs, the primary source of glucose is gluconeogenesis (Option B)

Gluconeogenesis:

  • It is a process in which glucose is synthesized by non-carbohydrate sources such as amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionyl CoA.
  • The major site of gluconeogenesis the liver> kidney.

 

 

Regulation of gluconeogenesis:

  • Glucagon activates fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase and inhibits PFK-1, favoring gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glycolysis
  • The availability of substrates such as alanine, lactate, and glycerol favors gluconeogenesis
  • Acetyl CoA is an allosteric activator of 1st regulatory step of gluconeogenesis (pyruvate carboxylase)

Muscle glycogenolysis (Option C) is used during exercise and muscle activity.

Dietary glucose (Option D) is used in the first 4 hrs after meals.

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma, with a positive family history/history of hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma has a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mismatch repair

Explanation:

  • Mismatch repair defects are primarily associated with HNPCC (Lynch syndrome), leading to an increased risk of colorectal and other cancers.

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome:

  • Characterized by microsatellite instability.
  • The most common gene mutation associated with Lynch syndrome is in the human MutS homolog 2 (hMSH2) gene.
  • Defects in mismatch repair genes, particularly hMSH1 and hMSH2, lead to ineffective repair of DNA replication errors.
  • These gene defects are located on chromosome 2.
  • The inability to correct mismatches during DNA replication increases the risk of mutations, contributing to the development of colon cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Nucleotide excision repair (Option B) associated with xeroderma pigmentosum (XP),Cockayne syndrome (CS) and Trichothiodystrophy (TTD).

Base excision repair (Option C) associated with genetic disorders like some forms of inherited breast and ovarian cancer, Alzheimers and Parkinson disease.

Point mutation (Option D) While they can contribute to cancer, hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma is related to mismatch repair pathway dysfunction, not general point mutations.

questions.text: A young girl presented to the OPD for an examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathione beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cysteine

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of tall, thin and dislocated lens with cystathione beta synthase deficiency indicates Type 1 Homocystinuria. Cysteine is deficient in this patient, thus supplement is required in this case.

Type 1 vs Type 2 Homocystinuria:

Feature

Type - I Homocystinuria

Type - II Homocystinuria

Enzyme Deficiency

Cystathionine beta-synthase

Methionine synthase

Metabolic Pathway Affected

Homocysteine to cystathionine

Homocysteine to methionine

Elevated Metabolites

Homocysteine and methionine

Homocysteine and elevated levels of Cysteine

Biochemical Diagnosis
  • Low levels of cysteine.
  • High levels of methionine.
  • High levels of cysteine.
  • Low levels of methionine.

Treatment
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation

Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet

questions.text: In the diagram provided, which enzymes are identified as E1 and E2, responsible for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pyruvate dehydrogenase and dihydrolipoyl transacetylase

Explanation:

  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is responsible for the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, a crucial step in aerobic glucose metabolism.
  • A deficiency in this complex leads to the accumulation of pyruvate, which is then shunted towards lactate production, resulting in lactic acidosis.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex:

dehydrogenase complex" data-author="" data-hash="11796" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="427" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/6yMTUtSDYeKjLVYStmOY1746433022.png" width="300" />

 

dehydrogenase complex" data-author="" data-hash="11798" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="400" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rx9qzB63H4OSsflR9P0n1746433050.png" width="400" />

 

  • Catalyzes the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in mitochondria.
  • A critical step in aerobic glucose metabolism, as it links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • Structure:
    • 5 Coenzymes - thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), lipoic acid, CoA, FAD, and NAD+.
    • 3 products: NADH, CO2, Acetyl-CoA.
    • 3 substrates: Pyruvate, NAD, CoA.
    • 3 subunits: E1 (PDH / PDC), E2 (dihydrolipoyl transacetylase), and E3 (dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase).
  • Irreversible reaction:
    • Pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is highly exergonic and irreversible, preventing direct synthesis of glucose from acetyl-CoA.
  • Regulation:
    • Inhibition: Acetyl-CoA, NADH, and ATP inhibit PDH to conserve glucose.
    • Phosphorylation: Kinase inactivates, and phosphatase activates PDH based on energy status.
    • Hormonal Control: Insulin activates PDH for fat synthesis
    • Calcium: Activates PDH during muscle contraction.
  • Clinical significance:
    • PDH complex deficiencies are rare but serious genetic disorders causing lactic acidosis, neurological issues, and developmental delays.
    • Thiamine deficiency, common in alcoholics, impairs PDH complex activity, leading to pyruvate accumulation and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A 27 year old female patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication to this uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Transverse lie

Explanation: Transverse lie is not a common complication of uterine didelphys.

Uterine didelphys:

  • Müllerian anomaly characterized by two separate uterine horns, each with its own endometrial cavity and cervix.
  • It results from the failure of fusion of the paired Müllerian ducts.
  • Pregnancies typically occur in one horn, with a higher frequency in the right (76%).
  • It has a better reproductive prognosis due to improved blood supply or earlier diagnosis.
  • Most women with uterine didelphys are asymptomatic but may experience dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, or chronic abdominal pain, often due to an obstructing vaginal septum that causes hematocolpos or hematometrocolpos.
  • Endometriosis (Option B) and genital neoplasms may rarely be reported in association with uterine didelphys.
  • Complications associated with uterine didelphys include:
    • Spontaneous abortion (Option A)
    • Preterm labor (Option C)
    • Cesarean delivery
    • Fetal growth restriction
    • Perinatal mortality
  • Uterine didelphys can be diagnosed using invasive techniques like hysteroscopy, hysterosalpingography, or laparoscopy. However, MRI offers a noninvasive, equally accurate alternative and can also detect associated urinary tract abnormalities.

      

 

Hysterosalpingography

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presented with easy fatigability, irritability and inability to concentrate. Labs revealed the following findings a and b (light and oil immersion respectively) on the bone marrow aspiration. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of easy fatiguability, irritability and inability to concentrate along with the microscopic findings of crumpled tissue appearance of macrophages.
  • Gaucher's disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucosylceramide in RBCs and platelet membranes due to a deficiency in the enzyme Glucocerebrosidase, leading to anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance.

Gaucher's disease:

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Defective enzyme: Glucocerebrosidase
  • Defect in metabolism: Accumulation of cerebroside (Glucosylceramide) in RBCs and platelet membranes. (Option B)
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal RBCs and platelets are engulfed by macrophages leading to accumulation inside macrophages causing wrinkled paper appearance.

 

 

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Substance accumulation

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A (Option A ruled out)

Ganglioside
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase (Option C ruled out)

Sphingomyelin
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

Sanfilippo Syndrome

N-acetyglucosaminidase (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the appropriate management for a 35-year-old woman with choriocarcinoma who presents with metastases to lung spleen and kidney, had a previous molar pregnancy removed 6 months ago, a pretreatment serum hCG level of 10,000IU/ml, a tumor of 6 cm diameter in the uterus, and failed chemotherapy with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) EMACO regimen

Explanation: The patient has stage IV disease (mets to organs other than lungs) with a score of 11 on the WHO prognostic system. Stage 4 (FIGO) is a criterion by itself for the EMACO regimen. Stage 4 or stages 2 and 3 with a risk score > 6 are criteria for High-risk invasive mole and choriocarcinoma.

Modified WHO Prognostic Scoring System as Adapted by FIGO

Low risk = WHO score of 0 to 6.

High risk = WHO score of ≥7.

Management

  • ≤ 6 Score: Single Agent: Methotrexate with alternate day folinic acid
  • ≥ 7 Score: EMACO Regimen (preferred regimen)
  • Etoposide
  • Methotrexate
  • Actinomycin D
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Oncovin

Methotrexate with folinic acid (Option A) is generally given for low-risk GTN and not high-risk GTN with metastasis.

Methotrexate (Option B) alone is not the most appropriate choice in this case. Methotrexate is typically used in combination with folinic acid to maximize its efficacy while minimizing toxicity in low-risk GTN and not high-risk GTN with metastasis.

Hysterectomy (Option D) involves the surgical removal of the uterus. In cases of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, hysterectomy may be considered as a definitive treatment option if the disease is localized and the patient has completed childbearing.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH

Explanation: As this patient has a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement, she requires anticoagulation therapy. Since she is in the third trimester with an INR of 3, the next step is to switch from warfarin to LMWH to reduce the risk of fetal teratogenicity.

Recommendations for anticoagulants in pregnancy:

  • Pregnancy significantly increases the risk of thromboembolism, but anticoagulation is vital for women with mechanical heart valves to prevent valve thrombosis. (if bioprosthetic valve replacement was done, anticoagulation therapy is not needed)
  • Based on recent guidelines, the dose of warfarin is <5 mg. It may be given in the first trimester, but if the dose is ≥5 mg, it needs to be replaced with LMWH during the first trimester.
  • Warfarin is teratogenic, potentially causing miscarriages, stillbirths, and a constellation of birth defects known as fetal warfarin syndrome. (Option C)
    • Skeletal Abnormalities:
      • Nasal hypoplasia
      • Stippled epiphyses
      • Shortened digits or limb abnormalities.
      • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).
    • Craniofacial Abnormalities:
      • Microcephaly (small head size), Midface hypoplasia, Cleft palate
    • Neurological Abnormalities:
      • Intellectual disability or developmental delays.
      • Seizures Growth Abnormalities:
    • Eye Abnormalities:
      • Optic atrophy or blindness
      • Strabismus.
  • Heparin, in both unfractionated (UFH) and low-molecular-weight (LMWH) forms, is considered safer for the fetus during pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta.
  • UFH, even at full anticoagulation doses, is considered inadequate for preventing valve thrombosis in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.
  • LMWH is associated with a lower risk of valve thrombosis compared to UFH, making it a preferred choice for many pregnant women requiring anticoagulation.
  • A common approach is to start LMWH during the first trimester to minimize fetal risks, then switch to warfarin after the first trimester for better valve thrombosis protection. Near term, warfarin is discontinued to reduce bleeding risks during labor, then restarted shortly after delivery.

 

 

  • Regular monitoring of anticoagulation levels
    • PT-INR for warfarin,
    • Anti-Xa levels for LMWH is not normally done, but it is essential during pregnancy.

Stop warfarin and start heparin (Option B): LMWH is preferred over unfractionated heparin due to its longer half-life, once-daily dosing, and fewer side effects. If LMWH is unavailable, unfractionated heparin can be used as an alternative.

Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin (Option D): Aspirin 75-100 mg can be given daily in pregnancy. It can be continued in women with mechanical heart valves if needed for other indications.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a patient who exhibited tendon xanthomas, with his lipid profile indicating serum cholesterol levels of 283 mg/dL and serum LDL levels of 202 mg/dL, and subsequently initiated on lovastatin treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Familial hypercholesterolemia

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of Tendon xanthomas, raised serum cholesterol and ldl levels indicate Familial Hypercholestrolemia.

Feature

Type IIa (Familial Hypercholesterolemia)

Defect

Defective LDL receptors or Apo B-100 ligand region mutation

Lipoprotein Fraction Elevated

LDL

Main Lipid Abnormality

Hypercholesterolemia

Laboratory findings

Raised serum LDL and Cholesterol

Features.
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Coronary artery disease (early onset)
  • Tendon xanthomas

Management
  • Statins
  • PUFA
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise)


Incorrect Options:

Tangier disease (Option B) is associated with very low HDL levels and characteristic features such as orange tonsils and peripheral neuropathy.

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency(Option C) Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Option D) Causes severe hypertriglyceridemia eruptive xanthomas, hepatomegaly, and a creamy layer over clear plasma, not typically elevated LDL.

questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for the occurrence of hyperthermia and muscle rigidity in a patient undergoing surgery while being administered anesthesia with halothane?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Suxamethonium

Explanation:

  • Suxamethonium (Succinylcholine): This depolarizing muscle relaxant can trigger malignant hyperthermia (MH) in genetically susceptible individuals, especially when used with volatile anesthetics like halothane.
  • MH is characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, hypercapnia, and tachycardia due to excessive calcium release in skeletal muscle.
  • Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but life-threatening condition triggered by drugs like succinylcholine and volatile anesthetics (e.g., halothane), requiring prompt treatment with dantrolene to prevent fatal outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

D-curare (Option A): A non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, but it is not associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia.

Cis-atracurium (Option C): A non-depolarizing agent with minimal side effects and no association with MH.

Rocuronium (Option D): Another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant not linked to malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done using the image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hysterosalpingography

Explanation: The investigation shown below is a hysterosalpingography (HSG) with a diagnosis of unicornuate uterus.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG):

  • Visualising the uterine cavity & fallopian tubes by retrograde injection of radiocontrast dye to identify filling defects & blocks.

Preparation
  • NSAID 30 minutes before to prevent tubal spasm.
  • Paracervical block in patients with cervical stenosis.

4 phases of radiographic images taken
  • Pre-contrast preliminary.
  • During contrast filling.
  • Contrast spillage into peritoneum.
  • During deflation and withdrawal.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

Hysteroscopy (Option A) is an operative procedure where a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) is inserted through the vagina and cervix to directly visualize the uterine cavity, aiding in diagnosing and treating uterine conditions.

Saline infusion sonography (Option B) involves injecting sterile saline into the uterus and using transvaginal ultrasound to assess uterine abnormalities like polyps, fibroids, or septa.

Transvaginal ultrasonography (Option D) is a non-invasive imaging technique using high-frequency sound waves to visualize pelvic organs, commonly assessing ovarian cysts, endometrial thickness, and follicle development during fertility treatments.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Arachnoid membrane

Explanation:

  • Arachnoid membrane: This is the final structure pierced during a lumbar puncture before the needle enters the lumbar cistern, where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is present.
  • During a lumbar puncture, the sequence of structures pierced includes skin → subcutaneous tissue → supraspinous ligament → interspinous ligament → ligamentum flavum → dura mater → arachnoid membrane.
  • The needle stops in the lumbar cistern, which lies between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater.

Incorrect Options:

Ligamentum flavum (Option A): This is pierced earlier, just after passing through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and supraspinous and interspinous ligaments.

Dura mater (Option B): This tough, outer meningeal layer is pierced before the arachnoid membrane.

Pia mater (Option D): This innermost meningeal layer closely adheres to the spinal cord and is not pierced during a lumbar puncture unless there is accidental trauma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade ll/I uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What type of urinary incontinence is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stress incontinence

Explanation: Leaking urine on coughing, combined with uterine prolapse and cystocele, indicates a diagnosis of stress incontinence.

Stress urinary incontinence:

  • Descent of the bladder neck below the levator ani muscles and loss of the urethrovesical angle (70–80%) cause funnelling of the bladder neck and upper urethra.
  • Causes of stress urinary incontinence:
    • Atony of pelvic floor muscles
    • Damage to pudendal nerve during vaginal delivery
    • Intrinsic sphincter defect (20-25%)
    • Detrusor overactivity
  • Risk factors:
    • Age
    • Obesity (BMI>20)
    • Smoking
    • Pregnancy
    • Cognitive and functional impairment
    • Chronically increased abdominal pressure (Chronic cough, constipation, occupational lifting)

Overflow incontinence (Option A) refers to the inability to completely empty the bladder, leading to continuous or frequent dribbling of urine. It is typically caused by bladder outlet obstruction or bladder dysfunction.

Urge incontinence (Option B) is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by an involuntary loss of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder and is often triggered by a specific stimulus or without any identifiable cause.

Neurogenic bladder (Option D) refers to bladder dysfunction caused by a neurological problem that interferes with the normal nerve control of bladder function.

questions.text: A young male patient was given a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive, and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) CPR with 20% intralipid

Explanation:

  • Bupivacaine toxicity: Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic known for its potential cardiotoxicity, especially when inadvertently injected intravascularly.
  • This can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias, cardiovascular collapse, and cardiac arrest.
  • 20% intralipid therapy: Lipid emulsion therapy is the treatment of choice for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST).
  • It acts by sequestering the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules ("lipid sink" effect), reducing their availability to cardiac and nervous tissues, and restoring cardiac function.
  • In cases of bupivacaine-induced cardiac arrest, immediate CPR and administration of 20% intralipid therapy are essential to reverse toxicity and improve patient outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

CPR with sodium bicarbonate (Option B): While sodium bicarbonate may help correct acidosis, it is not specific for treating bupivacaine toxicity.

CPR with dobutamine (Option C): Dobutamine is an inotropic agent used for cardiogenic shock but is not effective in reversing LAST.

CPR with calcium (Option D): Calcium is helpful in certain cardiac arrhythmias but does not address the underlying cause of LAST.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

Explanation: Hysteroscopy with septoplasty is the appropriate management as it removes the uterine septum, addressing infertility in the patient.

Hysteroscopic septoplasty:

  • Minimally invasive procedure used to resect a uterine septum under hysteroscopic guidance.
  • It involves the use of a resectoscope or laser for precise removal.
  • The procedure avoids uterine scarring, reduces the need for cesarean sections in future pregnancies, and minimizes the risk of pelvic adhesions compared to transabdominal approaches.
  • Postoperative live birth rates are approximately 85%.

Uterine septum:

  • Results from incomplete regression of the medial müllerian ducts during their fusion.
  • It can partially or completely divide the uterine cavity and may project from the fundus or extend to the cervix.
  • It is the most common congenital uterine malformation in women with infertility.
  • Associated complications include infertility, malpresentation, and increased risk of first- and second-trimester pregnancy loss.

Hysterectomy (Option A) is not appropriate as it involves the removal of the uterus, which is unnecessary for a correctable condition like a uterine septum and would prevent future fertility.

Laparoscopy and metroplasty (Option B) are not preferred as they may require cesarean delivery and can cause pelvic adhesions, leading to infertility. Hysteroscopy with septoplasty directly removes the septum with fewer risks.

Laparotomy and metroplasty (Option D) are not preferred for treating a septate uterus due to the need for cesarean delivery in future pregnancies to prevent uterine rupture and the risk of postoperative pelvic adhesions, which can lead to infertility.

questions.text: What is the specific action being demonstrated in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Head tilt, chin lift

Explanation:

  • Head tilt, chin lift is a technique used to open the airway in an unconscious patient. By tilting the head back and lifting the chin upwards, this maneuver helps to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.
  • This is commonly used in basic life support (BLS) and first aid for unresponsive patients to ensure proper ventilation.

Incorrect Options:

Jaw thrust (Option B): This technique is used when there is suspicion of a spinal injury and the head tilt, chin lift might exacerbate neck injury. It involves pushing the jaw forward to open the airway without tilting the head.

Head extension (Option C): This involves extending the neck backward beyond the neutral position, which may be used in specific cases, but it is not the same as the head tilt, chin lift.

In-line manual stabilization (Option D): This refers to stabilizing the neck and spine to prevent movement, especially when there is a concern of a cervical spine injury. It is not used to open the airway directly.

questions.text: What is the likely vector for the disease in a patient from Uttar Pradesh who presented with symptoms of fever, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, peripheral smear examination showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sandfly

Explanation:

  • The patient described with symptoms like fever, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and a peripheral smear showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast is most likely infected with Leishmania species, which cause visceral leishmaniasis (also known as Kala-azar). The organism observed in the smear (with a kinetoplast) is characteristic of Leishmania amastigotes.
  • Sandflies are the vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania species, including Leishmania donovani, which is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis in India, including Uttar Pradesh.

Life Cycle of Leishmania donovani

  1. Infection of the Vector:
    • A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus, Lutzomyia) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes.
  2. Development in the Sandfly:
    • Inside the sandfly’s midgut, amastigotes transform into promastigotes, which multiply and migrate to the proboscis.
  3. Transmission to the Mammalian Host:
    • When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes.
  4. Transformation in the Host:
    • Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes, which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly.
  5. Replication and Dissemination:
    • Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages.
  6. Transmission Back to the Sandfly:
    • If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues.

 

 

 

Clinical features of kala-azar:

  • Onset: Insidious.
  • The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous.
  • Night sweats
  • Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender.
  • Hepatomegaly is moderate.
  • Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent.
  • Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar).
  • The hair becomes thin and brittle.
  • Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen.
  • Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Ascites and edema may occur due to hypoalbuminemia.
  • Renal involvement is also common.
  • In the late stage of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, VL can present as an opportunistic infection. HIV coinfection rate is 5% in India and 20% in African countries.
  • Secondary infections such as herpes, measles, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and bacillary dysentery may occur.
  • Most untreated patients die in about two years due to some intercurrent disease such as dysentery, diarrhoea and tuberculosis.

 

Child with visceral leishmaniasis with hepatosplenomegaly

Diseases caused by Sandflies:

  • Leishmania
  • Sandfly fever caused by the Toscano virus
  • Bunya virus causing ‘Three-day fever’

Incorrect Options:

Tse-Tse fly (Option B): The Tse-Tse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma species, such as Trypanosoma brucei, which causes sleeping sickness (trypanosomiasis), not Leishmania.

Triatomine bug (Option C): This is the vector for Trypanosoma cruzi, which causes Chagas disease.

Female anopheles mosquito (Option D): This mosquito transmits Plasmodium species, the causative agents of malaria, but not Leishmania.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program for a 10- year-old student in school?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TT/ Td

Explanation:

  • According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, children at the age of 10 years receive the Td vaccine (Tetanus and Diphtheria, previously TT). This booster dose maintains immunity provided by earlier doses given during infancy and early childhood.
