National Immunization Schedule (India)

DPT (Option D): Used for children below 7 years. Beyond this age, the Td vaccine replaces DPT to minimize side effects from higher diphtheria toxoid content.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enveloped ssRNA

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described - cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots), and the development of a maculopapular rash - is highly suggestive of measles (also known as rubeola). Measles is caused by the measles virus, which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

Clinical Stages of Measles:

Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

Complications of Measles:

A. Secondary Bacterial Infections

  • Immune suppression following measles increases susceptibility to bacterial infections.
  • Otitis media and bronchopneumonia are the most frequent bacterial complications.
  • Worsening of underlying tuberculosis with a possible false-negative Mantoux test.

B. Complications Due to Measles Virus Itself

  • Giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht’s pneumonia), primarily in immunocompromised and HIV-infected individuals.
  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup).
  • Diarrhea leading to malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

C. Central Nervous System (CNS) Complications

  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare but severe late complication characterized by progressive CNS deterioration.
  • Other CNS complications include post-measles encephalomyelitis and measles inclusion body encephalitis.

Incorrect Options:

Naked ssRNA (Option B): A virus with naked (non-enveloped) ssRNA does not fit the description of the measles virus. Naked ssRNA viruses, such as enteroviruses or hepatitis A virus, have different clinical presentations.

Naked dsRNA (Option C): There are no naked double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) viruses that cause symptoms like those seen in measles.

Enveloped dsRNA (Option D): Enveloped dsRNA viruses include the rotavirus (which causes gastroenteritis), but the clinical symptoms of rotavirus are not similar to measles.

questions.text: A patient admitted following a road traffic accident has left a blood spill on the hospital floor. Which disinfectant is most appropriate for effectively decontaminating the area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sodium hypochlorite

Explanation:

  • Sodium hypochlorite is the disinfectant of choice for cleaning blood spills on hospital floors due to its potent virucidal, bactericidal, and sporicidal properties.
  • It effectively destroys blood-borne pathogens, including hepatitis B and C viruses and HIV, which might be present in the spilled blood.
  • The recommended concentration for disinfecting blood spills is 1% sodium hypochlorite (10,000 ppm).

Blood Spill Cleaning Protocol

Step

Action

Details

1. PPE

Wear Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

Gloves, goggles/face shield, gown/apron, mask (if necessary) to protect from exposure.

2. Control the Spill Area

Secure and contain the spill

Alert others, prevent access, and use absorbent materials (e.g., paper towels) to contain the spill.

3. Select and Apply Disinfectant

Use appropriate disinfectant

Sodium hypochlorite (1%) is preferred. Apply disinfectant to the spill and allow it to sit for 10 minutes.

4. Clean the Spill

Wipe the area with absorbent materials

Use disposable towels or wipes to clean up the blood and dispose of them in biohazard waste.

5. Disinfect Surrounding Area

Clean the surrounding floor or surfaces

Mop or wipe down the surrounding area with disinfectant to ensure thorough decontamination.

6. Dispose of Contaminated Items

Safely dispose of contaminated materials

Place used gloves, mop heads, towels, and any contaminated materials in a biohazard waste container.

7. Remove and Dispose of PPE

Safely remove PPE and dispose of it

Remove gloves last, ensuring that they are turned inside out. Dispose of PPE in biohazard waste containers.

8. Wash Hands

Clean hands thoroughly after cleaning

Wash hands with soap and water, or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap is unavailable.

9. Documentation and Reporting

Record the incident and inform relevant departments

Document the blood spill and cleaning procedure, and report any potential exposures to infection control.

 

Ethyl alcohol (Option A): Alcohol is effective as a disinfectant for skin or small equipment but is not suitable for blood spills as it gets inactivated by organic matter like blood. It does not have sporicidal properties.

Chlorhexidine (Option B): Chlorhexidine is primarily used for antisepsis (skin preparation before surgery or wound cleaning). It lacks activity against all viruses and is ineffective against bacterial spores.

Formaldehyde (Option D): While formaldehyde is a powerful disinfectant and sterilant, it is a gas at room temperature and not practical for cleaning floors. Its application involves complex procedures and can be hazardous to humans due to its toxic and irritant nature.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can contribute to the development of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Infectious diseases

Explanation:

  • Infectious diseases significantly contribute to malnutrition by increasing metabolic demands, reducing appetite, impairing nutrient absorption, and causing nutrient loss.
  • Common infections such as diarrhea, tuberculosis, parasitic infections, and respiratory infections lead to weight loss, muscle wasting, and stunting.
  • Recurrent infections create a vicious cycle where malnutrition weakens immunity, leading to more infections.

Role of Infectious Diseases in Malnutrition:

Infection

Effect on Nutrition

Diarrheal diseases

Causes fluid and nutrient loss, leading to dehydration and malabsorption.

Tuberculosis (TB)

Increases catabolism (muscle breakdown), leading to weight loss.

Parasitic infections (e.g., hookworm, giardiasis)

Causes iron deficiency anemia, protein loss, and malabsorption.

Measles

Leads to vitamin A deficiency, impairing immune function.

 

Child rearing (Option A): While child rearing practices can influence nutrition (e.g., breastfeeding practices, introduction of complementary foods), it does not directly cause malnutrition in the same way infections can. Poor child rearing practices may contribute, but they are not a primary factor.

Food habits (Option C): Food habits certainly play a role in nutrition, but they alone do not directly cause malnutrition unless they are extreme (e.g., insufficient intake of essential nutrients). In general, food habits are more of a contributing factor rather than a primary cause.

Socioeconomic factors (Option D): Socioeconomic factors, such as poverty, can significantly affect access to adequate food and healthcare, contributing to malnutrition. However, socioeconomic factors are broader and often contribute in conjunction with other factors like food habits and infectious diseases.

questions.text: What is the most relevant information that should be obtained from the medical history of a patient from Chhattisgarh who is experiencing gradual muscle weakness and spasms in the legs, and exhibits only motor impairment upon examination?

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) History of diet.

Explanation:

  • The patient is from Chhattisgarh, a region known for outbreaks of Lathyrism, a neurological disorder caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal).
  • Lathyrism is characterized by gradual-onset spastic paraparesis (muscle weakness and spasms in the legs), with only motor impairment and no sensory loss.
  • The toxin β-N-oxalyl-L-α,β-diaminopropionic acid (β-ODAP) in Khesari dal causes upper motor neuron (UMN) damage, leading to progressive spastic paralysis.

Features of Lathyrism:

Feature

Findings

Cause

Excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal)

Region

Endemic in Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Odisha

Symptoms

Gradual-onset spastic paraparesis, hyperreflexia

Sensory Involvement

Absent (pure motor disorder)

Prevention

Dietary restriction, government bans on Khesari dal

 

History of similar illness in the past (Option A): While a history of similar illness may be relevant in some cases, this patient's symptoms are more likely due to a dietary issue rather than a recurrent illness.

History of fever (Option B): Fever could indicate an infection or inflammation but isn't the primary concern given the gradual onset of symptoms. The absence of fever makes this less relevant in the current context.

History of vaccination (Option C): While vaccination is important for preventing diseases like poliomyelitis, in this case, the gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms suggests a nutritional or metabolic cause rather than a vaccine-preventable disease.

questions.text: What is the probable causative agent involved in the case of two individuals from a group of 20 friends who experienced nausea and vomiting in the early morning after consuming pastries from an external source during a late-night party?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enterotoxin of staphylococcus

Explanation:

  • Staphylococcus aureus produces enterotoxins that are heat-stable and can cause rapid-onset food poisoning. Symptoms typically occur within 2-6 hours of consuming contaminated food, and include nausea, vomiting, and sometimes abdominal cramps. The fact that symptoms occurred soon after eating suggests this mechanism.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can contaminate food, especially if it is improperly handled or stored at room temperature. The bacteria may multiply and produce enterotoxins in the food, which are then ingested and lead to illness. Pastries, if not stored properly, are a common source of contamination.

Disease caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option A)

 

Virulence factors

Key features

Cell wall-associated polymers

 

Peptidoglycan

 

Activates complement-induced release of inflammatory cytokines

Teichoic acid

Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization

Capsular polysaccharide

Inhibits opsonization

Cell surface

Protein A
  • Anti-complementary
  • Anti-phagocytic
  • Co-agglutination

Clumping factor

Responsible for the slide coagulase test

Toxins

Hemolysin

Alpha hemolysin-

  • Lyse sheep and human red blood cells.
  • Toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex, and the circulatory system

Beta-hemolysins or sphingomyelinase

  • Lyse sheep red blood cells only

Panton-Valentine (PVL) Leucocidin
  • Synergohymenotropic toxin
  • Attacks neutrophils, platelets
  • Produced by Methicillin-Resistant Staph. aureus (MRSA)

Enterotoxin (superantigen)
  • Food poisoning
  • Most cases are caused by type A.
  • It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem.

Toxic shock syndrome toxin(TSST) (superantigen)
  • Fatal multisystem disease
  • Tampon-related TSS

Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): the outer layer of the epidermis gets separated from the underlying tissues.
  • Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients.
  • Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo

Enzymes

Coagulase

Clotting of human or rabbit plasma

Lipid hydrolases

Helps in skin and subcutaneous tissue infections

Hyaluronidase
  • Breaks down the connective tissues
  • Staphylokinase, protease

Nuclease

Heat-stable DNase

Incorrect Options:

Emetic toxin of B. cereus (Option B): Bacillus cereus can also cause food poisoning with vomiting (due to its emetic toxin), but the symptoms usually occur within 1-5 hours, which is generally a shorter time frame than seen with Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin. The vomiting in B. cereus is also often associated with rice dishes or foods that have been improperly stored at warm temperatures.

Verocytotoxin from E. coli (Option C): This is produced by Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) strains, such as E. coli O157:H7, and typically causes bloody diarrhea and hemorrhagic colitis, rather than nausea and vomiting alone. It is associated with undercooked meat rather than pastries.

Shiga toxin from Shigella (Option D): Shigella infections cause dysentery, with symptoms like bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and sometimes fever. Shiga toxin is associated with Shigella dysenteriae, but it does not typically cause vomiting without the accompanying diarrhea and blood in stool.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. Which enrichment medium is used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Selenite F broth

Explanation:

  • Selenite F medium is an enrichment medium is used primarily for stool samples to suppress gut bacteria growth while allowing diarrheagenic bacteria (Salmonella, Shigella) to grow.

Enrichment Broth:

  • Liquid media with inhibitory agents selectively promote the growth of specific organisms and inhibit others.
  • Used for isolating pathogens from clinical specimens containing normal flora (e.g., stool, sputum).

Examples:

  1. Tetrathionate broth – Used for Salmonella Typhi isolation.
  2. Gram-negative broth – Used for Shigella isolation.
  3. Selenite F broth – Used for Shigella isolation.
  4. Alkaline peptone water (APW) – Used for Vibrio cholerae isolation.
  5. Lim Broth is an enrichment broth specifically used to enhance the growth of group B streptococci. It provides the necessary nutrients and conditions for the selective multiplication of these organisms.

Incorrect Options:

Robertson cooked meat broth (Option A): This is a general-purpose enrichment medium that supports the growth of a wide variety of organisms but is not specifically selective for Salmonella or Shigella (which might also cause bloody diarrhea).

Alkaline peptone water (Option B): This medium is used for the pre-enrichment of Vibrio species (like Vibrio cholerae) and is not useful for isolating Salmonella or other enteric pathogens causing bloody diarrhea.

Brain heart infusion broth (Option D): This is a non-selective medium used for the growth of a wide range of organisms, including bacteria and fungi, but it is not specifically used for isolating enteric pathogens like Salmonella from stool samples.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for overseeing the school health programs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary health center

Explanation:

  • Primary health centers (PHCs) are primarily responsible for overseeing and implementing school health programs.
  • They conduct regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education in schools, ensuring the overall health and well-being of students.

 

Hierarchical Structure of Health Centers in India:

Level

Name

Function

Population Coverage

Staffing

1

Sub-Centers (SCs) (Option C ruled out)

First point of contact for the community, providing basic healthcare services like immunization, maternal and child health, and health education.

5,000 people in plain areas, 3,000 in hilly/tribal areas

1 Female Health Worker (ANM) and 1 Male Health Worker

2

Primary Health Centers (PHCs)

Provides integrated curative and preventive healthcare services for rural populations. Focuses on maternal and child health, immunization, and family planning.

Serves 30,000 people

Managed by a Medical Officer with supporting healthcare staff

3

Block Primary Health Center (Block PHC)

Referral point for PHCs within the block, providing maternal and child health services, basic surgeries, and diagnostics.

Serves a block population (typically 30,000–50,000 people)

Medical Officer, Nurses, Lab Technicians

4

Community Health Centers (CHCs)

Serves as a referral point for PHCs and provides specialized care.

Serves 80,000 to 1,20,000 people

Staffed with specialists (e.g., surgeons, obstetricians, pediatricians)

5

Sub-Divisional Hospitals (SDHs) (Option D ruled out)

Provides more advanced care than PHCs or CHCs at the sub-divisional level, offering a broader range of medical services and treatments.

Sub-divisional coverage

Specialists, General Medical Practitioners

6

District Hospitals (Option B ruled out)

Provide secondary care services and act as referral points for CHCs. Services include emergency care, surgeries, and specialized treatments.

District-level coverage

Specialists, General Medical Practitioners

7

Tertiary Care Hospitals

Provide advanced medical care and specialized services, such as complex surgeries and treatment for rare conditions.

Multi-district coverage

Highly trained specialists in various medical fields

questions.text: A pregnant woman whose niece lives with her in the same house contracted Varicella. She tested negative for serum antibodies against varicella. What would this mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) She is susceptible to chickenpox

Explanation:

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) causes chickenpox (primary infection) and herpes zoster (reactivation).
  • Serum antibodies against VZV indicate prior infection or vaccination.
  • A negative antibody test means she has never had chickenpox nor been vaccinated, making her susceptible to primary varicella infection (chickenpox).
  • This is particularly concerning in pregnancy, as maternal varicella can lead to congenital varicella syndrome or severe neonatal infection.

Varicella Susceptibility and Immunity

Serology

Interpretation

Risk Status

Positive VZV IgG

Past infection or vaccination

Immune to chickenpox

Negative VZV IgG

No prior exposure

Susceptible to chickenpox

Positive VZV IgM

Recent infection

Active chickenpox infection

 

She is immune to zoster (Option A): Incorrect because her negative antibody test means she has never had VZV, so reactivation as zoster is not possible.

She is susceptible to zoster (Option B): Incorrect because zoster occurs due to reactivation of prior VZV infection, which she has never had.

She is immune to chickenpox (Option D): Incorrect because a negative antibody test indicates no immunity to VZV.

questions.text: Which type of microscope can be used to detect the motility of the probable causative organism in a truck driver presenting with painless indurated genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark-field microscope

Explanation:

  • The scenario described - a painless indurated genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity - is highly suggestive of chancre, which is characteristic of syphilis caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. This bacterium is spiral-shaped and motile, and it is best visualized in its motile form using a dark-field microscope.
  • The appearance of Treponema pallidum under dark-field microscopy is a slender spiral structure with slow cork screw movement.

Specimen Collection
  • Lesion cleaned with gauze soaked in warm saline.
  • Margins gently scraped to abrade superficial epithelium.
  • Gentle pressure applied to the lesion base to collect exudate (prevent blood admixture).
  • Serum collected for serology; CSF for neurosyphilis.

Dark ground microscopy
  • Exudate collected and placed under a coverslip.
  • Examined with dark ground microscopy.
  • T. pallidum identified by slender, tightly coiled spiral structure showing slow movement.

Silver Impregnation Staining
  • Fontana’s method is used for staining smear films.
  • Levaditi’s method is preferred for tissue sections.

Incorrect Options:

Electron microscope (Option B): While an electron microscope can provide highly detailed images of the organism at a subcellular level, it is not commonly used in routine clinical settings for motility testing or diagnosing syphilis due to its complexity and the need for specialized equipment.

Light microscope (Option C) can be used to visualize organisms, but it cannot detect the motility of Treponema pallidum. The bacterium is too small and thin to be easily observed using a light microscope without the use of specific stains or techniques.

Fluorescent microscope (Option D) is typically used for detecting organisms or structures that have been labeled with a fluorescent dye. While it can be useful for other types of pathogens, syphilis diagnosis usually involves direct examination using dark-field microscopy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, a second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and a third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Explanation: The history of recurrent miscarriages and preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia in this G4A3 woman strongly indicates antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • APAs or binding β2-glycoprotein-I causes platelet aggregation & endothelial dysfunction → Leading to thrombus formation.
    • Reduced prostaglandin E2, decreased protein C or S activity & increased prothrombin activation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Venous Thrombosis
    • Arterial Thrombosis: MI, Stroke
    • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia/ thrombocytopenia
    • Renal artery or vein; Glomerular thrombosis
    • Pregnancy:
      • Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome
      • Recurrent miscarriage
      • Preterm delivery
      • Fetal-growth restriction
      • Fetal death

Diagnosis: Modified Sapporo/Sydney criteria: At least 1 clinical + 1 lab criterion needed for diagnosis.

Clinical Criteria

Laboratory Criteria

Obstetrical:

  • ≥3 unexplained consecutive spontaneous miscarriages < 10 weeks gestation
  • ≥1 unexplained fetal death(s) ≥10weeks' gestation
  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

Vascular:

  • ≥1 episode of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue
  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant (ISTH guidelines)
  • Medium/high serum levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
  • Anti-β2 glycoprotein-I IgG or IgM antibody

Management:

APS Subtype

Antithrombotic Therapy

APS with prior thrombosis
  • Start therapeutic LMWH after confirming intrauterine pregnancy. (40 mg enoxaparin daily.)
  • Begin low-dose aspirin (LDA) before or immediately upon pregnancy confirmation. (60 to 80 mg daily)
  • Avoid oral anticoagulants and factor Xa inhibitors throughout pregnancy.

APS with pregnancy morbidity but no prior thrombosis
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin upon confirmation of pregnancy,
  • LDA (81 mg) as early as possible.

Patients with early or late pregnancy loss
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin,
  • LDA (81 mg) from before pregnancy or as soon as known

Preeclampsia with severe features or placental insufficiency
  • LDA from before pregnancy or as soon as known,
  • Consider LMWH in specific cases

Hydroxychloroquine: For recurrent pregnancy loss despite standard therapy.

IVIG and Prednisone: For refractory cases to reduce recurrent pregnancy loss; low-dose prednisone is preferred to minimise maternal and fetal risks.

Syphilis (Option A), caused by Treponema pallidum, can lead to adverse pregnancy outcomes like miscarriage or stillbirth. However, the recurrent pregnancy loss pattern described here is not characteristic of syphilis.

TORCH infections (Option C), including Toxoplasma, Rubella, CMV, and HSV, can cause sporadic spontaneous pregnancy loss and congenital abnormalities. However, the recurrent loss and preeclampsia pattern in this case is not typical of TORCH infections.

Gestational diabetic mellitus (Option D) causes complications like fetal growth issues, preterm birth, and preeclampsia, but it is not associated with the recurrent pregnancy loss pattern observed in this case.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She had a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had a lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sheehan syndrome

Explanation:

The patient's history of fatigue, constipation, lactational failure, postpartum amenorrhea, and multiple blood transfusions points to Sheehan syndrome, which is caused by pituitary infarction following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Sheehan Syndrome:

 

Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms
  • Failure to lactate
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Fatigue
  • Amenorrhea
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Decreased libido
  • Weight gain
  • Cold intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).
  • MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

Treatment:

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)
  • Sheehan’s Syndrome should be differentiated from other conditions causing hypopituitarism, such as pituitary apoplexy, hypothyroidism, Addison’s disease, empty sella syndrome, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, hypoprolactinemia.

Hypothyroidism (Option B): While hypothyroidism can cause fatigue and constipation, it does not typically cause lactational failure, and the history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery makes Sheehan syndrome a more likely diagnosis in this case.

Premature ovarian failure (Option C): While premature ovarian failure causes amenorrhea and hormonal imbalances, it does not explain the lactational failure or the history of significant blood loss after delivery, which points more towards Sheehan syndrome.

Delayed blood transfusion reaction (Option D) is unlikely in this case, as it typically presents with immediate symptoms related to the transfusion and does not account for the prolonged symptoms, such as lactational failure and amenorrhea, described by the patient.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wuchereria bancrofti

Explanation:

  • The parasite given is Wuchereria bancrofti, which is sheathed and has nuclei that do not extend to the tip of the tail.

Species

Wuchereria bancrofti (Option D)

Brugia malayi

(Option B ruled out)

Loa loa

Mansonella perstans

(Option D ruled out)

Mansonella ozzardi

Onchocerca volvulus

Shape

Posterior end

Tail nuclei

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

2 nuclei at the tip of the tail

Nuclei form continuous rows in the tip of the tail

Nuclei extend to the tip of the tail

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

Sheath

Sheathed

Unsheathed

Periodicity

Nocturnal

Nocturnal

Diurnal

Nonperiodic

Primary Vector

Culex, Anopheles, Aedes

Mansonia spp., Anopheles

Chrysops spp.

Simulium spp.

Culicoides

Culicoides

Brugia timori (Option C):

  • Periodicity: Nocturnal
  • Vector: Anopheles barbirostris

questions.text: What is the standard unit for measuring the brightness of light emitted from a single point source?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candela

Explanation:

  • Candela is the standard unit for measuring the brightness of light emitted from a single point source. It measures the intensity of light emitted in a particular direction.
  • It is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI) and is used to describe the luminous intensity of light.

Photometry and Measurement of Light

  • Photometry is the branch of physics that deals with the measurement of visible light, considering human eye sensitivity. Light measurement is crucial in various applications, including illumination engineering, display technology, medical imaging, and astronomy.

Photometric Quantities and Their Units

Photometric Quantity

Definition

SI Unit

Common Usage

Luminous Intensity

Brightness of a light source in a specific direction

Candela (cd)

Used in lighting design, LED specifications

Luminous Flux

Total light emitted in all directions

Lumen (lm) (Option D ruled out)

Used in bulb ratings, projector brightness

Illuminance

Light received per unit area

Lux (lx) (lm/m²) (Option B ruled out)

 

Used in workplace lighting standards, photography

Luminance

Perceived brightness of a surface emitting or reflecting light

Nit (cd/m²) or Lambert (Option C ruled out)

Used in display screens, road signs

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting with pharyngitis, when a throat swab is collected and sent for culture, in which colored bin should the used swab be disposed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Yellow

Explanation:

  • In healthcare settings, waste disposal is categorized by color-coded bins to ensure safe and proper handling of different types of waste.
  • Yellow bins are typically used for disposing of clinical waste that is contaminated or potentially infectious, such as used swabs, tissues, or any material that has come into contact with body fluids.
  • In the case of a throat swab collected for culture, it would be considered infectious waste until proven otherwise, so it should be disposed of in a yellow bin.

Biomedical Waste Disposal:

Color

Category of Waste

Description

Examples

Yellow

Infectious waste

Waste that may contain pathogens and poses a risk of infection.

Contaminated dressings, swabs, body fluids, soiled surgical items

Red (Option A ruled out)

Contaminated waste (non-infectious)

Waste that has been contaminated with bodily fluids but is not infectious.

Non-sharp waste like plastic, tubing, syringes (without needles), and items used in medical treatments

Blue (Option D ruled out)

Glass waste

Waste consisting of broken glassware or other glass items.

Glass vials, ampoules, broken glass containers

White (Translucent) (Option C ruled out)

Sharp waste

Waste items that can cut or puncture, requiring careful handling.

Needles, syringes with needles, scalpels, razors, and broken glass

Black

General or non-biomedical waste

Non-hazardous waste that is not contaminated by biological or medical waste.

Paper, packaging, non-infectious non-medical waste

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially, but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prozone phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The prozone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antibodies in the serum sample relative to the antigen during an agglutination test. This excess of antibodies can prevent the formation of an optimal antigen-antibody complex, which is necessary for visible agglutination. As a result, the test appears negative initially, but after performing serial dilutions of the serum (reducing the concentration of antibodies), the agglutination becomes visible and the test turns positive.

Brucella features:

  • Brucella melitensis is the most pathogenic species for humans.

Characteristics of Brucella:

Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Zoonotic Nature: Primarily affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, and pigs. Humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products

Clinical Presentation in Humans:

  • Symptoms: Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, and joint pain
  • Also known as Undulant fever, Mediterranean fever, Maltese fever
  • Diagnosis is challenging due to nonspecific symptoms and relies on high clinical suspicion

Diagnosis of Brucellosis:

Laboratory Testing Methods:

  • Blood Culture:
    • Most definitive diagnostic method
    • Requires trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in biphasic blood culture bottles (e.g., Castaneda method)
    • Large blood volume (5 ml) recommended due to low bacterial load
    • Incubation at 37°C under 5-10% CO2 for at least 6-8 weeks
    • Positive in approximately 30-50% of cases
    • Bone marrow cultures may have a higher yield
  • Serological Tests:
    • Used when culture methods are unsuccessful

Serological Test Types:

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Treatment of Brucellosis:

  • Antibiotics:
    • Standard treatment for adults: Doxycycline for 45 days and intramuscular streptomycin daily for the first two weeks
    • Children: Cotrimoxazole with rifampicin or gentamycin

Incorrect Options:

Incomplete antibodies (Option A): Incomplete antibodies are those that cannot cause agglutination on their own because they are not capable of forming a stable cross-link between the antigen and the antibody. However, they are not typically the cause of a negative test that turns positive after dilution. Incomplete antibodies may still contribute to a weaker or partial reaction but do not explain the phenomenon of dilution-dependent agglutination.

Complement inactivation (Option B): Complement inactivation refers to the loss of complement activity in a serum sample, which can affect some tests that depend on the complement system for full reaction (e.g., some hemolysis or lysis tests). This does not explain the initial negative and later positive agglutination result seen in the prozone phenomenon.

Post zone phenomenon (Option D): The postzone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antigen relative to the antibody, leading to a lack of agglutination because the antigen is in excess and does not form sufficient complexes with the antibodies. This does not apply to the situation described, where the serum antibody concentration was initially too high, not the antigen concentration.

questions.text:
A researcher wants to know whether there is an association of CRP values with the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke. The study group was divided into quintiles and the following table is formed based on the study results. Which of the following statements is true regarding the relationship between CRP and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke?


	
		
			
			Quintile
			
			
			CRP Values (mg/L)
			
			
			Relative Risk (RR)
			
			
			Study Population
			
		
		
			
			1
			
			
			0.1–1
			
			
			1
			
			
			6000
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			1.1–2
			
			
			1.3
			
			
			6000
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			2.1–3
			
			
			1.7
			
			
			6000
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			3.1–4
			
			
			2.1
			
			
			6000
			
		
		
			
			5
			
			
			4.1–5
			
			
			2.8
			
			
			6000

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP increases the risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In quintile 1, there is no risk of Ml/stroke

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increase in CRP increases the risk of MI/stroke

Explanation:

  • C-reactive protein (CRP) is an inflammatory marker associated with cardiovascular disease risk.
  • In the study, the relative risk (RR) increases progressively as CRP levels increase across quintiles:

Quintile

CRP (mg/L)

Relative Risk (RR)

1

0.1–1.0

1.0 (Baseline)

2

1.1–2.0

1.3

3

2.1–3.0

1.7

4

3.1–4.0

2.1

5

4.1–5.0

2.8
  • Higher CRP levels are associated with an increasing relative risk of MI/stroke, indicating a positive correlation.
  • Inflammation plays a key role in atherosclerosis, which explains the increased risk.

 

CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke (Option A): This is incorrect. The increasing relative risk with rising CRP values shows that CRP is indeed associated with the risk of MI/stroke.

Increase in CRP decreases the risk of MI/stroke (Option C): This is incorrect because the relative risk increases as CRP levels rise, indicating an increased risk, not a decrease.

In quintile 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke (Option D): This is incorrect. Although the relative risk in quintile 1 is 1 (the reference group), it does not imply that there is no risk of MI/stroke. It means that the baseline risk is used for comparison, but individuals in this group still have some risk.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is not included in the Global Hunger Index (GHI)?

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infant mortality rate

Explanation:

  • Infant mortality rate is not directly included in the Global Hunger Index. While it is closely related to hunger and malnutrition, it specifically refers to the death of infants under 1 year, whereas the GHI focuses on the broader effects of malnutrition, child undernourishment, and under-5 mortality.

Global Hunger Index (GHI):

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a comprehensive tool designed to assess and track hunger worldwide. It incorporates four key indicators that represent various dimensions of hunger:

Components of the Global Hunger Index

  1. Undernourishment

    • Definition: Measures the percentage of the population whose caloric intake is insufficient to meet the minimum dietary energy requirements.

    • Significance: Reflects overall food access and availability in a population, indicating widespread nutritional insufficiency.

  2. Child Stunting

    • Definition: The proportion of children under five years old who have low height for their age, signifying chronic undernutrition.

    • Significance: Highlights the impact of long-term nutritional deficiencies and food insecurity, especially among children.

  3. Child Wasting

    • Definition: The percentage of children under five who have low weight for their height, indicating acute undernutrition.

    • Significance: Suggests a recent and severe shortage of food intake or a high incidence of disease, often due to factors like food scarcity or poor health conditions.

  4. Child Mortality

    • Definition: The mortality rate of children under five years old.

    • Significance: Reflects the combination of poor nutrition, inadequate healthcare, and environmental conditions, indicating the overall health and well-being of a population.

Scoring System

The GHI score is on a 100-point scale, with lower scores indicating better nutritional status. The classification is as follows:

  • Low: ≤ 9.9

  • Moderate: 10.0 - 19.9

  • Serious: 20.0 - 34.9

  • Alarming: 35.0 - 49.9

  • Extremely alarming: ≥ 50.0

A higher score indicates a higher level of hunger severity, while a lower score reflects a better situation regarding food security and child nutrition.

2023 GHI Highlights

  • Global Score: 18.3, categorized as moderate hunger. This is a marginal improvement from 19.1 in 2015.

  • Undernourishment: The number of undernourished individuals rose from 572 million (2015) to approximately 735 million in 2023.

  • Most Affected Regions:

    • South Asia and Africa South of the Sahara both scored 27.0, indicating serious hunger.

    • Alarming Hunger Levels: Seen in 9 countries, including Yemen and Burundi.

 

Under-5 mortality rate (Option B): This measures the number of children who die before reaching the age of 5 per 1,000 live births. It serves as an indicator of both health and hunger-related issues.

Percentage of undernourished population (Option C ): This indicator measures the proportion of a population whose caloric intake is insufficient to meet daily energy requirements.

Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years (Option D): This reflects the proportion of children under 5 who suffer from chronic malnutrition or undernourishment.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having a nocturnal cough for the last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Strongylodes stercoralis

Explanation:

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode that can cause strongyloidiasis. It is known to produce larvae that can be detected in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen. The patient's history of chronic steroid use is significant, as steroids can lead to immunosuppression, which in turn can lead to dissemination of Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis typically causes a chronic, indolent infection, which can worsen during immunosuppression or steroid therapy. This can lead to dissemination, causing symptoms like respiratory distress and eosinophilia, which are consistent with the patient's presentation of acute worsening of respiratory symptoms, nocturnal cough, and elevated eosinophils.
  • Strongyloidiasis can involve the lungs as larvae migrate through the lungs before being coughed up and swallowed, which explains the respiratory symptoms.

Rhabditiform larva

Filariform larva

1st stage of the larva (L1).

3d stage of the larva (L3).

Formed when eggs hatch in the small intestine.

Developed from two molts of the L1 larva.

Measures approximately 0.25 mm in length with a short muscul’ar double-bulb esophagus.

Measures about 0.55 mm in length, characterized by a long, slender shape, uniform esophagus & notched tail.

Found in feces.

Seen in hyperinfection & disseminated infection may show in sputum, stool and body fluids.

Diagnostic form

Infective form

 

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis Infection

Effect of Migrating Larvae
  • Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic.
  • Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs.
  • Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour.
  • Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease.

Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae
  • Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss.
  • Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Hyperinfection Syndrome
  • Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae.
  • Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection.
  • Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Disseminated Strongyloidiasis
  • Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis.
  • Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases.
  • Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment.



 

Laboratory Diagnosis

Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis.

Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases.

Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae.

Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections.

Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides.

Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes.

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection.
  • Ivermectin (200 mg/kg daily for 2 days)

Incorrect Options:

Ancylostoma caninum (Option A): This is a hookworm primarily affecting dogs, though it can occasionally infect humans through contact with contaminated soil. However, it is less likely to cause eosinophilic pneumonia or produce larvae detectable in a BAL specimen.

Capillaria philippinensis (Option B): This parasite is responsible for intestinal capillariasis, primarily affecting the intestines and causing symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain, rather than causing respiratory symptoms or eosinophilia associated with respiratory issues. It does not typically involve larvae in the BAL.

Enterobius vermicularis (Option D): This is the cause of pinworm infections, which are generally not associated with eosinophilia or respiratory symptoms. The larvae of Enterobius vermicularis do not typically appear in BAL specimens, as it is primarily an intestinal parasite.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Explanation:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an oxidase-positive strict aerobe that is well-known for causing infections in burn wounds and other areas where there is tissue damage. It is a common pathogen in patients with severe burns and is notorious for causing secondary infections in compromised skin, such as burn wounds.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa has the ability to grow in a wide range of environments, especially in moist conditions, and it is known to produce greenish or blue-green colonies due to the production of pyocyanin and pyoverdin, which are pigments that are characteristic of this bacterium.
  • It is also known for its ability to form biofilms on burn wounds, making infections difficult to treat and often resulting in chronic wound infections.

Oxidase-positive organisms-

Organism

Morphology

Associated Diseases

Neisseria

Gram-negative diplococci

Gonorrhea, Meningitis

Pseudomonas

Gram-negative rods

Opportunistic infections, Pneumonia, UTI

Vibrio

Gram-negative comma-shaped rods

Cholera, Gastroenteritis

Moraxella

Gram-negative diplococci

Respiratory infections (e.g., otitis media, sinusitis)

Campylobacter

Gram-negative curved rods

Gastroenteritis (Campylobacter jejuni)

Aeromonas

Gram-negative rods

Wound infections, Gastroenteritis

Helicobacter

Gram-negative spiral rods

Peptic ulcers, Gastritis (H. pylori)

Legionella

Gram-negative rods

Legionnaires' disease

Brucella

Gram-negative coccobacilli

Brucellosis

Haemophilus

Gram-negative coccobacilli

Pneumonia, Otitis media, Epiglottitis, Meningitis, Sinusitis (H. Influenzae)

Chancroid (H. Ducreyi)

Bordetella

Gram-negative coccobacilli

Pertussis
  • All Enterobacteriaceae are oxidase-negative and catalase-positive, except Plesiomonas.

Incorrect Options:

Klebsiella (Option A): Although Klebsiella spp. can cause infections in burn wounds, they are more commonly associated with nosocomial infections such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections. Klebsiella is oxidase-negative.

Escherichia coli (Option B): While E. coli is a common pathogen, it is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections, gastrointestinal infections, or abdominal infections. It is less likely to be the primary pathogen in burn wound infections, especially in the absence of any associated gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms. E.coli is oxidase-negative.

Salmonella (Option D) is oxidase-negative and can cause gastrointestinal infections or systemic infections, but it is not a typical cause of burn wound infections. Salmonella infections usually present with diarrhea or septicemia, rather than being isolated from burn sites.

questions.text: Which type of thermometer is employed to assess the low air velocity rather than the cooling efficiency of the air?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kata thermometer

Explanation:

  • Kata thermometer is specifically designed to measure low air velocity.
  • It is an alcohol-based thermometer that is heated before use, and the time taken for the temperature to drop from a higher set point to a lower set point is recorded.
  • This cooling time is then used to calculate air movement in still air environments, such as indoor ventilation studies and occupational health assessments.
  • Unlike other thermometers, it does not measure air temperature directly but rather the effect of air movement on heat loss.

Comparison of Thermometers

Thermometer

Purpose

Measures

Kata thermometer

Low air velocity

Rate of heat loss from a heated bulb

Globe thermometer

Radiant heat

Temperature considering radiation from surroundings

Wet globe thermometer

Thermal comfort index

Combination of air temperature, humidity, and radiant heat

Dial thermometer

General temperature

Direct air or surface temperature

 

 

Globe thermometer (Option B): A globe thermometer is used to measure the radiant heat in the environment, typically in the context of assessing the mean radiant temperature (MRT). It is not designed to assess air velocity.

Wet globe thermometer (Option C): A wet globe thermometer measures the cooling efficiency of the air, specifically by assessing both the ambient air temperature and the effect of humidity on heat loss from the body through evaporation. It is used in environmental health studies but focuses on cooling, not air velocity.

Dial thermometer (Option D): A dial thermometer is used to measure temperature, typically in laboratory settings, and does not assess air velocity or cooling efficiency.

questions.text: One week after having unprotected sexual intercourse, a 25-year-old male develops urethral discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria gonorrheae

Explanation:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection (STI). One of the classic symptoms of gonorrhea in men is urethral discharge, which is typically yellow or purulent in appearance, matching the presentation in the image described.
  • Gonorrhea typically presents 1 to 7 days after exposure, making it a plausible cause for the symptoms seen in this 25-year-old male who developed symptoms one week after unprotected sexual intercourse.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly transmitted through unprotected sexual contact, affecting the urethra, rectum, and throat, and can lead to symptoms like painful urination and purulent discharge.

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

Incorrect Options:

Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option B): This bacterium can also cause urethritis and other genitourinary tract infections, but it typically results in a non-purulent discharge, which is less likely to be as yellow and purulent as seen in gonorrhea. Ureaplasma infections can be more asymptomatic and are often detected in the context of chronic symptoms or infertility.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C) (HSV): HSV typically presents with painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitalia, not a purulent urethral discharge. HSV can cause urethritis, but the classic presentation would include painful sores or blisters, which would likely be present in the image if HSV were the cause.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D): Trichomoniasis is caused by a protozoan parasite and can cause urethritis and discharge. However, the discharge is typically frothy, yellow-green, and has a foul odor, which is different from the purulent discharge seen with gonorrhea. Additionally, trichomoniasis usually presents with vaginal symptoms in women, though it can affect men as well.

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

Explanation: In a young woman with infertility and a suggestive ultrasound finding of a uterine anomaly, "Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy" is the most appropriate diagnostic method. It allows direct visualization of the uterus and pelvic structures, confirms tubal patency through chromopertubation, and helps identify anatomical defects, lesions, or adhesions affecting fertility.

Differentiating Bicornuate and Septate Uterus plays a crucial role in arriving at a diagnosis.

  • 3D sonography and MRI provide accurate assessments.
  • Gold standard- Hysteroscopy + Diagnostic Laparoscopy

Hysterosalphingography (Option A) provides information about fallopian tube patency and the uterine cavity's interior contour but does not visualize uterine anomalies or assess the uterus exterior, making it less suitable for diagnosing uterine anomalies.

Laparoscopy (Option C) can visualize pelvic organs but does not assess the interior contour of the uterine cavity, making it insufficient for confirming uterine anomalies.

Transvaginal sonography (Option D) is often used as a screening tool for uterine anomalies but is not definitive for confirming the diagnosis, as it lacks the detail and accuracy of hysteroscopy and laparoscopy.

questions.text: Considering the immune status of a girl child who has been experiencing repeated yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since the age of 3 months, which vaccine should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Measles/MMR

Explanation:

  • Measles/MMR should be avoided due to the live virus components, which can be risky for immunocompromised children.
  • A child who has a history of repeated yeast infections and respiratory viral infections may have an underlying immune deficiency or immunodeficiency disorder.
  • Immunocompromised children, particularly those with T-cell deficiency (such as in conditions like DiGeorge syndrome or severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)), should avoid live vaccines due to the risk of severe infection.
  • The Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine contains live attenuated viruses for measles, mumps, and rubella. In immunocompromised children, live vaccines pose a risk of causing active infections or serious complications due to their weakened immune system.

National Immunization Schedule (India)

Killed IPV (Option A): The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains inactivated (killed) virus, which is safe for immunocompromised children because it cannot cause infection.

DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) (Option C): The DPT vaccine is an inactivated vaccine and is safe for immunocompromised children.

TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid) (Option D): This is a toxoid vaccine and is also safe for immunocompromised children, as it does not contain live bacteria.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination, was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/ position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Occipitoposterior

Explanation: The fetal presentation/position is likely Occipitoposterior, as infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones suggest a posterior fetal position.

Occipito-posterior (OP):

  • Occurs when the occiput is located posteriorly, either over the sacroiliac joint or directly above the sacrum, with the fetus in a vertex presentation.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Inspection: Flattening of the abdomen below the umbilicus, known as infra-umbilical flattening, may be observed.
    • Pelvic examination: Fetal head is not engaged, and the sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not easily palpable.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart tones are typically heard over the flanks, but in the direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.
  • Variants of OP position:
    • Left OP position: The occiput is directed towards the left sacroiliac joint (fourth vertex position).
    • Right OP position: The occiput faces the right sacroiliac joint, which is more common than the left OP position (third vertex position).
    • Direct OP position: The occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

Brow (Option A): In a brow presentation, the fetal head is partially extended, presenting the brow. This position, with a larger head diameter, does not align with infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones, which are more typical of an occipitoposterior position.

Knee (Option B): In a knee presentation, one or both fetal knees are present at the maternal pelvis. This rare presentation is not consistent with infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones, which are more typical of an occipitoposterior position.

Right dorso-anterior (Option D): In a right dorso-anterior presentation, the fetus lies transversely with the back towards the anterior, causing a wide abdomen and the head and breech to be felt in opposite iliac fossae, which occurs in a transverse lie.

questions.text: A primi at term presented with labor pain and multiple painful vesicular lesions on her vulva. No rashes were found on other parts of the body. What will be the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

Explanation: The diagnosis is herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, and the management is Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes transmission.

HSV Infection in Pregnancy:

  • Caused by HSV-1 or HSV-2, typically transmitted through sexual contact. Vertical transmission to the fetus is more likely to be caused by primary infections.
  • Transmission Risk: Highest during labor, but can also occur in utero or postnatally.
  • Diagnosis: Confirm with PCR or culture of lesions.
  • Treatment:
    • Acyclovir (oral or IV) for both primary and recurrent infections.
    • IV acyclovir for severe infections.
    • Pain management: Analgesics or topical anesthetics.
  • Delivery Recommendations: Elective cesarean section is advised if active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms (itching/burning) are present to minimize the risk of transmission to the baby.

Acyclovir and induction of labor (Option B): Inducing labor in the presence of active genital herpes is not recommended, as it increases the risk of neonatal herpes transmission.

Spontaneous delivery (Option C) is not recommended due to the risk of transmitting active genital herpes to the newborn.

Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery (Option D): Even after antiviral therapy, normal vaginal delivery is contraindicated with active genital herpes lesions due to the risk of neonatal herpes transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed by evaluating the patient's treatment and clinical management in a healthcare facility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Process

Explanation:

  • The Process of healthcare evaluation refers to the methods and actions taken during patient care. This includes the assessment of how the patient is managed, the treatments administered, and the clinical decisions made by healthcare providers during their treatment in a healthcare facility.

Components of healthcare evaluation:

Evaluation Type

Description

Focus

Purpose

Structure Evaluation (Option C ruled out)

Assesses the resources and organizational components of healthcare facilities.

Infrastructure, staff qualifications, medical equipment

Ensure the healthcare facility has adequate resources, equipment, and trained staff.

Process Evaluation

Assesses how healthcare services are delivered, focusing on procedures and practices.

Clinical guidelines, care delivery methods, patient interactions

Ensure care is aligned with best practices and protocols.

Outcome Evaluation (Option A ruled out)

Evaluates the results of healthcare interventions.

Health outcomes, symptom improvement, recovery, patient satisfaction

Determine the effectiveness of treatments and interventions in improving health.

Input Evaluation (Option D ruled out)

Assesses the resources available for healthcare.

Financial resources, staff levels, medical supplies

Ensure sufficient resources for effective healthcare delivery.

Cost-Effectiveness Evaluation

Assesses whether the intervention provides good value for the cost.

Cost relative to health outcomes, alternative treatments

Ensure the efficient use of resources and value for money in healthcare.

Patient-Centered Evaluation

Focuses on patient experience and satisfaction.

Patient satisfaction, provider-patient relationship, treatment understanding

Ensure care aligns with patient needs and improves their experience and compliance.

 

Components of health program evaluation:

Component

Definition

Key Focus Areas

Relevance

Assesses whether the program addresses the priority health needs of the target population.

Disease burden, target group needs, alignment with public health goals.

Adequacy

Evaluates whether the resources and scale of the program are sufficient to achieve the intended outcomes.

Coverage, resource allocation, unmet needs.

Accessibility

Measures how easily beneficiaries can access program services.

Geographic, financial, and cultural barriers to access.

Acceptability

Determines whether the program is acceptable to beneficiaries and stakeholders.

Community participation, cultural compatibility, stakeholder feedback.

Equity

Assesses whether the program reduces disparities in health outcomes and services.

Reach among marginalized populations, fairness in resource distribution.

Efficiency

Evaluates the optimal use of resources to achieve desired outcomes.

Cost-efficiency, time management, operational performance.

Effectiveness

Measures the extent to which the program achieves its objectives and desired outcomes.

Reduction in morbidity and mortality, behavior changes, program goals met.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis in the community and a vaccination drive is launched. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Killed and intramuscular.

Explanation:

  • Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is the most common cause of viral encephalitis outbreaks in endemic regions.
  • The Japanese Encephalitis vaccine (JE vaccine) is available in two types: inactivated (killed) and live attenuated.
  • The inactivated (killed) vaccine is commonly given intramuscularly (IM) as part of mass vaccination programs in outbreak settings.
  • Live attenuated vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are administered subcutaneously (SC), but they are generally used for routine immunization rather than in acute outbreak settings.

Types of Japanese Encephalitis Vaccines

Vaccine Type

Examples

Route of Administration

Usage

Inactivated (Killed)

JEEV, IXIARO

Intramuscular (IM)

Used in outbreaks & travelers

Live Attenuated

SA 14-14-2

Subcutaneous (SC)

Routine immunization

 

Live and subcutaneous (Option B): Incorrect. Although there is a live attenuated JE vaccine (e.g., SA 14-14-2), it is usually administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly. However, this option does not align with standard killed vaccines used in most vaccination drives.

Live and intramuscular (Option C): Incorrect. Live attenuated vaccines for JE are administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly.

Killed and subcutaneous (Option D): Incorrect. Killed vaccines are administered intramuscularly, not subcutaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following is the probable cause in a case of tinea capitis where white powdery colonies were obtained from the hair specimen and the hair perforation test was positive on the isolate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

Explanation:

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp, commonly caused by dermatophytes. In this case, the white powdery colonies observed from the hair specimen and the positive hair perforation test are key diagnostic clues.
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is a common cause of tinea capitis, and it is known for producing white, powdery colonies on culture media. The hair perforation test is used to differentiate dermatophytes, and a positive result indicates that the organism can break down the hair shaft, a characteristic feature of Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is also capable of infecting both the hair and skin, and its positive perforation test helps distinguish it from other dermatophytes.

Hair Perforation Test

  • Purpose: Differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Procedure

  1. Place strands of human hair in a petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water.
  2. Autoclave the dish.
  3. Add sterile 10% yeast extract and fragments of the test fungus to the hair.
  4. Incubate at 25°C for 2-3 weeks.
  5. Examine the hair microscopically with a lactophenol cotton blue-stained wet preparation.

Test Results

  • Positive- If T. mentagrophytes is present:
    • The hair shaft appears wedge-shaped due to surface erosion. (Option C)
  • Negative- T. rubrum (Option A ruled out)

Characteristics of Fungal Infections:

  • Both T. rubrum and T. mentagrophytes cause ectothrix hair infections, where arthrospores form a sheath around the hair.
  • T. rubrum is the most common dermatophyte in humans, often leading to chronic, treatment-resistant lesions.

Identification Methods

Method

Description

Macroscopic examination

Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media

Urea hydrolysis test

Determines ability to hydrolyze urea

Growth on polished rice or special media

Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions

Temperature tolerance test

Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures

Nutritional requirements test

Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamins

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Trichophyton rubrum (Option A): This species is typically associated with tinea corporis (ringworm), tinea pedis (athlete’s foot), and onychomycosis (nail infection). It produces red to yellowish colonies and does not typically give a positive hair perforation test, making it less likely to be the cause of tinea capitis in this case.

Trichophyton schoenleinii (Option B): This organism is a rare cause of tinea capitis, especially in children, and is known for producing scaly, grayish-white colonies. It typically produces a negative hair perforation test, so it is unlikely in this case.

Trichophyton violaceum (Option D): This species is associated with tinea capitis, but it usually forms purple or violet-colored colonies rather than white powdery colonies. Moreover, it does not typically show a positive hair perforation test, making it less likely as the causative agent in this case.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. Upon further investigation, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myomectomy

Explanation: The appropriate management is myomectomy to remove the fibroids and preserve fertility, as intramural fibroids can affect implantation and pregnancy, and the patient wishes to retain the uterus.

Myomectomy:

  • Surgical removal of fibroids while preserving the uterus.
  • It is indicated for women with infertility, those desiring pregnancy, or those wishing to keep the uterus.
  • By removing the intramural fibroids, the uterine cavity is optimized for embryo implantation, increasing the chances of successful conception and pregnancy.
  • It can be done via hysteroscopy or laparoscopy.
 

Hysteroscopy

Laparoscopy

Indication
  • Fibroid of 3–4 cm in diameter
  • Type 0 submucosal
  • Type 1 submucosal
  • Subserous
  • Intramural fibroids
  • Type 2 submucosal

Instrument used
  • Electrocautery
  • Electro-diathermy
  • Harmonics
  • Laser
  • Extracorporeal sutures

Uterine artery embolization (Option A) is a non-surgical procedure that blocks the blood supply to the fibroids, causing them to shrink. However, it may reduce fertility and is not recommended in this case, as the patient desires to retain fertility.

Artificial reproductive techniques (Option C) may be considered later if infertility persists, but myomectomy is the preferred approach to address the fibroids as the likely cause of infertility.

GnRH analogues (Option D) temporarily shrink fibroids by suppressing estrogen production and may be used preoperatively to reduce fibroid size, but they are not the primary treatment in this case.

questions.text:
What is the classification of the air quality index in Delhi station on November 23, based on the provided air pollution index chart for 4 consecutive days?


	
		
			
			Date
			
			
			AQI
			
		
		
			
			November 21
			
			
			350
			
		
		
			
			November 22
			
			
			340
			
		
		
			
			November 23
			
			
			407
			
		
		
			
			November 24
			
			
			356
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Severe

Explanation:

  • The Air Quality Index (AQI) is classified as follows in India:

51-100

101-200

201-300

401-500

Severe

Severe health impacts, emergency conditions
  • On November 23, the AQI was 407, which falls into the Severe category (401-500).
  • This indicates serious respiratory health effects and requires urgent measures to reduce pollution exposure.

Air Quality Index (AQI) and Its Classification

The Air Quality Index (AQI) is a standardized measure used to assess air pollution levels and their impact on human health. It is calculated based on the concentration of major air pollutants, including:

  • Particulate Matter (PM10, PM2.5)
  • Nitrogen Dioxide (NO₂)
  • Sulfur Dioxide (SO₂)
  • Carbon Monoxide (CO)
  • Ozone (O₃)

AQI Categories and Health Impacts

AQI Range

0-50

Good

Minimal or no impact

51-100

Satisfactory

101-200

Moderate

201-300

Poor

Increased discomfort, especially for children, elderly, and those with lung diseases

301-400

Very Poor

Respiratory illnesses on prolonged exposure

401-500

Severe

Serious health impacts, emergency conditions

 

Moderately polluted (Option A): Incorrect because AQI for moderate air quality is 101-200, whereas 407 is much higher.

Poor (Option B): Incorrect because "Poor" air quality is 201-300, but 407 exceeds this range.

Very poor (Option C): Incorrect because "Very Poor" is 301-400, while 407 is in the Severe category.

questions.text: The Pathanamthitta district of Kerala was affected by floods and the government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. Which other chemical will be distributed along with it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Malathion

Explanation:

  • Doxycycline is given as prophylaxis against Leptospirosis, a common infection after floods due to contaminated water exposure.
  • Floods also increase mosquito breeding, leading to a rise in vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue.
  • Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide used for mosquito control, making it the appropriate choice for distribution alongside doxycycline.
  • Other options (Zinc phosphide, Lindane, Paris green) are not relevant for mosquito control in flood conditions.

Chemicals Used in Public Health Disease Control

Chemical

Use

Relevance in Floods

Malathion

Mosquito control (insecticide)

Prevents malaria, dengue

Zinc phosphide

Rodenticide (kills rats)

Not used for mosquitoes

Lindane

Treats lice and scabies

Not relevant for floods

Paris green

Historical mosquito larvicide

Less commonly used today

 

Zinc phosphide (Option A): It is a rodenticide, but it is not used in flood situations alongside doxycycline.

Lindane (Option C): This is a pesticide used for external treatment of lice and scabies, not typically used for flood-related control.

Paris green (Option D): This is a pesticide primarily used for insect control in agriculture, not in flood disaster management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Physiological

Explanation: The cause of her vaginal discharge is likely physiological, as increased discharge around ovulation occurs approximately 13 days after her last menstrual period.

Leucorrhoea/Physiological vaginal discharge:

  • Refers to an increase in normal vaginal discharge, which can vary in consistency and volume depending on the menstrual cycle.
  • It can occur physiologically in the following conditions:
    • Puberty
    • Ovulation (where the discharge may become more copious and clear, resembling egg white consistency)
    • Pregnancy
    • Pre-menstrual phase (occasionally)
  • The discharge may originate from the cervix or vagina, and a speculum examination can distinguish between the two.
  • If the discharge is cervical, excessive mucoid secretion will be visible at the external os.
  • Normal vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, odourless, non-itchy, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2.
  • This type of discharge is not associated with pathology or infection.

Candidiasis (Option A) is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, typically present with itching, thick white discharge resembling cottage cheese, and vulvar redness or swelling, which is not described here.

Bacterial vaginosis (Option B) is caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria in the vagina, diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, which require at least three of the following five criteria:

  1. Clue cells (epithelial cells with adherent bacteria) present in >20% on microscopic examination.
  2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5.
  3. Positive whiff test with potassium hydroxide (fishy odour).
  4. Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge.
  5. Fishy odour.

Trichomoniasis (Option C) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It typically presents with symptoms such as itching, a frothy yellow-green discharge, and a vaginal odour, none of which are described in this scenario.

questions.text: What is the vector that causes the occurrence of buboes in the community?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Xenopsylla cheopis.

Explanation:

  • Buboes are swollen lymph nodes that are typically associated with bubonic plague, which is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis.

  • The vector responsible for transmitting Y. pestis to humans is the rat flea Xenopsylla cheopis. The fleas bite infected rats, and when they bite humans, they transmit the bacterium, leading to the formation of buboes.

 

 

Diseases and their vectors:

Disease

Vector

Identification

Habitat

Details

Malaria

Female Anopheles mosquito (Option D ruled out)

 

Slender body, long legs, and dark-colored spots on wings.

Stagnant, clean water sources like ponds, lakes, and rice fields.

Transmits Plasmodium species causing malaria.

Dengue

Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus

Aedes aegypti

White markings on legs, lyre-shaped pattern on the thorax.

Urban areas, especially around human dwellings and discarded containers.
