Transmits Dengue virus causing dengue fever.

 

Chikungunya

Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus

Aedes albopictus

Similar to Aedes mosquitoes, with black and white banded legs.

Urban and suburban areas, especially in domestic settings.

Transmits Chikungunya virus, causing joint pain.

Japanese Encephalitis

Culex mosquito

Smaller, brown or black, with a distinct scutellum (plate-like structure).

Ponds, marshes, and areas with stagnant water.

Transmits Japanese encephalitis virus, causing encephalitis.

Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar)

Phlebotomus argentipes (sandfly) (Option B ruled out)

Small, yellowish-brown, with a hairy body and long legs.

Sandy, dusty areas, often near human dwellings or animal shelters.

Transmits Leishmania species causing visceral leishmaniasis.

Bubonic Plague

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea)

Small, reddish-brown, flattened body.

Found on rats, especially in urban areas and during rodent infestations.

Transmits Yersinia pestis causing bubonic plague.

Filariasis

Female Culex mosquito

Similar to Anopheles but with more rounded body and darker markings.

Stagnant water, especially in urban and rural areas.

Transmits Wuchereria bancrofti causing lymphatic filariasis.

Zika Virus

Aedes mosquitoes

Aedes albopictus

Similar to Aedes aegypti, black and white striped legs.

Urban and suburban areas, particularly in places with standing water.

Transmits Zika virus causing fever and birth defects.

Tick-borne Encephalitis

Ixodes tick (Option C ruled out)

Small, oval-shaped, with a flattened body.

Forested areas, grasslands, and areas with high animal populations.

Transmits Tick-borne encephalitis virus causing encephalitis.

Rickettsial Diseases

Rhipicephalus (dog tick) and other ticks

Oval, flat, with prominent mouthparts.

Grasslands, forests, and around domesticated animals.

Transmits Rickettsia bacteria causing typhus, scrub typhus, etc.

Malaria (P. falciparum)

Female Anopheles mosquito (Option D ruled out)

 

Same as malaria vector.

Found in areas with stagnant water and human proximity.

Responsible for severe malaria (Plasmodium falciparum).

Scrub Typhus

Leptotrombidium mites (chiggers)

 

Small, red, and often barely visible to the naked eye.

Rural and semi-rural areas with dense vegetation.

Transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi causing scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT, and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus?

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery

Explanation: In the case of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), the vessels are ligated in the following order: uterine artery → ovarian artery → internal iliac artery.

  • The uterine artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery, is the primary vessel targeted for ligation, as it supplies most of the blood to the uterus.

  • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated between the upper and lower segments of the uterus, at the lateral border.

  • If bleeding persists, the ovarian artery arising from the abdominal aorta may be ligated just below the ovarian ligament.

  • Finally, if bleeding continues, the anterior division of the internal iliac artery is ligated about 5 cm distal to the common iliac bifurcation.

  • Bilateral or unilateral ligation of the internal iliac artery reduces pulse pressure in the arteries distal to the ligation, promoting hemostasis through pressure and clot formation.

Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery (Option B): The external iliac artery does not directly supply the uterus and would not address uterine bleeding.

Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery (Option C): The vaginal artery supplies the vagina and lower uterus but is not typically targeted for ligation in postpartum hemorrhage.

Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery (Option D): The pudendal artery supplies the perineum and external genitalia, not the uterus, making it unsuitable for controlling uterine bleeding.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. What is the most common complication that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endometriosis

Explanation: A teenage patient with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and a transverse vaginal septum is most likely to develop endometriosis due to retrograde menstruation.

  • Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue grows outside the uterus, causing pelvic pain and other symptoms.

  • A transverse vaginal septum causes vaginal obstruction, leading to retrograde menstruation, where menstrual blood flows back into the pelvis instead of exiting the body.

  • According to Sampson's theory, retrograde menstruation allows endometrial cells to implant in the pelvic cavity. This leads to the development of endometriosis, which results in dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

Tubo-ovarian abscess (Option B): A transverse vaginal septum does not directly cause tubo-ovarian abscesses, which are more commonly associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Dermoid cyst (Option C) is an ovarian cyst containing tissues like hair, skin, and teeth. It is not directly related to a transverse vaginal septum and is not the most common complication in this case.

Theca lutein cyst (Option D) are associated with hormonal imbalances, particularly in gestational trophoblastic disease or multiple gestations. They are not directly related to the presence of a transverse vaginal septum.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigue, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1 cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anthracotic pigment

Explanation:

  • Anthracotic pigment is a black, carbon-based pigment commonly seen in lymph nodes and lungs, as well as in individuals with chronic smoking or environmental pollution exposure.
  • These particles are engulfed by macrophages in the lungs and then transported to nearby lymph nodes, often leading to anthracosis.
  • HPE shows carbon-laden macrophages.
  • In patients with lung cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, the presence of hilar lymphadenopathy and black pigment is a common finding due to the direct proximity of the lungs and lymphatic drainage of carbon particles.


Melanin (Option B) is responsible for skin and hair pigmentation and protects against UV radiation. While it can sometimes be found in melanomas (a type of skin cancer), it is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Lipochrome (Option C) is a group of yellow to brown pigments that arise from the breakdown of lipids (fats). On microscopy, it appears as a yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic pigment, often deposited in the perinuclear location. These pigments can be found in various tissues but are not typically associated with lung diseases or lymph node involvement.

 

Hemosiderin (Option D) is an iron-containing pigment derived from the breakdown of hemoglobin. While hemosiderin can appear brown, it does not appear as a black pigment in the context of smoking-related lung disease or cancer.

questions.text: A female patient recently diagnosed with tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy. Since she is using oral contraceptive pills, she was advised also to use a barrier method of contraception. Why was she given this advice?

choices.text: Rifampicin induces OCP metabolism and causes contraception failure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rifampicin induces OCP metabolism and causes contraception failure

Explanation:

  • Rifampicin is a potent cytochrome P450 enzyme; thus, when given along with OCP, it increases OCP's metabolism, causing contraception failure.
  • To prevent pregnancy, extra precautions must be taken when using barrier methods.

Enzyme inducing drugs

Enzyme inhibiting drugs

  • Barbiturates
  • Phenytoin
  • Carbamazepine
  • Rifampicin
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • Macrolides
  • Azoles
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Omeprazole
  • SSRI’s
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Cimetidine
  • Metronidazole

 

Drugs Affecting metabolism of estrogen/oral contraceptives:

  • Induction of CYP450 enzymes in the liver:
    • Rifampicin induces CYP3A4, resulting in increased estrogen metabolism, leading to contraceptive failure.
  • Interruption with enterohepatic cycling:
    • Seen with penicillins, cephalosporins, tetracyclines, macrolides, antifungals, and sulphonamides.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics reduce small intestine bacteria.

Estrogen Metabolism" data-author="" data-hash="11876" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="238" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/PX4rLT3u4VLKwh8pNllK1746438549.png" width="400" />

 

Teratogenicity of Antitubercular drugs (Option A) is an incorrect answer, as Antitubercular drugs are not known to be teratogenic.

Failure of Antitubercular drugs (Option B) does not occur with concurrent use of ATT and OCP; rather, failure of OCP occurs due to enzyme induction by Rifampicin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal checkup in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) G2P1

Explanation: The correct obstetric score is G2P1, as she is in her second pregnancy (G2), and her previous twin delivery counts as one parity (P1), regardless of the number of babies born.

The obstetric score includes:

Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state, both present and past, irrespective of the period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Number of living children

Note: Twin pregnancy counts as one for both gravida and parity.

G2P2 (Option A): This implies two pregnancies with two full-term deliveries, but her previous twin delivery counts as one parity (P1), and this is her second pregnancy (G2).

G3P2 (Option B): This suggests three pregnancies, which is not supported as she has only had two.

G3P1 (Option D): This indicates three pregnancies, but the scenario confirms only two

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been complaining of fatigue for the past year. The examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the presence of anemia, TLC 150,000/microL, and PBS shows 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. The myeloid-to-erythroid ratio was 18:1. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) FISH and PCR

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with massive splenomegaly, anaemia, and a markedly elevated TLC with myeloblasts, myelocytes, and basophils is highly suggestive of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML), and the most sensitive test for diagnosing CML is FISH and PCR.

 

Investigations to find CML

CBC
  • Normal RBC + Elevated TLC + Elevated platelets

Peripheral smear
  • Left shift with predominant segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes.
  • College girl/garden party appearance.

Bone marrow aspirate
  • Increased Myeloid: Erythroid ratio.
  • Dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Sea blue histiocytes (blue-coloured cytoplasm)
  • Pseudo Gaucher cells

NAP/LAP score

The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is low in CML and can be used to differentiate it from other leukaemias, but it’s not the most sensitive test. (Option B ruled out)

FISH (IOC)
  • Confirms t(9:22) translocation.
  • Analysis to quantify Philadelphia chromosome-positive cells.
  • Estimates the tumour load.

PCR

  • To quantify BCR-ABL-1.
  • It can be a false negative or a false positive.
  • False negative: Early part of the disease.

 

Immunophenotyping (Option A) can be useful for characterising cell surface markers in hematologic malignancies, but it is not the most sensitive test for CML. It is more helpful in identifying acute leukaemias or lymphoproliferative disorders but does not directly detect the genetic mutation responsible for CML.

Flow cytometry (Option D) is primarily used to analyse the immunophenotype of hematologic cells and is useful for detecting acute leukaemias and lymphoproliferative disorders. However, it does not directly detect the Philadelphia chromosome or the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which are key to diagnosing CML.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who is on oral contraceptive pills for contraception has forgotten to take her pills on 4 different days in the last 2 weeks. She presents to the primary health centre, asking for advice. What would you suggest to her?

choices.text: Take 4 pills now, continue the schedule, and use a barrier method of contraception
Take 1 pill now, continue the schedule, and use a barrier method of contraception
Take 1 pill now, use a barrier method, and consider emergency contraception in case of recent intercourse
Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception.

Explanation: Discard the pack, start a new one immediately, and use an alternate method of contraception (e.g., barrier method) for the next 7 days, as missing 4 pills disrupts the contraceptive efficacy.

Missed oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Number of Pills Missed

Timing of Missed Pills

Management

Additional Considerations

1 Pill

Anytime
  • Take the missed pill as soon as remembered and continue the rest at the usual time ( Take two pills in one day).

No additional contraception is needed. Emergency contraception (EC) is not required.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 1 or Week 2
  • Take the most recent missed pill as soon as remembered ( Take two pills in one day) and continue the rest as usual.
  • Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for 7 days.

Consider EC if missed during Week 1 and unprotected sex occurred in the previous 5 days.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 3 or Week 4
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

3 or More Consecutive Pills

Anytime
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient on treatment for infertility came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient? hCG- Human Chronic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Single-dose methotrexate

Explanation: The patient's history of infertility treatment, along with amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, and a beta-hCG value of 28,000 mIU/mL, suggests a possible unruptured ectopic pregnancy, and the most appropriate management is single-dose methotrexate.

Expectant Management: (Option A)

  • Suitable for asymptomatic women with stable or falling β-hCG levels.
  • Predictors of success:
    • Initial β-hCG levels <175 mIU/mL.
    • Significant drop in β-hCG over 48 hours.
    • Sonographic findings of an inhomogeneous mass.
  • Requires close surveillance and emergency care access.

Medical Management: Single or multiple dose of Methotrexate is preferred if:

  • Best candidates are asymptomatic, motivated, and compliant.
  • Predictors of success:
    • Low initial serum β-hCG levels (<5000 mIU/mL).
    • Small ectopic pregnancy size (<3.5 cm).
    • Absence of fetal cardiac activity.
  • Protocols:
    • Single-Dose Protocol: 50 mg/m² MTX intramuscularly.
    • Multidose Protocol: MTX (1 mg/kg) alternates with leucovorin (0.1 mg/kg). Up to four MTX/leucovorin pairs if needed.

Surgical Management:

  • Indications:
    • Hemodynamic instability or tubal rupture.
    • Persistent trophoblast after MTX failure.
  • Procedures:
    • Salpingectomy: (Option C)
      • Removal of the affected fallopian tube.
      • Preferred for ruptured ectopic pregnancies.
  • Salpingostomy:
    • Incision to remove ectopic pregnancy while preserving the tube.
    • Higher risk of persistent trophoblast (5-15%).

Milking of the tube (Option D) is not a recognized treatment for ectopic pregnancy, as it increases the risk of bleeding, tubal damage, and recurrence.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, a webbed neck, thick calves, a shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and an increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical features described are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is a genetic condition caused by the partial or complete absence of one of the X chromosomes (45 XO karyotype).
  • It leads to hypogonadism in phenotypic females.
  • Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

Down syndrome (Option B) results from Trisomy 21. It is associated with features such as intellectual disability, epicanthal folds, flat facial profile, and congenital heart defects but does not include the specific skeletal and physical features seen in Turner syndrome.

Patau syndrome (Option C) occurs due to trisomy 13, and its clinical features include microphthalmia, microcephaly, rocker bottom feet, polycystic kidney disease, and congenital heart disease, none of which are consistent with the features described in the question.

Edward syndrome (Option D) is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18 (Trisomy 18) and is characterized by severe developmental delay, clenched fists, rocker-bottom feet, and heart defects, which differ significantly from the features seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. The absolute eosinophil count is >5000/µL. Chest x-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

Explanation:

  • The nocturnal cough, fever, breathlessness, and wheezing with eosinophilia of >5000/µL and miliary pattern in chest X-ray all point to the diagnosis of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE)

  • TPE is a pulmonary hyperreactive condition triggered by trapped microfilariae in lung tissue, leading to symptoms like nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing.

Pathophysiology:

  • Eosinophils are key in the pathogenesis, triggered by microfilariae released from the lymphatic system that become trapped in pulmonary microcirculation.
  • Eosinophils degranulate, releasing proteins to clear microfilariae and cause lung damage.
  • IL-4 promotes airway hyperactivity, while IFN-gamma suppresses it.
  • An overactive TH2 response increases IL-4, IL-5, and specific IgG, IgM, and IgE antibodies, leading to eosinophilia.

Clinical features:

  • History of travel or residence in filarial endemic areas.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dry, paroxysmal, nocturnal cough
    • Dyspnea
    • Systemic signs (fever, malaise, weight loss)
    • Peripheral eosinophilia (>3,000/mm³)
    • Extrapulmonary signs: Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Physical Findings: Wheezing, crepitations, organomegaly, enlarged lymph nodes.

Investigations:

  • Blood Tests: Leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated IgE, filarial antibody titers.
  • Stool Test: Rule out other parasitic causes.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: Reticulonodular opacities, miliary mottling, or normal in 20-30% of cases.
    • Chest CT: Bronchiectasis, lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion in unclear cases.
  • Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Mixed restrictive and mild to moderate obstructive patterns.

Management:

  • First-line:
    • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 21 days.
    • It targets both microfilariae and adults, leading to dramatic symptom improvement.
  • Adjunctive:
    • Corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation, particularly in chronic cases.
  • Alternative Drugs:
    • Ivermectin and albendazole target microfilariae and adult worms, though there is limited data.

Incorrect Options:

Bronchial asthma (Option A) is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to symptoms such as wheezing, coughing (often nocturnal), breathlessness, and occasionally fever. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of bronchial asthma.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option B) is a severe form of tuberculosis (TB) in which the infection spreads throughout the body, including the lungs. It is characterized by the dissemination of tiny, millimetre-sized lesions throughout various organs, including the lungs, giving a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. The elevated absolute eosinophil count is not typical of miliary tuberculosis.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) (Option D), also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an immune-mediated lung disease caused by the inhalation of various organic substances such as dust, moulds, or animal proteins. The absolute eosinophil count can be elevated in some cases. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of HP.

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and an evening rise in temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leukemia

Explanation:

  • Occupational exposure to benzene is a well-established risk factor for the development of leukemia, particularly AML and ALL.
  • It is a known carcinogen that can cause damage to the bone marrow, leading to disruption of normal blood cell production, which can result in leukemia.
  • The clinical features in this case, such as repeated infections, fatigability, weight loss, and fever, also suggest a hematological malignancy like leukemia.

Risk of specific carcinomas related to specific exposure

Risk of carcinoma

Occupation exposure

Lungs (Option B ruled out)

Arsenic, beryllium, cadmium, chromium, Asbestosis, Silica, radon, Nickel, and aromatic hydrocarbon.

Bladder (Option C ruled out)

Benzidine, Auramine, Beta-naphthylamine, Para amino-diphenyl, Magenta.

Liver

Vinyl chloride, Arsenic.

Leukaemia

Benzene, ethylene oxide.

Skin (Option D ruled out)

Arsenic, ionising radiation, Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Scrotum

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

questions.text: A patient with giant cell arteritis presented with headache, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, and mononeuritis multiplex. What should be the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Steroids

Explanation:

  • The symptoms suggest the diagnosis of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), for which the first line of treatment is administering steroids.

Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA):

  • GCA is an inflammatory condition of medium and large-sized arteries
  • Earlier called temporal arteritis due to temporal artery involvement
  • It's a systemic vasculitis affecting carotid artery branches and the aorta and its major branches
  • It occurs almost exclusively in people over 50 years
  • Shows strong female predominance
  • Genetic associations: HLA-DR4 and HLA-DRB1*04 variants
  • Strong association with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR):
    • 40-50% of GCA patients have PMR
    • 10-20% of PMR patients later develop GCA

Clinical Manifestations:

  1. Common Symptoms:
    • Fever
    • Headaches
    • Malaise and fatigue
    • Anorexia and weight loss
    • Sweats
    • Arthralgias
    • Scalp pain
    • Jaw claudication
  2. Complications:
    • Ischemic optic neuropathy leading to blindness
    • Strokes
    • Scalp/tongue infarction
    • Large vessel complications (in up to 1/3rd of patients):
      • Subclavian artery stenosis
      • Aortic aneurysms (thoracic > abdominal)
      • Risk of aortic rupture or dissection

Treatment Protocol:

  1. Initial Management:
    • Prednisone 40-60 mg/day for 1 month
    • IV methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days if ocular symptoms
    • Aspirin (Option D) 81 mg daily to reduce cranial ischemic complications
  2. Additional Therapies:
    • Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6) FDA approved (Option B)
    • Given as 162 mg SC weekly/biweekly with steroids
    • Methotrexate as alternative steroid-sparing agent
  3. Monitoring:
    • Treatment typically needed for ≥2 years
    • ESR/CRP is useful for monitoring
    • 60-85% have symptom recurrence during tapering
    • Watch for glucocorticoid toxicity (35-65% of patients)

 

Abatacept (Option A) can be used to treat giant cell arteritis along with prednisolone to reduce the risk of relapse. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

Aspirin (Option D) is not the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis and is only prescribed for cases with high ischemic risks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of episodes of palpitations, headache, and profuse sweating for the past few days. MIBG scan shows a deep-seated tumour in the adrenal medulla. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition described?

choices.text: Surgical excision is the definitive treatment
Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension

Explanation:

The above condition is characteristic of pheochromocytoma.

  • Episodes of palpitations, profuse sweating, and headache constitute a classic triad of pheochromocytoma.
  • The diagnosis is typically confirmed by measuring urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamine levels, and the definitive treatment is surgical excision.
  • However, the initial management of hypertension in pheochromocytoma involves starting with an alpha-blocker to prevent a hypertensive crisis. Beta-blockers like propranolol are only added after adequate alpha blockade is established to avoid unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, which could worsen the hypertension.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Vomiting (Option D)
  • Pain abdomen
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines (Option A)
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines
  • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (a metabolite of adrenaline and noradrenaline) (Option A)

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. (Option B)
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) (vs Option C)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of atherosclerosis underwent a circumflex artery bypass. The stent is now placed successfully. He's already taking lisinopril, verapamil, and metoprolol. Which drug should be added?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) P2Y12 receptor blocker

Explanation:

  • P2Y12 receptor blockers, such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, and prasugrel, are antiplatelet medications commonly used in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), including the placement of stents.

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • P2Y12 receptor antagonists are used with aspirin for up to 12 months.
      • Clopidogrel (300mg, followed by 75 mg daily) with aspirin reduces death, reinfarction, and stroke risks in STEMI patients.
      • Newer drugs like ticagrelor (180 mg, followed by 90 mg twice daily) and prasugrel (60 mg, followed by 10 mg daily) are more effective than clopidogrel for ischemic complication prevention in STEMI patients undergoing PCI but have a higher bleeding risk.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Incorrect Options:

Phosphodiesterase-3 (PDE 3) inhibitors (Option A) are commonly used in the treatment of heart failure and peripheral vascular disease.

Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) (Option B) may be considered in some patients with certain indications, such as atrial fibrillation or mechanical heart valves. The routine use of DOACs may not be necessary in all patients who undergo a circumflex artery bypass for atherosclerosis.

Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE 5) inhibitors (Option D), such as sildenafil, tadalafil, and vardenafil, are primarily used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest x-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coarctation of aorta

Explanation:

  • The feeble femoral pulses and raised upper limb blood pressure indicate the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. The enlarged intercostal vessels indicate collaterals.

Coarctation of the Aorta:

  • It is a congenital condition leading to the narrowing of the aortic arch.
  • This narrowing causes a shelf-like obstruction in the descending aorta, typically near the junction of the main and left pulmonary arteries. Less commonly affects the transverse aortic arch.

Physical Examination Findings:

  • Characteristic features:
    • Elevated blood pressure in the upper limbs.
    • Brachiofemoral delay: Diminished or delayed femoral pulses compared to brachial or radial pulses.
  • Lower extremity blood pressure and pulses are lower and delayed than upper extremities (systolic pressure gradient > 20 mmHg between upper & lower extremities) unless significant aortic collaterals have developed.
  • A continuous murmur may be heard over the scapula due to collateral blood flow.

Hemodynamic Effects:

  • Increased afterload on structures receiving oxygenated blood, including the left ventricle, coronary arteries, ascending/transverse aorta, cerebral and arm vessels, and proximal descending aorta.

Associations:

  • A bicuspid aortic valve (typically with right-left commissural fusion) is commonly seen.
  • Turner syndrome should be considered, especially in women with short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, and primary amenorrhea. Turner syndrome often indicates a more severe condition with increased risks.

Prognosis and Risks Post-Surgical Repair:

  • Generally good prognosis after surgical repair.
  • However, patients remain at risk for:
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Premature atherosclerosis
    • Left ventricular failure
    • Aortic aneurysm, dissection, and recurrent coarctation.


Incorrect Options:

Atrial septal defect (Option B) typically causes right heart volume overload, with a fixed split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur at the pulmonary area, reflecting increased pulmonary flow. It does not produce a blood pressure difference between the upper and lower limbs or weak femoral pulses.

The bicuspid aortic valve (Option C) has a varied presentation and has findings of low-pitched systolic ejection murmur and ejection click.

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option D) is a congenital anomaly of the heart where the ductus arteriosus fails to completely close and leads to a continuous machinery murmur below the clavicle, prominent precordial impulse, tachycardia, and bounding peripheral pulses.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/kg, and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • The serum osmolality is low (270 mOsm/kg, below the normal 285–295 mOsm/kg), indicating a diluted serum, while the high urine osmolality (1000 mOsm/kg) shows that the kidneys are still concentrating urine. This pattern is characteristic of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia, most commonly seen in SIADH, where inappropriate ADH secretion leads to water retention and dilution of serum sodium. This severe dilutional hyponatremia can lower sodium levels enough to trigger seizures.

Causes of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia include:

  • Drugs (desmopressin, oxytocin, antidepressants, opioids, thiazide diuretics, carbamazepine or its analogues, vincristine, nicotine, antipsychotics, chlorpropamide, cyclophosphamide, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, MDMA)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
    • Increased ADH leads to water retention with near-normal sodium levels.
    • Water overload leads to the release of ANP ( Atrial natriuretic peptide) from atria.
    • ANP causes natriuresis which leads to euvolemic hyponatremia.
    • No edema occurs.
    • Causes of SIADH:
      • Tumours
      • Central nervous system disorders: stroke, trauma, infection, psychosis, porphyria
      • Pulmonary disorders: pneumonia, tuberculosis, obstructive lung disease
      • Drugs: anticonvulsants, psychotropics, antidepressants, cytotoxics, oral hypoglycaemic agents, opiates
      • Idiopathic
  • Addison's disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • High fluid intake in conditions like primary polydipsia or potomania, caused by a low intake of solutes with relatively high fluid intake
  • Medical testing related to excessive fluids, such as a colonoscopy or cardiac catheterisation
  • Iatrogenic

Incorrect Options:

Plasma osmolality in hypernatremia (Option A) would typically be associated with increased serum osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) due to a deficit of water in relation to sodium.

Hyperkalemia (Option C) refers to an elevated level of potassium in the blood. It is not related to the given scenario as it occurs in conditions of metabolic acidosis, particularly in kidney disease, where potassium excretion is impaired.

Hypokalemia (Option D) is a condition characterized by a low level of potassium in the blood. It is caused by diuretics, GI losses, and hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hard exudate, diabetes mellitus

  • Hard exudates are bright yellow, well-defined deposits caused by leakage of fluid rich in lipids and proteins from damaged retinal capillaries. They often form around microaneurysms and, in the macular region, can create a star-shaped pattern (macular fan/ star), which is seen most commonly in diabetic retinopathy (although it can also be seen in Hypertensive retinopathy).

Hard and Soft Exudates:

Feature

Soft Exudates (Cotton-Wool Spots)

Hard Exudates

Appearance
  • Cloud-like, small, ill-defined, whitish patches
  • Bright yellow, well-defined lipid deposits

Formation Mechanism
  • Caused by ischemia and axonal swelling; blockage of axoplasmic flow
  • Formed by leakage of fluid rich in proteins and lipids

Location
  • Superficial retinal layers, often seen around the optic nerve
  • Seen around leaking microaneurysms, especially in the macula

Common Shape
  • Indistinct and variable; may change shape quickly
  • Radial, star-shaped figure in the macula (macular fan/star)

Main Causes
  • Hypertensive retinopathy (Most common cause)
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Lupus erythematosus (LE)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • Retinopathy associated with AIDS
  • Diabetic retinopathy (Most common cause) (Option B)
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Coats' disease
  • Circinate retinopathy

Image

questions.text: What would be the suitable course of action for managing a 15-year-old girl who is non-adherent to wearing spectacles for her myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Spherical equivalent spectacles

  • The most appropriate management for a 15-year-old girl who is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism would be spherical equivalent spectacles. Spherical equivalent spectacles provide correction for both myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism. They are a non-invasive and reversible option that can effectively improve visual acuity and provide clear vision when worn.

Management options for Astigmatism:

Optical
  • Spectacles: with cylindrical power correction/ spherical equivalent spectacles is the initial treatment option especially for paediatric age group (Option B)
  • Rigid contact lenses: for up to 3D
  • Toric contact lenses: for > 3D astigmatism cases

Refractive Procedures
  • Phototherapeutic keratectomy: Using excimer lens, for irregular astigmatism, can correct up to 3D
  • LASIK (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): can correct up to 5D
  • IOL implantation: Toric IOLs are preferred using Collamer lenses

Surgical
  • Penetrating or Deep Lamellar Anterior Keratoplasty (DLAK): in cases of corneal scarring/ no improvement with other treatment modalities

Incorrect Options:

LASIK (Option A) (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): is a surgical procedure that reshapes the cornea to correct refractive errors. It involves creating a corneal flap and using a laser to remove tissue. LASIK is generally not recommended for individuals under the age of 18 as their eyes are still developing. It is also important to consider the patient's non-compliance with spectacles, which raises concerns about their readiness for a surgical procedure.

Femto LASIK (Option C): is a variation of LASIK that uses a femtosecond laser to create the corneal flap. Similar to LASIK, it is a surgical procedure and carries the same considerations and limitations mentioned above.

Implantable collamer lens (Option D): is a type of intraocular lens that is surgically implanted in the eye to correct refractive errors. It involves placing a lens inside the eye, typically in front of the natural lens. Like LASIK, this is a surgical option that may not be suitable for a non-compliant patient, especially considering the patient's age.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with a fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest x-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pneumonia

Explanation:

  • The given scenario is of pneumonia in an AIDS-infected child. The most common organism causing fever, and productive cough, with given examination findings, is Streptococcus pneumonia.

Pneumonia Etiology and Common Pathogens

  • Main Pathogens: Bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa.
    • Typical Bacteria: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA).
    • Atypical Bacteria: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Legionella species
    • Viruses: Influenza, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2).

Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Atypical Pneumonia

Outpatients

Hospitalised Patients

Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species.

Common causes:

S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae

H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses (influenza, RSV).

Non-ICU

ICU Patients

Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species.

Pathogens include S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae.

Specific Pathogens in Certain Conditions:

Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA):
  • It can cause CAP, often complicating influenza infections.
  • Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) has emerged as a significant cause of necrotizing pneumonia.

Pneumococcal Pneumonia:
  • Higher risk in elderly patients, and those with comorbidities like dementia, heart failure, cerebrovascular disease, alcoholism, smoking, COPD, and HIV infection.

CA-MRSA Pneumonia:
  • More likely in patients with prior skin infections or following viral illnesses.

Enterobacteriaceae:
  • Common in patients recently hospitalized, those treated with antibiotics, or those with comorbidities like alcoholism, heart failure, or renal failure.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
  • Found in patients with severe structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or advanced COPD.

Legionella Infection:
  • Associated with risk factors like diabetes, hematologic malignancies, cancer, severe renal disease, HIV, smoking, male gender, and recent travel (air conditioners, showers, hotels, cruise ships). It is an important cause of atypical pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Pneumocystis jirovecii (Option A) pneumonia (PJP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS. However, it typically presents with non-productive cough, shortness of breath, and bilateral diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C) is another bacterium that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, including those with AIDS. It is known for causing severe infections, including necrotizing pneumonia, but not the most common cause.

Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option D) is an atypical bacterium that can cause pneumonia, particularly in children and young adults. It often presents with a milder respiratory illness, including a persistent cough, headache, sore throat, and patchy infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation in the chest X-ray.

questions.text: In a patient, a 33-year-old female presents with symptoms of gradual vision loss specifically affecting the right halves of both eyes. The question pertains to the location of the lesion in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Left optic tract

  • The clinical presentation of difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes indicates a visual field defect known as Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Optic Tract.

Visual Pathway: Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the Lateral Geniculate body (LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex
  • The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

 

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

 

Anopia (Option D)

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia) (Option C)

Optic Tract/ Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)/ Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Posterior Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

(Option B)

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old infant who was brought in by their mother due to complaints of light sensitivity, difficulty opening the eyes, and excessive tearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma:

  • The presence of classic triad of symptoms- watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm in a 2-month old infant are all consistent with Congenital glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma:

Types
  1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

questions.text: A patient on Digoxin, Potassium chloride, Clarithromycin, Atenolol and Triamterene developed atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate. Investigations showed elevated Digoxin levels. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the rise in serum Digoxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Clarithromycin

Explanation:

  • Atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate along with elevated digoxin levels are suggestive of digoxin toxicity, which has most likely occurred due to concurrent use of Digoxin with Clarithromycin, as clarithromycin inhibits P-glycoprotein.

P-glycoprotein (P-gp), also known as ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1) or multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1), is an efflux transporter protein.

  • It has a major role in the elimination of Digoxin.
  • Its primary function is to pump out drugs from inside the cell to outside the cell
  • Location of Pgp in various body tissues:
    • GIT: Decreases absorption of the drug.
    • Kidney: Increases urinary excretion of the drug.
    • Liver: Increases bile excretion of the drug.
    • Blood-brain-barrier/Placenta: Decreases drug entry into the brain/placental cells.

 

P-glycoprotein Inducer

P-glycoprotein Inhibitor

Activity

Increases the activity of Pgp

Decreases the activity of Pgp

Drugs
  • Rifampicin
  • Phenobarbitone.

Mnemonic: QVACKER

  • Quinidine
  • Verapamil
  • Amiodarone
  • Clarithromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Erythromycin
  • Ritonavir

Combined with Substrate

of p-glycoprotein

(Digoxin)

 

Increases the activity of P-gp.

  • Increased urinary excretion.
  • Digoxin is excreted.

Reduces the activity of P-gp.

  • Reduced urinary excretion.
  • Increased plasma concentration of the drug.
  • Toxicity of digoxin: Arrhythmias.

 

Potassium Chloride (Option A) is a supplement that is used to correct potassium deficiencies and is not known to interact with digoxin metabolism directly.

Atenolol (Option C) is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. While it can interact with digoxin, it typically reduces its effects rather than increasing its effects.

Rifampicin (Option D) is an antitubercular drug that induces P-glycoprotein; thus, it increases the activity of P-gp, which results in increased excretion of Digoxin.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient?

LMP- Last Menstrual Period

USG- Ultrasonography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crown-rump length by USG

Explanation: Ultrasound measurement of the crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method to assess gestational age in early pregnancy.

Gestational Age Determination:

  • Based on the woman's Last Menstrual Period (LMP) and ultrasound measurements of the embryo or fetus.
  • Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the LMP, usually in weeks.
  • If LMP is uncertain or there is a discrepancy between LMP and ultrasound, ultrasound measurements determine the Estimated Due Date (EDD).

Ultrasound parameters for estimation of the gestational age:

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Most accurate before 14 weeks gestation. Accuracy is within 5-7 days.
  • After 14 weeks gestation: Additional measurements like biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC), and femur length (FL) are used for gestational age and fetal weight estimation.

Gestational Age

Parameter

Threshold Value to Redate

<9 weeks

CRL

>5 days

9 to <14 weeks

CRL

>7 days

14 to <16 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>7 days

16 to <22 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>10 days

22 to <28 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>14 days

≥ 28 weeks

BPD, HC, AC, FL

>21 days

Adding 280 days to the LMP (Option B): This method assumes a pregnancy lasts 280 days (40 weeks) from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP). However, it may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles, as variations in cycle length and ovulation timing can affect gestational age calculation.

Fundus examination (Option C): This method estimates gestational age by palpating the top of the uterus to assess the height of the uterine fundus above the pubic symphysis. It is less accurate than ultrasound and can be influenced by factors like maternal weight and fetal position.

Adding 256 days to the LMP (Option D): Similar to Option B, this method assumes a fixed duration of pregnancy but with a shorter duration of 256 days. However, it is not a commonly used or recommended method for estimating gestational age.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Methotrexate in Osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR

Explanation:

  • The anticancer action of methotrexate in osteosarcoma is achieved via competitive inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

Methotrexate is a folate analogue that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and prevents the formation of Tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the synthesis of purine and pyrimidine. This results in decreased availability of nucleotides, and it disrupts DNA synthesis and cell proliferation.

 

Folate Analogues" data-author="" data-hash="11924" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="430" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ELqlyVYpU8PXG4lV3VbK1746441398.png" width="560" />

 

Uses of methotrexate

 

Methotrexate Toxicity and Side Effects:

  • Bone Marrow Suppression
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Alopecia and dermatitis
  • Pneumonitis
  • Nephrotoxicity (high doses)
  • Defective oogenesis or spermatogenesis, abortion, and teratogenesis
  • Hepatotoxic (Cirrhosis )
  • Intrathecal Administration of MTX can cause
    • Meningismus
    • Inflammatory Response in CSF
    • Seizures, coma, and rare cases of death.

Management of Methotrexate Toxicity:

  • Stop methotrexate immediately.
  • Administer leucovorin: It is advised to monitor methotrexate levels to establish the correct dosage and duration for leucovorin rescue therapy.
  • Administer glucarpidase if serum methotrexate concentration is significantly elevated or persistent elevation with renal dysfunction.
  • Hydration and alkalinization: IV fluids with sodium bicarbonate to alkalinize urine and promote methotrexate excretion.
  • Hemodialysis
  • Supportive Care: Blood transfusions, Antibiotics, Platelet transfusions

questions.text: The person in the image is at the risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Exposure keratopathy

  • Image in the question shows Eyelid coloboma - incomplete closure of the embryonic cleft of eyelid, the patient is at the risk of developing Exposure Keratopathy due to increased exposure of corneal area.

Coloboma:

  • Congenital eye malformations caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic cleft, leading to underdeveloped or missing tissues in the uvea, retina, or extending onto the back of the iris.
  • Types of Coloboma:
    • Typical: Found along the inferior aspect of the eye structures, including the iris, lens, choroid, retina, and optic nerve.
    • Atypical: Occurs in the non-inferior location of the eye, like the upper iris or peripheral retina, which are not along the path of the embryonic fissure.

Types of Coloboma and their characteristics:

 

Iris Coloboma
  • Pear-shaped defect extending from the pupil but not always reaching the ciliary body. It may occur alone or be associated with colobomata of the lens, choroid, or retina.

Coloboma of lens
  • Notch-shaped defect typically found along the inferior lens margin due to incomplete development of the suspensory ligament.

Fundus Coloboma
  • Oval or comet-shaped defect with a rounded apex toward the optic disc, often with an irregularly depressed surface.

Coloboma of Optic Disc
  • It appears as an inferior crescent at the lower edge of the disc due to incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.
  • Found in Hypermetropic and Astigmatic eyes.

Coloboma of Lid
  • Notch or gap in the eyelid edge, most commonly on the upper lid, often associated with iris coloboma or accessory auricles.
  • The corneal surface cannot stay lubricated and hence can lead to exposure keratopathy.

Neurotrophic and Neuroparalytic Keratopathy:

Neurotrophic Keratopathy:

  • Caused by trigeminal nerve paralysis.
  • Decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation.
  • May follow procedures like Gasserian ganglion removal or blockage, often used in treating trigeminal neuralgia.

Neuroparalytic Keratopathy:

  • This condition occurs due to facial nerve paralysis, leading to lagophthalmos (inability to close the eye) and subsequent corneal exposure.
  • The patient's history does not suggest facial nerve paralysis, making this less likely.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be consumed by a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis currently on metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alcohol

Explanation:

  • Patients taking metronidazole should not consume alcohol due to the risk of developing a Disulfiram-like reaction due to metronidazole.

Metronidazole, when consumed along with alcohol, causes a disulfiram-like reaction, which can present with abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, psychosis and headache.

Metronidazole

MOA
  • Prodrug is converted to active form through nitro group reduction inside the bacteria → formation of nitric oxide free radicals → causes DNA damage → inhibits replication.
  • Inhibits PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) in protozoa → DNA damage.

Uses

  • Giardiasis (in HIV-positive patients)
  • Entamoeba histolytica → Amebic dysentery & amebic liver abscess
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Dracunculus (guinea worm)
  • Gardenella / bacterial vaginosis
  • Empiric intra-abdominal and soft tissue anaerobic infections
  • H. pylori gastritis (combined with proton pump inhibitor)
  • Prophylaxis for colorectal surgery
  • Fulminant C.difficile infection (IV metronidazole + oral vancomycin)
  • Mild to moderate Crohn's disease

Adverse effects
  • Metallic taste, intensely bitter
  • Headache, nausea, dry mouth (most common)
  • Vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal distress
  • Dysuria, cystitis, and a sense of pelvic pressure
  • Dizziness, vertigo,
  • Neurotoxicity: Peripheral neuropathy, numbness, paresthesias, ataxia
  • Brown color urine
  • Urticaria, flushing, and pruritus ( rare cause of Stevens-Johnson syndrome)

Drug Interaction
  • Inhibitor of CYP enzymes
  • Disulfiram-like effect: abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, headache or psychosis with alcoholic beverages during or within 3 days of therapy.
  • Precipitate lithium toxicity
  • Prothrombin time prolongation with warfarin (anticoagulant).

Contraindications
  • CNS diseases
  • Severe hepatic disease
  • First trimester of pregnancy

 

Grapefruit Juice (Option A) does not interact with Metronidazole and is considered safe to be consumed concurrently.

Benzodiazepines (Option C) are used to treat insomnia, anxiety and other psychiatric conditions, and there are no specific interactions between metronidazole and benzodiazepines.

MAO/SSRI (Option D) are antidepressant agents, and there are no specific interactions between metronidazole and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Which of the following interleukin (IL) is inhibited by Tocilizumab?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IL-6

Explanation:

  • Tocilizumab inhibits interleukin-6 (IL-6).
  • It is a new humanized antibody that binds to soluble, membrane-bound IL-6 receptors and inhibits them, thus preventing IL-6-mediated signalling.
  • IL-6 causes T-cell activation, acute phase protein synthesis and stimulation of inflammation and is involved in the pathogenesis of Rheumatoid arthritis, Giant cell arteritis and cytokine release syndrome.

Uses

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Juvenile Idiopathic arthritis

Adverse effects

  • Upper respiratory tract infections
  • Hypertension
  • Headache
  • Deranged LFT

 

IL-2 receptor (Option A) is inhibited by Daclizumab and Basiliximab, and they are used as immunosuppressive agents after renal and heart transplantation.

IL-5 (Option B) is inhibited by Mepolizumab, Reslizumab, and Benralizumab, which can be used to reduce asthma exacerbations.

IL-4 (Option D) is inhibited by Dupilumab, which can be used to reduce asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable, and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transoesophageal echocardiography

Explanation:

  • The clinical features here point to the diagnosis of aortic dissection, and the most sensitive and specific investigation for this is transesophageal endoscopy.

Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE)

  • TEE uses a transducer at the tip of an endoscope inserted into the oesophagus for clearer views of the heart.
  • Provides better image quality and spatial resolution, especially for posterior structures.
  • Preferred for assessing small cardiac lesions like valvular vegetations, intracardiac thrombi, and congenital abnormalities.
  • Requires topical and systemic anaesthesia, usually conscious sedation.
  • Risks include oesophagal damage, perforation, aspiration, and anaesthesia complications.
  • Used in intubated patients and for intraoperative monitoring during cardiac surgeries.

Clinical Features of Aortic Dissection:

  • Pain: Sudden onset, severe, tearing chest pain, often associated with diaphoresis.
    • Pain location: Can be anterior or posterior chest, commonly in the interscapular region, and may migrate as the dissection progresses.
  • Associated Symptoms:
    • Syncope, dyspnea, and weakness.
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g., hemiplegia, hemianesthesia due to carotid artery obstruction, paraplegia due to spinal cord ischemia).
    • Bowel ischemia, hematuria, and myocardial ischemia.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, aortic regurgitation, pulmonary oedema.
    • Horner's syndrome, superior vena cava syndrome, hoarseness, dysphagia, and airway compromise (from adjacent structure compression).
  • Complications:
    • Acute aortic regurgitation (in >50% of proximal dissections), often causing bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and diastolic murmur.
    • Hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, especially in type A lesions with retrograde dissection.

Investigations/Diagnosis of Aortic Dissection:

  • Chest X-ray: (Option D)
    • Widened superior mediastinum, left-sided pleural effusion in ascending aorta dissection.
    • Widened mediastinum and potentially wider descending aorta in descending aorta dissection.
    • Not highly specific, especially in cases suspecting cardiovascular events.
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG):
    • No myocardial ischemia on ECG helps differentiate aortic dissection from myocardial infarction.
  • Transthoracic Echocardiography:
    • Simple and rapid, with a sensitivity of 60-85% for aortic dissection.
    • Most effective for proximal ascending aorta dissections.
  • Transesophageal Echocardiography:
    • Highly sensitive (98%) and specific (~90%) for detecting dissections of the ascending and descending aorta.
    • Less effective for diagnosing arch dissections.
  • CT and MRI: (Option A)
    • Highly accurate (>90% sensitivity and specificity) for identifying intimal flaps, dissection extent, and involvement of major arteries.
    • Useful for detecting intramural haemorrhage and penetrating ulcers.
  • Selection between CT, MRI, and echocardiography depends on institutional resources and patient hemodynamic stability.


Cardiac enzymes (Option C), such as troponin and creatine kinase-MB elevation, indicate injury or infarction of the heart muscle, which can occur in conditions like a heart attack. While cardiac enzymes are essential in the evaluation of chest pain and suspected myocardial injury, they do not provide immediate information about the current hemodynamic instability and the cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman comes to the OPD for preconception counselling. Which of the following antihypertensives should be discontinued in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor

Explanation:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) should be discontinued in women planning for pregnancy or immediately upon confirmation of pregnancy, as they are teratogenic and associated with risks of fetal malformations, growth retardation, renal agenesis, and reduced amniotic fluid levels.

Antihypertensives in pregnancy

To be used

To be avoided

  • Labetalol (α + β receptor antagonist)
  • Nifedipine (Calcium channel blocker *)
  • α - Methyldopa
  • Hydralazine
  • Thiazides can be used in chronic hypertension in pregnant women
  • ACEi and ARB - teratogenic
  • Diuretic - reduces uteroplacental perfusion
  • Non-selective beta-blocker

* CCB can be useful in preeclampsia, but they must be stopped before labour as they can weaken uterine contractions

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects will the drug have on the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective COX inhibitor that causes premature closure of ductus arteriosus if used in pregnant women.
  • It is a nonselective COX inhibitor that has anti-inflammatory, antipyretic and analgesic properties.
  • It is an approved treatment for the closure of persistent ductus arteriosus in premature infants and is given intravenously, but if used by a pregnant woman, it can prematurely close the ductus arteriosus, which is essential for fetal circulation and can be fatal to the fetus.

Uses

  • Arthritis: Rheumatoid, Gout and Osteoarthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • It has limited use due to the availability of safer, well-tolerated and effective alternatives.

Adverse effects

  • Frontal headache
  • Dizziness
  • Diarrhoea
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Hepatitis
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia
  • Rarely aplastic anemia

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma in a patient with bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Latanoprost

Explanation:

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2α) analogue that is commonly used to lower intraocular pressure in open-angle glaucoma, and it can be used in patients with bronchial asthma as it is not associated with bronchospasm.

Latanoprost

MOA
  • Alters ciliary muscle tension - improves aqueous humour outflow

Advantages

  • High efficacy
  • Once daily application only
  • No systemic side effects

Disadvantages

  • Expensive

Adverse effects

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema (in aphakic patients )

 

Drugs used in the management of glaucoma

Drugs increasing trabecular outflow

  • Miotics
  • Dipivefrine, Epinephrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Netarsidil

Drugs increasing uveoscleral outflow

  • PGF2α analogue - Latanoprost

Drugs decreasing aqueous humour production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Acetazolamide

Hyperosmotic agents

  • Mannitol
  • Urea

Timolol (Option B) is a non-selective beta-blocker that can be used topically to treat glaucoma but it is contraindicated in patients with asthma and COPD as it can have systemic side effects and lead to bronchospasm.

Gemeprost (Option C) is a PGE1 analogue that is used in the medical termination of pregnancy and not in glaucoma.

Mannitol infusion (Option D) is used to treat acute angle closure glaucoma as it causes decongestion of the eyes via its osmotic action. It is not used for open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: In iron deficiency anaemia, all of the following are increased except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transferrin saturation

Explanation:

  • Transferrin saturation is decreased in iron deficiency anaemia. This is because although TIBC is elevated, there is not enough iron to saturate the transferrin molecules, leading to low transferrin saturation.

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL)

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low

Serum transferrin saturation

(Option A)

Low

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) (Option C ruled out)

Increased: TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased

Ferritin soluble receptors (sTfR)(Option D ruled out)

Increased

RBC protoporphyrin (Option B ruled out)

Increased

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test for Iron deficiency anaemia.

questions.text: As a medical practitioner in India, how will you prescribe Alprazolam to a patient?

choices.text: 0.5 mg once daily before bedtime for 7 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 0.5 mg once daily before bedtime for 7 days

Explanation:

  • The correct method of prescribing alprazolam is 0.5 mg once daily before bedtime for 7 days.

The prescription should be legibly written, and the drug should be prescribed in generic names in capital letters, along with details of the patient.

  • Proper dosing and quantity.
  • Duration for which it should be taken.
  • Time when it should be taken.
  • Avoid the use of abbreviations - especially Latin.
  • Leading zero should always be mentioned (0.5 is correct, .5 is incorrect)

Parts of a prescription

  • Date
  • Name and address of the doctor
  • Information about the patient
  • Rx - Superscription
  • Name and dose of the drug - inscription
  • Dispensing direction to the pharmacist - subscription
  • Instruction to the patient
  • Signature and stamp of the doctor

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Giant papillary conjunctivitis

  • A history of prolonged soft contact lens use, along with symptoms like bilateral itching, redness, watery discharge, and the presence of large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, points towards a diagnosis of Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis.

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis:

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

 

Follicular Conjunctivitis (Option A): is the most common clinical form of Viral Conjunctivitis (Adenocirus, Molluscum contagiosum, Herpes simplex, COVID-19). Presents as a milder form of acute conjunctivitis (less symptoms). Follicular appearance of conjunctiva is seen on examination.

Spring Catarrh (Option B): Other name of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (type I & IV > type I hypersensitivity reaction), is characterized by seasonal symptoms, cobblestone-like papillae, limbal thickening with Horner-Trantas dots, and potential corneal involvement, unlike giant papillary conjunctivitis, which typically presents with large papillae associated with contact lens use.

Trachoma (Option D): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the occurrence when a therapist experiences a combination of conscious and unconscious emotions towards their patient during psychotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Countertransference

Explanation:

Countertransference occurs when a therapist unintentionally projects their personal feelings and experiences onto their patient during psychotherapy.

  • Countertransference is a process of the physician unconsciously displacing the patient's pattern of behaviour or emotional reactions like he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life.
  • Ideally, therapists are expected to remain calm and unbiased, avoiding interference from their emotions and history.
  • However, countertransference can lead to therapists having mixed conscious and unconscious feelings toward their patients.
  • Supervision and personal therapy can help the psychiatrist identify and deal with this issue.

Transference (Option B) refers to the patient's unconscious redirection of feelings and emotions from past relationships onto the therapist during therapy.

Dissociation (Option C) is a defence mechanism where a person detaches or disconnects from their thoughts, emotions, or experiences. It often occurs as a response to trauma or overwhelming situations.

Preoccupation (Option D) is an intense and persistent focus or preoccupation with a specific thought, feeling, or idea, often interfering with daily functioning and causing distress.

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on an antihypertensive presented with the following presentation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following antihypertensive medications was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lisinopril

Explanation:

  • Based on the history and clinical presentation, this patient is most likely suffering from angioedema, which is associated with Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor.
  • It presents with swelling of the face, lips, tongue, throat and extremities. Although rare, it is a serious allergic reaction that requires immediate medical attention.
  • It is treated with antihistamines and corticosteroids.
  • If laryngospasm has occurred, subcutaneous injection of epinephrine can be used.

Adverse effects of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

 

Nifedipine (Option B) is a calcium channel blocker that reduces calcium influx into the smooth muscle cell of arterial walls, causing vasodilation, which reduces blood pressure. It is associated with headache, flushing and dizziness.

Atenolol (Option C) is a beta-1-selective blocker that reduces the effects of catechol on the heart. It reduces heart rate, blood pressure and cardiac output. It is associated with bradycardia, cold extremities and fatigue.

Clonidine (Option D) is an alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist that acts centrally and results in inhibition of the release of norepinephrine in the terminal nerves and reduction in sympathetic outflow from the CNS. It is associated with bradycardia and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Systemic sclerosis

Explanation:

  • Numbness in fingertips and tightened face with ANA finding positive and nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence suggest systemic sclerosis.

Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening: Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally.
  • Skin Pigmentation Changes:
    • Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure.
    • Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages:
    • Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching.
    • Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy.
  • Fixed Contractures: Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis.
  • Neck Skin Ridges: Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension.
  • Facial Changes ("Mauskopf"):
    • Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility.
    • Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia.
    • Pinched, beak-like nose.

 

 

  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.
  • Skin Ulcerations:
    • Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected.
    • Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits."
  • Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia.
  • Calcinosis Cutis:
    • Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc.
    • Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression.

Immunofluorescence:

  • The nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence detecting Th/To autoantibodies.

Incorrect Options:
