Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B) is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting moisture-producing glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, gritty eye sensation, fatigue, joint pain, etc.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option C) is a multisystem autoimmune disease that can affect many organs. Common manifestations include a malar (butterfly) rash, joint pain, kidney problems, and blood abnormalities. While SLE may cause numbness or tingling due to nerve involvement, its ANA pattern is typically homogeneous or speckled, not nucleolar.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D) primarily affects the joints, causing inflammation, pain, and stiffness. It does not typically involve numbness of the fingertips or the tightening of the face seen in systemic sclerosis. Additionally, the nucleolar pattern on ANA immunofluorescence testing is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) β-2 microglobulin

Explanation:

  • In multiple myeloma, one of the most significant poor prognostic markers is β-2 microglobulin.
  • Elevated levels of β-2 microglobulin correlate with a higher tumour burden and more aggressive disease

Prognosis of Multiple Myeloma is determined by:

  • Durie-Salmon staging system (earlier)
  • International Staging System (ISS): Three-stage system to predict survival based on:
    • β2-microglobulin
    • Albumin levels

Calcium levels (Option B): Hypercalcemia is a common marker in multiple myeloma, but it is often a late-stage complication and does not directly indicate poor prognosis compared to β-2 microglobulin.

Serum creatinine (Option C), when elevated, indicates renal impairment, which is a common complication of multiple myeloma. While kidney function is important for prognosis, serum creatinine is not a prognosis indicator compared to β-2 microglobulin.

Protein levels (Option D) are commonly elevated and serve as disease markers, but they do not directly indicate a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with laboured breathing. ECG shows tall, tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 5 mEq/L

Explanation:

  • The low pH and HCO3 levels in the blood show metabolic acidosis.

Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

Incorrect Options:

pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L (Option B): Although the pH and pCO₂ suggest acidemia with respiratory compensation, the high HCO₃⁻ (34 mEq/L) is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis. A high bicarbonate would be seen in metabolic alkalosis, which does not fit this clinical picture.

pH-7.54, HCO3- 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 34 mmHg (Option C): This option shows a high pH (7.54), indicating alkalosis. The pCO₂ is slightly low, suggesting respiratory alkalosis, while the HCO₃⁻ is near normal. This acid-base picture does not match the metabolic acidosis expected in a dialysis patient with hyperkalemia.

pH-7.4, HCO3- 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mmHg (Option D): This combination of normal pH, normal pCO2, and normal HCO3- does not indicate any significant acid-base imbalance. Therefore, this option is less likely to be the correct acid-base imbalance in this case.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Delirium tremens
Explanation:

  • Based on the patient's history of alcohol use and current presentation, he is most likely suffering from delirium tremens, a life-threatening condition that occurs during alcohol withdrawal.
  • It usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink and can present as:
    • Confusion,
    • Intense physical reactions
    • Visual hallucinations
    • Motor agitation
    • Disorientation
    • Paranoid delusions
    • Altered sensorium

Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis) (Option D)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours


Wernicke's encephalopathy (Option B) is a neurological disorder that occurs due to thiamine deficiency, which can occur due to alcohol abuse, nutritional habits or malabsorption.

It involves acute symptoms like problems with eye movement (nystagmus), coordination (ataxia), and confusion.

Korsakoff psychosis (Option C) results from untreated Wernicke encephalopathy. It presents with the following symptoms.

  • Impaired mental syndrome - recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. The general examination showed pallor, and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed a Hb level of 3 g/dl, a TLC of 1500/microL, and a platelet count of 15,000/microL. A peripheral smear shows macrocytes, and the reticulocyte count is 0.5%. A bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes with no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of gum bleeding, fever, pallor, severe anaemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, along with the findings of peripheral smear and bone marrow biopsy, strongly point toward idiopathic acquired aplastic anaemia (AAA).
  • Aplastic Anemia is characterised by bone marrow failure, where the bone marrow does not produce enough blood cells, leading to Pancytopenia.
  • In severe cases, the bone marrow may become hypocellular, making it difficult to aspirate sufficient material, leading to a dry tap.

 

  • The absence of immature cells and the presence of fatty streaks in the bone marrow suggests bone marrow failure, typical of aplastic anemia, where normal hematopoiesis is replaced by fat.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B) is a rare disorder that causes red blood cells to prematurely break down by the complement system. It is characterised by hemolytic anemia and hemoglobinuria. The peripheral smear shows evidence of hemolysis, which is not the case here.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (Option C) is a group of disorders characterised by ineffective hematopoiesis and dysplastic cells in the bone marrow. While MDS can cause pancytopenia, it would typically show dysplastic features in the marrow, including abnormal shapes of cells, which is not the case here.

Tuberculosis (Option D) is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is not commonly associated with severe pancytopenia, fatty marrow, or absence of megakaryocytes. TB-related bone marrow suppression would usually have other findings like granulomas.

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

Explanation:

  • The child’s presentation of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis (joint pain), hematuria and proteinuria is most consistent with Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP).

 

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA vasculitis)

Definition

It is a systemic vasculitis characterised by inflammation of small blood vessels, primarily affecting children, but can also occur in adults.

Etiology

Often follows upper respiratory tract infections

Pathology

Immune complex deposition of IgA in small blood vessels leads to inflammation

Clinical features

  • Inflammation of small blood vessels primarily affects children but can also occur in adults.
  • Associated with elevated serum IgA levels
  • Skin: Palpable purpura, most prominently on the lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthralgia or arthritis, often transient and non-deforming.
  • Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes gastrointestinal bleeding, Intussusception is a severe but rare complication.
  • Renal: Hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts in urine.
  • It can progress to IgA nephropathy in severe cases.

Management

  • Supportive care: Hydration, rest, and pain management with NSAIDs for arthralgia.
  • Glucocorticoids: For severe abdominal pain, renal involvement, or systemic symptoms.
  • Intussusception: Surgical intervention if required.
  • Nephritis: Immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide) in severe cases.


Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A) is characterised by isolated thrombocytopenia without significant involvement of other systems. The purpura is typically non-blanching and is not associated with arthritis, abdominal pain, or renal symptoms.

Dengue (Option B) often presents with high fever, rash, severe headache, and retro-orbital pain. While petechiae can occur, Dengue is not commonly associated with purpura or renal involvement.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option C) is also called Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis and is a vasculitis that is associated with asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous inflammation. It is part of the group of ANCA-associated vasculitis. It normally does not present with palpable purpura or renal involvement, as seen in HSP.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrates the proper handwashing technique to her students, who then practice it both at school and at home. What type of learning does this scenario represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psychomotor

Explanation: The steps of handwashing demonstrated by the teacher and performed by the students are an example of Psychomotor learning.

Domains of learning

Psychomotor
  • Psychomotor learning involves acquiring physical skills and coordination through observation, practice and repetition, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain.
  • It is measured based on speed, precision, distance and procedure in execution
  • It includes imitation, manipulation, precision, articulation and naturalisation
  • E.g., An intern learning how to insert an IV cannula by observing the staff nurse

Affective learning

(Option C)
  • Includes domain of attitude and values
  • It includes emotions, feelings, attitudes, and values
  • It encompasses the subjective experiences and expressions of emotions.
  • E.g., communicating with patients with empathy

Cognitive learning

(Option A)
  • It refers to mental processes related to knowledge acquisition, understanding, thinking, and problem-solving.
  • It involves perception, memory, attention, language, and reasoning processes.
  • E.g., Solving NEET PG entrance exam MCQs

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal, with no immature cells. A lymph node biopsy showed diffuse effacement of the lymph node architecture and cells with an indented nucleus and prominent nucleolus that are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Follicular lymphoma

Explanation:

  • Given the lymphadenopathy, the findings on lymph node biopsy (indented nuclei, BCL2 positivity), and the normal blood counts (no immature cells), Follicular lymphoma is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Follicular lymphoma (FL) is a malignant neoplasm originating from germinal centre B-cells, characterised by the t(14;18) translocation leading to overexpression of BCL2.
  • Clinically, it presents with painless lymphadenopathy and may include systemic symptoms.
  • Histopathologically, FL exhibits a nodular growth pattern with centrocytes(Small cells with cleaved nuclei and scanty cytosol) and centroblasts(Larger cells with open nuclear chromatin and several nucleoli)
  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD10/19/20, BCL2, and BCL6, and negativity for CD5.
  • Management focuses on palliative approaches due to their indolent but incurable nature.

 

 

Burkitt lymphoma (Option B) is a type of B-cell lymphoma characterised by rapidly growing tumours, typically extranodal, most commonly in the abdomen or jaw. It often presents as large masses rather than just cervical lymphadenopathy. It has a "starry sky" pattern on histology due to macrophages phagocytosing apoptotic tumour cells, which was not noted in the biopsy here.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C) is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that primarily affects the skin and presents as patches, plaques, or tumours. It does not typically present with lymphadenopathy as a primary feature; its main involvement is in the skin rather than the lymph nodes.

Chronic myeloid leukemia (Option D) is a myeloproliferative disorder that is marked by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), which leads to the production of the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Derailment

Explanation:

  • Derailment, also known as loosening of associations, is a formal thought disorder characterized by a disruption in the normal flow of thoughts, leading to tangential or incoherent speech.
  • It is a symptom commonly associated with certain psychiatric conditions, such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.

Abnormal thought process

Derailment
  • Sudden or gradual deviation in thought (without blocking) is often used synonymously with loosening associations.

Talking Past the Point (Vorbeireden)
  • The patient responds with incorrect answers related to the topic despite understanding the question.
  • Example: Saying "white" for grass colour and "green" for snow colour.
  • Seen in hysterical pseudodementia (dissociative disorder) and Ganser’s syndrome (approximate answers).
  • It also occurs in acute schizophrenia, especially in adolescents (hebephrenia).

Loosening of Associations
  • Disorganised thought progression, shifting between unrelated topics, leading to incoherent communication.

Incoherence
  • Disconnected, disorganised, or incomprehensible speech.
  • Word Salad: Incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.

Word Approximation


 
  • Using conventional words in an unconventional way (e.g., "hand shoes" for gloves)
  • It is distinguished from a neologism, a newly created word with an unclear or unknown origin.


Obsessions (Option A) are intrusive, persistent, unwanted thoughts, images, or urges that cause distress and anxiety.

Delusions (Option C) are false beliefs that are firmly held despite clear evidence. It is a disorder of contentment of thought.

Thought insertion (Option D) is the belief that one's thoughts are being controlled or inserted into one's mind by an external force or entity. It is a disorder of the possession of thoughts.

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatiguability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12-14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very few fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9 g/dl, and MCV is 80 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Iron deficiency

Explanation:

  • This patient’s symptoms with a history of poor dietary habits and laboratory findings of Hb 9 g/dL with an MCV of 80 fl (microcytic anaemia) strongly suggest iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia can result from dietary lack, impaired absorption, increased iron requirement (e.g., during pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding).
  • Clinical features include Koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, esophageal webs, pica and intestinal malabsorption, affecting overall nutritional status.

 

Cyanocobalamin deficiency (Option A) causes megaloblastic anemia, which typically presents with macrocytic anemia (elevated MCV), not the microcytic anemia seen in this patient.

Folic acid deficiency (Option B) also causes megaloblastic anemia, which presents with macrocytic anemia (high MCV), not microcytic anemia.

Hereditary spherocytosis (Option D) is a condition where red blood cells are abnormally shaped (spherocytes), leading to hemolysis and normocytic anemia (normal MCV).

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced by stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Medication overuse headache

Explanation:

The scenario here suggests overuse of analgesics and hence the diagnosis of medication overuse headache.

  • Medication overuse headache (MOH) is a secondary headache because it results from the frequent use of headache medication, unlike tension-type headaches, migraines, and primary stabbing headaches, which are all primary headaches.
  • This develops due to the overuse of analgesics for already-existing headaches.
  • This overuse induces MOH, which leads the patient to take more analgesics, thereby increasing the frequency of headaches, thus forming a vicious cycle.

Main Risk Factors for MOH:

  • Demographic
    • Age (less than 50 years)
    • Female
    • Low educational level
  • Self-reported complaints
    • Chronic musculoskeletal complaints
    • Gastrointestinal complaints
    • Anxiety or depression
  • Lifestyle
    • Smoking
    • Physical inactivity
    • Metabolic syndrome
    • High daily caffeine intake (greater than 540mg versus less than 240mg)
  • Medication
    • Tranquillizers
    • Aspirin
    • Ibuprofen
    • Opioids

Treatment of Medication Overuse Headache (MOH)

  • Patient Education and Prevention
    • Educate on appropriate medication use and risks of MOH.
    • Emphasize the importance of limiting acute headache medications to ≤2 days per week.
  • Medication Discontinuation Strategies
    • Stop overused medication abruptly (preferred for most patients) and start/optimize preventive therapy, titrated based on individual factors.
    • Gradual tapering: Useful for Opioids, Barbiturates, or Benzodiazepines (2-4 weeks for high doses; transdermal clonidine or phenobarbital may help with withdrawal).
  • Preventive Medications
    • Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, TCAs, and anticonvulsants.
    • Topiramate and OnabotulinumtoxinA (useful, especially in chronic migraine with MOH).
  • Bridge Therapy
    • NSAIDs: Naproxen, Indomethacin, Ketorolac
    • Adjuncts: Tizanidine with NSAIDs, antiemetics (Prochlorperazine, Metoclopramide), and dihydroergotamine (DHE) for severe cases.
    • Raskin protocol: IV DHE + Metoclopramide every 8 hours.
  • Alternative Approaches
    • Withdrawal symptoms management: NSAIDs, hydration, antiemetics, magnesium, and lidocaine infusions.
    • Discontinuation first approach: Avoid starting preventive therapy for 2 months post-medication discontinuation (less tolerated).

Incorrect Options:

In tension headaches (Option B), the pain is described as a dull, bilateral ache, often associated with neck tension, stress, and fatigue.

Migraine (Option C) sufferers describe a prodrome of fatigue, neck discomfort, mood changes, increased urination and thirst, and cognitive impairment. Typical migraine symptoms include a strong, throbbing headache, photophobia, phonophobia, osmophobia, allodynia and vomiting.

Cluster headaches (Option D) are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain. They are more common in males and can be associated with other symptoms such as nasal congestion and watering of the eyes.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who exhibits symptoms such as excessive familiarity, rapid flow of thoughts, heightened mood, heightened sexual desire, and experiencing pseudohallucinations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mania​​​​​​​
Explanation:

  • The described symptoms — excessive familiarity, rapid flow of thoughts, heightened mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudohallucinations — are characteristic of mania, a condition often seen in bipolar disorder.
  • Mania involves elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, impulsivity, and psychotic features such as pseudohallucinations in severe cases.

Mania
  • Mania is a mood disorder characterised by a distinct period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and increased energy or activity levels.
  • Mania is a period of at least 1 week where a person's behaviour drastically changes and affects their functioning.
  • Individuals experiencing mania engage in heightened goal-directed activity and may show psychomotor agitation.
  • Mania is a characteristic of Bipolar I disorder.
  • Symptoms (My Asia FAST GDP)
  • M - Mood elevation
  • A - Activity levels Increased
  • F - Flight of ideas
  • A - Abnormally increased levels of activity/energy
  • S - Sleep decreased (Need for sleep is also reduced)
  • T - Talkativeness (Overtalkativeness)
  • G - Grandiose ideas and increased self-esteem
  • D - Distractibility
  • P - Painful consequences (Involvement in such activities

Diagnostic criteria

  • Mood Changes: Elation/ irritability
  • Persistently increased Energy

+ ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if irritable mood) for at least 1 week:

 
  • Distractibility.
  • Impulsivity/ high-risk activities
  • Grandiosity/ Inflated Self-Esteem
  • Flight of Ideas (Racing and expansive thoughts)
  • Activity increased (Hyperactivity)
  • Sleep deficit (decreased need for sleep)
  • Talkativeness/ Pressured speech

Management




 

First line

Monotherapy: Lithium, divalproex, and atypical antipsychotics such as olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, aripiprazole, cariprazine, asenapine, paliperidone, iloperidone, ziprasidone.

Adjunctive therapy with lithium or divalproex:

Risperidone, quetiapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, asenapine
 

Second line

Monotherapy: Carbamazepine, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), haloperidol.

Combination therapy: Lithium + Divalproex
 

Third line

Monotherapy: Chlorpromazine, Clozapine, Tamoxifen

Combination therapy: lithium or divalproex + haloperidol, lithium + carbamazepine, adjunctive tamoxifen

Hypomania (Option B) has symptoms similar to mania but less severe.

  • No Marked impairment in functioning and No hospitalisation necessitated
  • No psychotic symptoms
  • Flight of ideas usually not seen
  • The duration of hypomania is ≥4 days.

Cyclothymia (Option C) is characterised by chronic mood fluctuations

  • Over at least 2 years, including periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms.
  • The patient’s symptoms have lasted only 5 days
  • Do not include depressive episodes.

Schizomania (Option D) is a mood disorder with manic and mixed episodes in the bipolar type of schizoaffective disorder.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. Whereas laboratory tests revealed normal platelet counts. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Henoch-Schonlein purpura

  • The clinical scenario of palpable blanching purpura, arthritic pain, abdominal pain with normal platelet count is characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects small blood vessels, commonly seen in children. The characteristic clinical features include palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement. Hematuria and proteinuria are common findings in urine examination due to kidney involvement. The symptoms may be preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection

Etiology
  • Most common in males.
  • Exact cause unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1 observed in some cases.

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on legs and buttocks
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often include vomiting, diarrhea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception.
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

Palpable purpura plus at least one of the following:

  • Diffuse abdominal pain
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
  • Renal involvement

Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicating inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic renal failure due to long term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

While Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A) can present with purpura and thrombocytopenia, it does not typically involve joint pain, abdominal pain or renal manifestations such as hematuria and proteinuria.

Dengue (Option B) is a viral infection that can cause fever, rash, joint pain and thrombocytopenia .

Churg Strauss syndrome (Option C) also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is a rare systemic vasculitis that primarily affects medium and small blood vessels. It is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present, and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intermediate filaments

Explanation:

  • The presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes is a key finding in alcoholic liver disease.
  • Mallory-Denk bodies or Mallory hyaline bodies are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of intermediate filaments, particularly cytokeratin 8 and 18, commonly seen in hepatocytes in conditions such as alcoholic liver disease.
  • Conditions where Mallory Hyaline bodies are seen are (Mnemonic: New Indian WATCH)
    • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
    • Indian childhood cirrhosis
    • Wilson’s disease
    • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency; Alcoholic Liver Disease
    • Tumor of the liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma)
    • Chronic Cholestatic conditions
    • Hepatic or Primary Biliary cirrhosis (not seen in Secondary biliary cirrhosis)

 

 

Actin (Option B) is a structural protein found in microfilaments but does not typically form eosinophilic inclusions in alcoholic liver disease.

Microtubules (Option C) are involved in intracellular transport and cell division but do not form eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes.

Fibronectin (Option D) is an extracellular matrix protein, and although it plays a role in tissue repair and scarring, it is not associated with the formation of intracytoplasmic inclusions in liver cells, especially in alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thymoma

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) in this patient, coupled with a mediastinal mass, strongly suggests a thymoma, a tumor of the thymus gland, which is located in the anterior mediastinum.
  • It is often asymptomatic initially but can cause a range of paraneoplastic syndromes and is also associated with autoimmune diseases like myasthenia gravis.
  • One of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with thymoma is PRCA.
  • In PRCA, red blood cell production in the bone marrow is selectively failed, while white blood cells and platelets are usually unaffected. This leads to severe anemia in the absence of any abnormalities in other cell lines.

Thymoma

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic (small tumor), incidentally detected.
  • It may compress the trachea (dyspnea), esophagus (dysphagia), recurrent laryngeal nerve (dysphonia or hoarseness of voice), and superior vena cava (superior vena cava syndrome).

Investigations

CT scan
  • Investigation of choice
  • It is used to determine the extent of the disease.

 

Histology (definitive diagnosis)
  • Noninvasive thymomas: Medullary-type epithelial cells (elongated or spindle-shaped) or a mixture of medullary- and cortical-type epithelial cells (admixture of polygonal cortical-type epithelial cells and a denser infiltrate of thymocytes).

 

  • Invasive thymoma: Cytologically benign but locally invasive. The epithelial cells have abundant cytoplasm and rounded vesicular nuclei mixed with numerous thymocytes.
  • Cytokeratin (marker to distinguish thymoma from lymphoma; thymomas are positive for cytokeratin)

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B) can cause lymphadenopathy and mediastinal masses, but it is not associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C) may cause mediastinal masses due to lymph node involvement or direct tumour extension, but it is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Germ cell tumours (Option D) in the mediastinum can cause a mediastinal mass and are not typically linked with pure red cell aplasia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient with a history of spinal tuberculosis was brought to the hospital with low-grade fever, dull backache, and persistent flexion of the hip joint. Hip joint motion was limited and painful. Identify the muscle affected in the CT image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:

  • The arrow marking as 2 is psoas muscles and in the context of a 15-year-old patient with a history of spinal tuberculosis and presenting with low-grade fever, dull backache, and persistent flexion of the hip joint, the involvement of the psoas muscle is highly suggestive of a psoas abscess.
    • Muscle from anterior aspect crossing hip joint anteriorly - Iliopsoas muscle.
    • Pulling the femur anteriorly causing the hip flexion- Iliopsoas muscle (Proximal muscle) - Chief muscle for hip flexion.
  • The psoas muscle is a large muscle located in the lower back that plays a key role in hip flexion and stabilization of the spine.
  • Psoas abscesses can occur as a complication of spinal tuberculosis, with the infection spreading from the vertebral column to the adjacent psoas muscle.

 

 

Spinal TB (Pott’s Disease)

Involves lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae in adults; and upper thoracic spine in children.

Lesions spread to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral disks.

Advanced Disease
  • Collapse of vertebrae leads to kyphosis (gibbus deformity).
  • Paravertebral cold abscesses:
    • Upper spine: Abscess may penetrate the chest wall as a soft tissue mass.
    • Lower spine: May track to the inguinal region or form a psoas abscess.

Diagnosis of Spinal TB
  • Imaging (CT/MRI): Shows characteristic lesions, suggesting TB aetiology.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Includes tumours and infections like pyogenic bacterial osteomyelitis.
  • Confirmation: Aspiration or biopsy confirms TB via positive cultures and typical histology.

Complications
  • Paraplegia: Due to abscess or spinal cord compression; requires emergency drainage if caused by a large abscess.

1 (Option A): Abdominal wall muscles, including the rectus abdominis, external oblique, internal oblique, and transversus abdominis, are responsible for core stability and movement of the trunk. In the given scenario, the symptoms and CT image findings are not indicative of abdominal wall muscle involvement.

3 (Option C): The adductor muscles, including the adductor longus, adductor brevis, and adductor magnus, are located in the inner thigh and are responsible for hip adduction. They are not directly related to the symptoms and CT findings described in the scenario.

4 (Option D): The gluteal muscles, including the gluteus maximus, gluteus medius, and gluteus minimus, are located in the buttocks and are responsible for hip extension, abduction, and rotation. Their involvement is not typically associated with the symptoms and CT image findings described in the given scenario.

questions.text: In a child presenting with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, what metabolic abnormality is commonly observed, given the presence of recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis:

In infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), there is a thickening of the pyloric muscle, leading to the obstruction of the passage between the stomach and the small intestine. This obstruction results in persistent non-bilious vomiting.

The vomiting in IHPS leads to the loss of gastric acid (HCl), causing a decrease in both chloride and hydrogen ions. This leads to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Additionally, the loss of gastric fluid also leads to the loss of potassium (K+), resulting in hypokalemia.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS):

  • This involves hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction, mostly in first-born male infants, typically between 3 to 6 weeks of age.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds
    • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.
    • Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria

  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound (USG) is the investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
      • Pyloric muscle thickness of ≥4mm
      • Pyloric length ≥ 16 mm
      • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)
    • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis, and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed, which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained, and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aschoff’s bodies

Explanation:

  • Aschoff's bodies are the hallmark histopathological findings in rheumatic fever.
  • This patient’s symptoms of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation, along with the characteristic granulomatous lesions, point to rheumatic heart disease caused by rheumatic fever.

Histopathological features of RHD

Aschoff bodies
  • They are focal areas of inflammation with infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells and activated macrophages or histiocytes.
  • An endomyocardial biopsy showing Aschoff's bodies helps in confirming the diagnosis of RHD.

Anitschkow cells
  • They are activated macrophages with elongated and wavy nuclei commonly found within Aschoff bodies.
  • They appear as caterpillars in longitudinal sections (hence also called Caterpillar cells) and owls in cross sections.

Fibrinoid necrosis

This is seen in areas of the valves affected by inflammation.

Granulation tissue is seen in cases of repair. It comprises proliferating blood vessels, inflammatory cells and fibroblasts.

 

Epithelioid granuloma (Option B) is a characteristic feature of tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases (like sarcoidosis). These granulomas are not typically seen in rheumatic fever.

Granulomatous vasculitis (Option C) refers to a condition where there is inflammation of the blood vessels, and granulomas form in the vessel walls. This is typically seen in diseases like Wegener's granulomatosis or Takayasu arteritis, not rheumatic fever.

Granuloma inguinale (Option D) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It causes ulcerative lesions in the genital area and does not lead to heart murmurs, mitral regurgitation, or migratory arthritis.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman is admitted due to persistent vomiting. She gives a history of consuming food from outside. On evaluation, her blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings. What is the cause of her ABG findings?

pH - 7.52

HCO3- 30 meq/L

PaCO2 - 20 mmHg

Na- 123 mEq/L

K- 3.2 mEq/L

CI- 67 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Persistent vomiting

Explanation:

  • The arterial blood gas shows an elevated pH (7.52) and increased bicarbonate (30 meq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia further support this diagnosis. The cause of this in the given scenario is persistent vomiting (hypochloremia).

Metabolic Alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.
  • Causes
    • Exogenous Bicarbonate Loads
      • Acute alkali administration
      • Milk-alkali syndrome
    • Effective ECFV Contraction (Normotension, K+ Deficiency, Secondary Hyperreninemic Hyperaldosteronism)
      • Gastrointestinal Origin: Vomiting, gastric aspiration, congenital chloridorrhea, gastro cystoplasty, villous adenoma
      • Renal Origin: Diuretic use (thiazides, loop diuretics), post hypercapnic state, hypercalcemia/hypoparathyroidism, recovery from acidosis, non-resorbable anions (e.g., penicillin), Mg²⁺ deficiency, K⁺ depletion, Bartter's syndrome, Gitelman's syndrome
    • ECFV Expansion, Hypertension, K+ Deficiency, and Mineralocorticoid Excess
      • High Renin: Renal artery stenosis, accelerated hypertension, renin-secreting tumour, estrogen therapy
      • Low Renin: Primary aldosteronism (adenoma, hyperplasia, carcinoma), adrenal enzyme defects (11β-hydroxylase, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency), Cushing’s syndrome, substances like liquorice, carbenoxolone
    • Genetic Sodium Channel Mutation (Liddle's Syndrome)
    • A gain-of-function mutation in the distal convoluted tubule, causing ECFV expansion, hypertension, K⁺ deficiency, and hypo-reninemic-hypoaldosteronism
  • Clinical Features
    • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
    • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
    • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
    • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
    • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
    • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.

Incorrect Options:

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) (Option A) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar levels, increased body ketone concentration, and metabolic acidosis.

Septic shock (Option C) can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and a state of metabolic acidosis. The pH of 7.52 in the ABG report suggests alkalosis rather than acidosis, so septic shock is unlikely to be the cause.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) (Option D) is a condition characterized by a defect in the kidneys’ ability to excrete acid, leading to a buildup of acid in the body. Since the ABG report shows alkalosis with a pH of 7.52, RTA is not the likely cause.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and a low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dysplasia

Explanation:

  • The findings described in the pap smear hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index are characteristic of dysplasia, a pre-cancerous condition.
  • Dysplasia is abnormal cell growth and differentiation, often seen in the epithelial layer, without penetration through the basement membrane.
  • This is reversible in the early stages (may become irreversible if the entire epithelium is involved).

 

Carcinoma (Option B) refers to invasive cancer where the abnormal cells have breached the basement membrane and spread beyond the epithelial layer. The description clearly states that the basement membrane is intact, ruling out carcinoma.

Metaplasia (Option C) is the replacement of one type of cell with another, often occurring in response to tissue damage, repair, chronic irritation, or regeneration. It does not explain the nuclear changes (hyperchromasia and irregularity) seen in the pap smear.

Hyperplasia (Option D) is an increase in the number of cells in a tissue, typically in response to a stimulus. It does not usually involve abnormal nuclear features like hyperchromasia and irregular borders, which are more indicative of dysplasia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Takayasu arteritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of forearm claudication, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain with weak femoral pulses point to the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis.

Takayasu Arteritis ("Pulseless disease"):

General features:

  • Predominantly affects young females (<20 years)
  • Vascular Involvement:
    • A leading cause of renal artery stenosis in India
    • Most commonly affects the left subclavian artery
    • Characteristic ostial narrowing vs. diffuse involvement in atherosclerosis

Clinical Features:

a) Early Phase (Pre-pulseless):

  • Systemic symptoms: fever, malaise, night sweats
  • Arthralgias, anorexia, weight loss

b) Vascular Phase:

  • Arm claudication
  • Unequal blood pressure between arms
  • Pulseless disease (difficult to appreciate radial artery)
  • Hypertension (32-93%)

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Young female with renal artery stenosis:
    • India: Think Takayasu arteritis
    • USA: Think fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD)
  • Arm claudication:
    • Rule out neurogenic claudication (cervical disc disease)

Investigations:

  • ESR/CRP elevation
  • Mild anaemia
  • Elevated immunoglobulins
  • Investigation of choice: MR angiography (MRA)
  • Complete imaging of the aorta and major branches is needed

Management:

  • First Line: Steroids (40-60mg prednisone/day)
  • Second Line: Methotrexate (up to 25mg/week) for steroid-refractory cases

Important Points for Differential Blood Pressure:

  • Normal difference between arm-leg BP: <20 mmHg
  • Conditions with unequal arm BPs:
    • Takayasu arteritis
    • Supravalvular aortic stenosis with Coanda effect
    • Preductal coarctation of aorta

Major complications: Heart failure, stroke, MI, aneurysm rupture, renal failure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option A) presents non-specific symptoms like weakness, malaise, headache, abdominal pain, and myalgia. These symptoms do not align with the given scenario.

Thromboangitis obliterans (Option B) or Buerger disease affects the small to medium arteries and veins and presents with ischemic signs and symptoms in the regions of the distal arteries of the upper and lower limbs. In this condition, claudication is seen in the arch of the foot and calf and is also called the Raynauds phenomenon.

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D) is a rare autoimmune disease where there is small vessel necrotizing vasculitis that manifests as systemic symptoms involving the kidneys (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), lungs (diffuse alveolar haemorrhage, chronic interstitial fibrosis), skin (palpable purpura, urticaria, nodules, etc), GIT (bleeding), and CNS (peripheral neuropathy).

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl, born out of a non-consanguineous marriage, presented with rachitic changes in her limbs since the age of 2 despite receiving several rounds of vitamin D treatment. Investigations are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?


	
		
			
			Parameter
			
			
			Lab determined value
			
		
		
			
			Serum Calcium
			
			
			9.5 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Serum Phosphate
			
			
			1.6 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			ALP
			
			
			814 IU
			
		
		
			
			PTH
			
			
			Within normal limits
			
		
		
			
			Serum electrolytes
			
			
			Within normal limits
			
		
		
			
			Serum creatinine
			
			
			Within normal limits
			
		
		
			
			ABG
			
			
			Within normal limits
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hypophosphatemic rickets

  • The patient’s presentation with rachitic changes in limbs since the age of 2 and receiving multiple courses of vitamin D with a normal calcium level and a low phosphate level is suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets. Hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate, resulting in low levels of serum phosphate (hypophosphatemia). This leads to defective bone mineralization, resulting in rachitic changes in the bones.

Vitamin D dependent rickets (Option A) can occur due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or receptor defects. However, in this case, the PTH is normal, which is not consistent with vitamin D-dependent rickets, where PTH levels are typically high.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option B) is characterized by low levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) leading to low calcium levels and high phosphate levels. However, in the given scenario, the PTH level is within normal limits, ruling out hypoparathyroidism.

Chronic renal failure (Option C) can cause renal tubular dysfunction, leading to electrolyte imbalances and bone abnormalities. However, in the given scenario, the serum electrolytes and creatinine levels are within normal limits, indicating normal renal function.

questions.text: A woman with hysteria who was hyperventilating developed carpo-pedal spasms. What could be the likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

The clinical features of hyperventilation leading to carpal spasm are caused due to respiratory alkalosis.

  • Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the blood, leading to an increase in alkalinity.
  • Hyperventilation causes excessive elimination of carbon dioxide, leading to decreased blood CO2 levels. This results in respiratory alkalosis

Clinical features of respiratory alkalosis will include:

  • Tachypnea
  • Symptoms of hypocapnia
  • Paresthesias from decreased ionized calcium due to alkalemia
  • Reduced cerebral blood flow from hypocapnia
  • Decreased ionized calcium causing tetany/carpopedal spasms

Respiratory alkalosis- Clinical Features & Management

Category

Features

Cause

Neurological
  • Dizziness
  • Mental confusion
  • Paresthesias
  • Circumoral numbness
  • Seizures (severe cases)
  • Due to reduced cerebral blood flow
  • From rapid ↓ PaCO2
  • May occur without hypoxemia

Cardiovascular
  • Chest tightness/pain
  • Palpitations
  • Arrhythmias
  • Possible ECG changes
  • Due to coronary vasoconstriction
  • ↓ ionized calcium effects
  • Bohr effect on O2 delivery

Neuromuscular
  • Carpopedal spasms
  • Tetany
  • Muscle twitching
  • Weakness
  • From ↓ ionized calcium
  • Enhanced nerve excitability
  • Similar to hypocalcemia

Laboratory
  • ↑ pH
  • ↓ PaCO2
  • ↓ Ionized calcium
  • ↓ K+, ↓ PO4
  • Acute: ↓ HCO3- by 2 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Chronic: ↓ HCO3- by 4-5 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Electrolyte shifts into cells

Management

Underlying Disease:

  • Treat primary condition
  • Address anxiety if present
  • Manage sepsis if present
 

Hyperventilation Syndrome:

  • Reassurance
  • Rebreathing techniques
  • Paper bag breathing if needed
  • β-blockers if needed
  • Primary focus on the underlying cause
  • Avoid sedatives for anxiety
  • Monitor during mechanical ventilation
  • Adjust ventilator settings if needed
  • Regular monitoring of blood gases
  • Address psychological factors

Incorrect Options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A) results from impaired ventilation due to pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle fatigue, or abnormalities in ventilatory control. Some examples of these are drugs, alcohol, motor neuron diseases, skeletal muscle disease, etc.

Metabolic acidosis (Option B) is caused by methanol, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, iron tablets, isoniazid, etc and not by hyperventilation.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is caused by exogenous bicarbonate loads, hypertension, K+ deficiency, mineralocorticoid excess, etc.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation of the child, the height for the age is < -2 SD according to WHO growth charts. This is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Chronic malnutrition:

  • The child's height for age being below -2SD suggests chronic malnutrition. The best indicator of chronic malnutrition is a decrease in height for age, i.e., stunting. It can be caused by factors such as insufficient food availability, poor dietary diversity, inadequate breastfeeding, or repeated infections that affect nutrient absorption.

WHO Classification of Malnutrition

Moderately underweight

Weight for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely underweight

Weight for age is < -3 SD.

Moderately wasted

Weight for length/height is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely wasted

Weight for length/height is < -3 SD.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI for age is between -2 and -3 SD.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) :

 
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDS.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is < -3 SD.

Acute malnutrition (Option B) refers to a severe and sudden lack of adequate nutrition, often resulting from a recent significant decrease in food intake or a severe illness. The best indicator of acute malnutrition is a decrease in weight for height, i.e., wasting.

While recent infection (Option C) can temporarily affect a child's growth and nutritional status, a recent infection alone is less likely to cause a significant and sustained decrease in height for age.

questions.text: A 12-week-old child presented with fever, cyanosis, and fatigue. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

Explanation:

The X-ray reveals a "figure-of-eight" or "snowman" appearance, which is characteristic of supracardiac TAPVC.

 

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathology
  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection
  • Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion

Sites of venous connection
  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava (Most common)
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation
  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure
  • With ASD- wide and split S2

Chest X-ray
  • Snowman or figure-8 configuration in supracardiac TAPVC

Treatment
  • Surgery
  • No indication for prostaglandins (Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion)

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Associated with "boot-shaped heart" on X-ray.

 

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option C): Associated with "egg on a string" appearance on X-ray.

 

Pericardial Effusion (Option D): Would present with an enlarged, globular heart ("water bottle" appearance) on X-ray.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child who exhibits generalized swelling and is diagnosed with high cholesterol levels, as well as protein 3+ and fat bodies observed in urine analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • The patient’s presentation with generalized swelling and high cholesterol levels, protein 3+ and fat bodies observed in urine analysis (lipiduria) is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, lipiduria and hyperlipidemia.

 

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome (Option B)

Clinical Presentation

Edema, heavy proteinuria

Hematuria, oliguria, edema, hypertension

Proteinuria

Heavy (3+ to 4+) on dipstick

(>3.5gm/24 hour)

(1+ to 2+) levels of proteinuria (<1gm/ 24-hour)

Hematuria

Rare, microscopic hematuria may occur

Common, with cola-colored urine due to gross hematuria

Urinary Casts

Hyaline and granular casts

Red blood cell casts (indicating glomerular inflammation)

Serum Albumin

Low (<1 g/dL)

Usually normal unless severe renal impairment

Blood Urea and Creatinine

Normal unless hypovolemia or acute kidney injury

Elevated due to impaired renal function

Serum Complement C3

Normal

Low in 90% of cases, returns to normal in 8-12 weeks

Cholesterol

Hypercholesterolemia (may cause milky plasma)

No significant hypercholesterolemia

ASO/Anti-DNase B Titers

Not elevated

Elevated ASO titers (pharyngitis) or anti-DNase B (skin infection)

Goodpasture's disease (Option C) is a rare autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the kidneys and lungs. It is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane (Anti GBM) antibodies, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

IgA nephropathy (Option D) also known as Berger's disease, is a common form of glomerulonephritis characterized by the deposition of IgA in the glomeruli of the kidneys. It often presents with recurrent episodes of hematuria, particularly following respiratory or gastrointestinal infections.

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) V

Explanation:

  • The Leiden mutation is a genetic alteration in Factor V, a protein essential for blood clotting.
  • It has the autosomal dominant type of inheritance.
  • The mutation makes factor V resistant to inactivation by protein C, disrupting an antithrombotic pathway and increasing the risk of thrombosis.

Factor VIII (Option B) plays a key role in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, where it activates Factor X to Xa, which then helps in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, leading to the formation of a blood clot. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Factor I (Option C), also known as fibrinogen, is the precursor to fibrin, which forms the structural framework of a blood clot. When bleeding occurs, fibrinogen is converted to fibrin by the enzyme thrombin during the final steps of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Factor X (Option D), also known as the Stuart-Prower factor, is a key enzyme in the blood clotting process. It is activated to Factor Xa and plays a crucial role in converting prothrombin to thrombin, ultimately leading to the formation of a blood clot. It is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

questions.text:
A patient following a skid resulting in a motor traffic accident was brought to the emergency room 2 hours later. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechiae were seen. Severe tenderness was elicited in the left hypochondriac region and BP-90/50 mm of Hg. What is the best investigation used in the ER?

GCS: Glasgow coma scale

FAST: Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FAST

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario, the best investigation to be used in the emergency room is FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).
  • FAST is a rapid bedside ultrasound examination that is commonly used in the emergency setting to evaluate patients with suspected abdominal or thoracic trauma.
  • It is a non-invasive and relatively quick procedure that can provide valuable information about potential injuries and guide further management.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST):

  • Purpose: Assess for free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavities, and pericardium.
  • Nature of Injury: Not used to determine the specific nature or extent of injury.
  • Advantages:
    • Rapid, reproducible, portable, and non-invasive bedside test.
    • Can be performed simultaneously with resuscitation.
    • Accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood.
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent and may be unreliable in obese patients or when the bowel is full of gas.
    • Low sensitivity (29–35%) for detecting hollow viscus or solid organ injuries without haemoperitoneum.
    • Unreliable for excluding injuries in penetrating trauma.
    • Requires repeat or supplementary investigations if needed.
    • Unreliable for assessing retroperitoneum.

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage (DPL): (Option C)

  • Purpose: Assess for the presence of blood or contaminants in the abdomen, valuable in resource-limited settings.
  • Procedure:
    • Nasogastric tube and urinary catheter placement.
    • Cannula insertion below the umbilicus for aspiration and fluid infusion.
    • The positive result is if
      • Frank blood or contaminants are present, or
      • If laboratory results show >100,000 red cells/µL or >500 white cells/µL or
      • Amylase levels in the fluid of more than 175 IU/dl.
    • Drainage of lavage fluid via a chest drain indicates diaphragm penetration.
  • Limitations: Largely replaced by eFAST but remains the standard in some settings where eFAST is unavailable or unreliable.
  • Contraindications:
    • When laparotomy is indicated
    • Previous laparotomy
    • Pregnancy
    • Obesity

X-ray (Option B): are less sensitive in detecting injuries to internal organs. Therefore, it may not be the best initial investigation for this patient.

CT scan (Option B): Gold standard for detailed assessment but requires a stable patient. This patient is hypotensive, making CT less ideal initially.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to verify the placement of the endotracheal tube in a 30-year-old male patient who has been intubated for surgery by a final-year resident?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) End-tidal CO₂ concentration

Explanation:

  • End-tidal CO₂ concentration (capnography): This is the most reliable and effective method to confirm endotracheal tube placement.
  • A sustained detection of CO₂ in exhaled air indicates proper placement in the trachea and confirms ventilation. It provides immediate, continuous, and quantitative confirmation.
  • Capnography is the gold standard for confirming endotracheal tube placement during intubation due to its accuracy and real-time feedback.

Incorrect Options:

X-ray chest (Option A): Useful for confirming tube depth or ruling out complications like pneumothorax, but it is not practical for immediate verification of tube placement.

Auscultation (Option B): Helps assess ventilation by listening for bilateral breath sounds, but it is less reliable as it can miss esophageal intubation or identify asymmetrical placement.

Chest rise (Option D): A visible chest rise may indicate ventilation but does not confirm tracheal placement, as it can occur with esophageal intubation or bag-mask ventilation.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An X-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jejunum

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the X-ray findings of dilated bowel loops with visible valvulae conniventes suggest small bowel obstruction involving the jejunum.
  • Valvulae conniventes (or plicae circulares):
    • These are mucosal folds that run transversely across the lumen of the jejunum and proximal ileum.
    • They are most prominent in the jejunum and appear as complete lines spanning the width of the bowel on X-ray.

Investigations for Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Diagnostic Test: Abdominal X-ray
    • Erect View:
      • Better for identifying air-fluid levels.
      • Shows dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern.
  • Supine View:
    • Better for identifying the site of obstruction.
    • Obstruction typically visible in the ileum.
  • IOC-CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):
    • Used for:
      • High-grade obstruction.
      • Extraluminal causes of obstruction.
      • Strangulation.

Radiographic Features

Jejunum

Plicae circulares or valvulae conniventes

  • Visible as circumferential, ring-like patterns.
  • Multiple dilated bowel loops.
  • Loops are centrally located.
  • The mucosal pattern appears well-defined with a “feathery” appearance due to the plicae circulares.

Ileum

(Option B)

Dilated bowel loops.

  • Loops are centrally located.
  • Featureless or “characteristically characterless” appearance, lacking the pronounced mucosal pattern seen in the jejunum.

Duodenum (Option C): Retroperitoneal, less frequently visible on abdominal X-ray unless there is significant dilation.

Transverse colon (Option D): Haustrations (incomplete lines that do not span the full width of the bowel).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain, with each episode lasting for 3-5 min and subsiding with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He has a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia and is currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Injection enoxaparin

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation, history of recurrent chest pain, and ECG findings of left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-waves raise concerns for NSTEMI-acute coronary syndrome. Injection enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is often used as an initial treatment to prevent clot formation and progression of coronary artery disease.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularisation includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).


Incorrect Options:

IV glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Option A) is given in case of patients presenting with ongoing chest pain. The given scenario here gives a history of recurrent chest pains but does not specify that the patient suffers from it at presentation. Hence, it is not the best step for management.

Add clopidogrel (Option C): Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug that has antithrombotic action, however, enoxaparin is a better agent than clopidogrel and hence not preferred.

Increase the dose of beta-blocker (Option D): This step is not preferred over anticoagulation therapy using enoxparin.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neurons

Explanation:

Neurons are terminally differentiated, non-dividing cells. Their low mitotic activity makes them relatively resistant to radiation-induced damage.

According to the Law of Bergonie:

The more the cells are rapidly dividing, the more they are sensitive to radiation.

  • M-phase (dividing phase) is the most radiosensitive phase
  • S-phase (Synthesizing phase) is the most radioresistant phase

  • Most radiosensitive tissue in the body is Bone marrow (rapidly dividing).
  • Most radioresistant tissue in the body is neurons (non-dividing).
  • Most radiosensitive cells in the blood are lymphocytes.
  • The most radioresistant cell in the blood is the platelet.
  • The most radioresistant organ in the body is the vagina.

Spermatogonia (Option A): are highly radiosensitive because they are actively dividing cells. Irradiation can severely affect spermatogenesis.

Intestinal epithelial cells (Option B): are composed of rapidly dividing cells. It has one of the highest turnover rates in the body, making it highly sensitive to radiation.

Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells (Option D): Bone marrow cells, including erythroid precursors, are highly proliferative and sensitive to radiation. Irradiation often results in significant suppression of hematopoiesis.

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post-surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. Suspecting meningitis, which of the following is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

  • In cases where a child with a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt presents with symptoms, suggestive of meningitis, obtaining a CSF sample from the shunt tap is the preferred method to evaluate for infection, as it involves accessing the shunt reservoir and collecting CSF directly from it. The shunt tap procedure allows for a more accurate assessment of CSF infection, as it is more likely to reflect the current status of the shunt system. Additionally, blood cultures should also be obtained to identify any potential bloodstream infection.

Shunt-related meningitis:

  • Most common complication of the CSF shunts.
  • Most frequently caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis.
  • Diagnosed by “Shunt tapping” (direct aspiration of the shunt).
  • Management: Antibiotic therapy and shunt removal.

Complications of CSF Shunt:

  • Shunt occlusion
    • Manifesting as headache, papilledema, vomiting, altered mental status.
  • Bacterial infections, caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), most commonly by S. epidermidis.
  • This may result in the following:
    • Meningitis (fever, headache, irritability)
    • Peritonitis (fever, abdominal tenderness, distention, pain)
    • Wound infection (erythema, swelling, discharge, or dehiscence along the shunt tract and most often occurs within days to weeks of the surgical procedure)

Wait and watch (Option A) is not appropriate in this case, as prompt evaluation and treatment are necessary for suspected meningitis as it is life threatening.

Check shunt patency by nuclear study (Option B): While shunt malfunction is a possibility in a child with a VP shunt, the symptoms described are more suggestive of an infection. Checking shunt patency may be a consideration, but it is not the most urgent next step.

Blood culture and taking a CSF sample by lumbar puncture (Option D) is not the preferred choice because obtaining CSF from the shunt tap provides a more direct and specific assessment of the shunt system.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is responsible for returning deoxygenated blood back to the placenta in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Umbilical artery

  • In fetal circulation, deoxygenated blood is carried back to the placenta through the umbilical artery.

Fetal circulation:

Structure

Number

Type of Blood

Flow of blood

Umbilical Artery

2

Deoxygenated blood

Fetus to the placenta

Umbilical Vein

1

Oxygenated blood

Placenta to the fetus

questions.text: Which of the following investigations would be most beneficial in diagnosing the condition of a 10-year-old boy who is experiencing seizures along with a medical history of fever accompanied by a rash at the age of 1 year, which was resolved on its own?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - lgG measles in CSF:

  • The child's history of fever with rash at 1 year of age, which resolved spontaneously, suggests a possible previous measles infection.

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles that can occur years after a measles infection. In SSPE, there is persistent measles virus infection in the central nervous system, leading to inflammation and progressive neurological deterioration. To diagnose SSPE, the presence of elevated measles-specific IgG antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is considered a helpful investigation. IgG antibodies are produced in response to previous infection and can persist in the CSF for an extended period.

Complications of Measles: Complications of measles are more frequent in the young, malnourished and immunocompromised individuals.

  • Otitis media (most common complication)
  • Pneumonia (most common cause of death)
  • Other respiratory complications - bronchitis, laryngitis, etc.
  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE): rare, fatal (most common long term complication.
  • Acute encephalitis

Prevention of Measles:

  • Measles is a preventable and potentially eradicable disease.
  • Maternal antibodies protect infants until 6-9 months of age, so administering the vaccine at 9 months in endemic countries ensures early protection and seroconversion.
  • The measles vaccine, derived from the Edmonston-Zagreb strain, is available as a monovalent preparation or in combination with rubella (MR), mumps (MMR), and varicella (MMR-V).
  • The vaccination schedule is as follows:

Vaccine

MR (Measles-Rubella)

Type

Live attenuated

Dose

0.5 ml

Site

Right upper arm (at the insertion of deltoid)

Schedule

1st dose - 9 months; 2nd dose - 16-24 months

MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (Option B) is a specific finding on MRI associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It is characterized by atrophy and abnormal signal intensity in the mesial temporal structures, particularly the hippocampus.

The detection of lgM measles in CSF (Option C) may indicate recent or ongoing measles infection. However, in the case of SSPE, the initial measles infection usually occurred several years before the onset of symptoms. Therefore, the presence of IgM antibodies in CSF is not helpful in diagnosing SSPE.

C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF (Option D) are not associated with SSPE or measles infection. These antibodies are typically associated with certain autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy weighs 8 kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-age) is provided below. What is the most appropriate advice for this child?

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation centre
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother how to feed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother how to feed

  • The child's weight for age falls between -2 SD and -3 SD on the growth chart (Moderately underweight). This child's weight is below the average range for his age, indicating some degree of malnutrition. However, it is not severe enough to warrant immediate referral to a nutrition rehabilitation center.
  • Instead, the focus should be on educating the mother or caregiver on proper feeding practices and providing guidance on improving the child's nutritional intake. This may involve promoting a balanced diet, ensuring adequate calorie and nutrient intake, and addressing any feeding difficulties or challenges.

WHO Growth Charts

  • Designed specifically to track the growth and development of children under 5 years of age globally.
  • Growth charts are derived from the Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS) carried out by the WHO. This study was a community-based, multi-country initiative that took place in Brazil, Ghana, India, Norway, Oman, and the United States.
  • Features: Provide accurate references for weight, length, and head circumference, reflecting normal growth patterns in children.

Percentile Curves: The growth chart displays curves representing percentiles (3rd, 15th, 50th, 85th, and 97th).

  • 3rd Percentile: Lower end of normal growth.
  • 50th Percentile: Median or average growth.
  • 97th Percentile: Higher end of normal growth.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old patient who presented with a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination revealing the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Retinoblastoma

  • A paediatric patient with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and Histiopathology revealing Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes is diagnostic of Retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette is an example of True rosette and is a highly specific feature of Retinoblastoma.

Clinical features and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma:

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

Incorrect Options:

Medulloblastoma (Option B): is a rapidly growing tumor of the brain, is unlikely to present with eye symptoms initially. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Synaptophysin+, CD56+, GFAP+.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C): presents with acute painful proptosis. Usually seen in boys in the 1st decade of life. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Desmin+.

Astrocytoma (Option D): Histopathology would reveal Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells, Eye manifestations are unlikely to be seen in Astrocytoma.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - MRI

  • MRI is contraindicated in cases where there is a risk of metallic foreign bodies, such as in this industrial worker with a suspected foreign body in the eye. The strong magnetic field of an MRI can cause movement or displacement of the metallic object, potentially leading to further injury or damage to the eye.

Intraocular Foreign Bodies (IOFBs):

Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
