  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred.
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs.
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely to be affected in a patient who underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein and is now experiencing paresthesia and sensory loss over the inner side of the leg and foot?
questions.solution:
Answer B - Saphenous nerve

  • The saphenous nerve is a purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve (L3-L4) that supplies sensation to the medial leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the great saphenous vein (GSV) is commonly harvested for the bypass procedure.
  • Since the saphenous nerve runs alongside the GSV in the leg, it is highly susceptible to injury during vein harvesting, leading to paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

Superficial peroneal nerve (option A): Provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Unlikely to be affected in CABG as it is located in the lateral compartment of the leg.

Femoral nerve (option C): Provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior and medial thigh. Injury would cause weakness of quadriceps and loss of knee jerk reflex, which is not described in the question.

Sural nerve (option D): Provides sensory innervation to the lateral foot and posterolateral calf. Not involved in medial leg and foot sensation, making it an unlikely option.

questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
Answer A - Anterior communicating artery

  • The optic chiasma is located just above the anterior communicating artery (AComA) in the suprasellar cistern. Aneurysms of the AComA are the most common intracranial aneurysms and can compress the optic chiasma, leading to bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes). These aneurysms often present with vision loss, headaches, and possibly subarachnoid hemorrhage if they rupture.

 

 

Anterior choroidal artery (option B): This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Aneurysms here are rare and typically cause contralateral motor deficits rather than optic chiasma compression.

Middle cerebral artery (option C): The MCA does not course near the optic chiasma. MCA aneurysms more commonly affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or neglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (option D): The ACA courses superior to the optic chiasma, but aneurysms at this location usually do not cause direct compression. ACA infarcts more commonly lead to leg weakness (contralateral) due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a fever and massive splenomegaly. The spleen was 15 cm on palpation and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Phrenicocolic ligament:

  • The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold that extends from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm, supporting the spleen inferiorly. It acts as a shelf that prevents the spleen from descending vertically into the left lower quadrant, limiting downward displacement in conditions like massive splenomegaly.

Lienorenal ligament (option A): Also called the splenorenal ligament, it connects the spleen to the left kidney and contains the splenic vessels and tail of the pancreas. It provides posterior support but does not prevent downward descent of the spleen.

Gastrosplenic ligament (option B): This ligament connects the stomach to the spleen and contains the short gastric arteries and left gastroepiploic artery. It mainly stabilizes the spleen anteromedially but does not prevent downward movement.

Lienophrenic ligament (option D): Also called the splenophrenic ligament, it attaches the spleen to the diaphragm and provides superior support. It prevents upward displacement, not downward movement.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Circumvallate

  • Circumvallate papillae are large, dome-shaped papillae located at the posterior part of the tongue, arranged in a V-shape anterior to the sulcus terminalis. They have deep surrounding trenches (moats) lined by taste buds, which help in taste perception.
  • Von Ebner's glands, which secrete serous fluid to cleanse taste buds, are located at the base of the trenches.

Fungiform papillae (option A): Mushroom-shaped papillae located scattered on the anterior tongue, mainly on the tip and sides. Contain taste buds on their apical surface but lack surrounding trenches.

Filiform papillae (option C): Most numerous, thin, and conical papillae covering most of the tongue's dorsal surface. Do not contain taste buds; instead, they aid in mechanical functions such as food manipulation.

Foliate papillae (option D): Located on the lateral margins of the tongue as vertical folds. Contain numerous taste buds but are less developed in humans.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Answer C - Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The musculocutaneous nerve (C5–C7) arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and primarily supplies the flexor muscles of the arm.

Key functions affected in this injury:

  • Elbow flexion → Impaired due to paralysis of biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis.
  • Forearm supination → Weakened because biceps brachii is affected (but supination is not completely lost as the supinator muscle is intact).
  • Sensory loss → Over the lateral aspect of the forearm due to involvement of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, which is a branch of the musculocutaneous nerve.

Coracobrachialis:

  • Origin: Medial coracoid process ; Insertion: Medial aspect of middle humerus
  • Nerve supply: Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)
  • Action: Flexion (+adduction) of arm at shoulder joint
  • May not be paralyzed in Erb’s palsy, as in case of Erb’s palsy: C5,C6 are compromised but C7 remains unaffected and hence Coracobrachialis is not paralyzed.

Muscles of arm:

Muscle

Attachments

Nerve supply

Action

Biceps brachii
  • Origin: Short head- Coracoid process ; Long head- Supragelnoid tubercle
  • Insertion: Radial tuberosity
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C6)
  • Flexion and supination of forearm

Brachialis
  • Origin: anterior humerus
  • Insertion: coronoid process & ulnar tuberosity
  • Motor: Musculocutaneous nerve
  • Proprioceptive: Radial nerve
  • Flexion of forearm

Coraco- brachialis
  • Origin: medial coracoid process
  • Insertion: medial aspect of middle humerus
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)
  • Flexion of arm

Median nerve (option A): Motor: Controls most forearm flexors and thenar muscles, but does not significantly affect elbow flexion or supination. Sensory: Supplies the lateral palm and first three fingers, not the lateral forearm.

Radial nerve (option B): Motor: Affects wrist extension (wrist drop) and elbow extension, but not elbow flexion. Sensory: Supplies the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand, not the lateral forearm.

Ulnar nerve (option D): Motor: Controls intrinsic hand muscles and some forearm flexors, but does not significantly affect elbow flexion or supination. Sensory: Involves the medial hand and little finger, not the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lingual nerve

  • The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve, runs very close to the submandibular gland and is at high risk of injury during gland resection.

Functions affected if damaged:

  • Loss of general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Loss of taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (as it carries fibres from the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve).
  • Possible decreased salivation (as chorda tympani also carries parasympathetic fibres to the submandibular and sublingual glands).

  • The lingual nerve originates from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) in the infratemporal fossa.
  • It then descends and moves forward, initially positioned medially to the lateral pterygoid muscle and deep to the ramus of the mandible.
  • As it enters the floor of the mouth, it lies superficial to the hyoglossus muscle and deep to the submandibular duct.
  • The nerve loops under the duct, passing from lateral to medial, before ascending to supply sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • This intricate course places the lingual nerve close to the submandibular gland, making it particularly susceptible to injury during surgical procedures in this area.

Nerve to mylohyoid (option A): A branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (V3), it supplies the mylohyoid muscle and anterior belly of the digastric muscle. Damage would affect floor of mouth muscle function, but not tongue sensation or taste.

Inferior alveolar nerve (option B): This nerve runs inside the mandibular canal and supplies sensation to the lower teeth, chin, and lower lip. It is not closely related to the submandibular gland.

Hypoglossal nerve (option D): Supplies motor function to all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). Injury would cause tongue deviation towards the affected side, but not sensory or taste loss.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - IX

  • The Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx, soft palate, and uvula. Touching the uvula stimulates the afferent limb of the gag reflex, which is mediated by CN IX.
  • The efferent response of the gag reflex is carried by the Vagus nerve (CN X), causing contraction of the pharyngeal muscles.

Vagus nerve (Option X): Controls motor innervation of the soft palate and pharynx but does not carry sensory input from the uvula. If damaged, it causes uvula deviation to the opposite side, but it is not responsible for sensation.

Accessory nerve (Option XI): Innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Has no role in sensation or movement of the uvula.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option XII): Controls tongue muscles, affecting tongue movement. Does not contribute to the gag reflex or uvula sensation.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This occurs due to the inhibition of ________ by aspirin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thromboxane

Explanation:

  • Inhibition of thromboxane by aspirin results in bleeding within the gastrointestinal tract, which leads to the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Aspirin

MOA

Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, particularly COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 is involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxane.

Effect on platelets

  • Thromboxane A2 is a potent pro-inflammatory and pro-thrombotic molecule that promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
  • By inhibiting COX-1, aspirin reduces the production of thromboxane A2, which leads to decreased platelet aggregation and a reduced tendency for blood clot formation, which can contribute to gastrointestinal bleeding, including the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Uses

  • Analgesic: Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Antipyretic
  • Antiplatelet: Post Myocardial infraction and CVA

Adverse effects

0.5-2 g/day - analgesic dose

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Epigastric discomfort

3-5 g/day - anti-inflammatory dose

  • Salicylism - vertigo, hyperventilation, tinnitus, reversible loss of hearing
  • Hepatitis
  • Hypersensitivity

Reye’s syndrome: A rare condition seen when salicylates are given in children suffering from viral infections such as influenza, presenting as acute liver failure.

 

Phospholipase A2 (Option A) plays a crucial role in the release of arachidonic acid from cell membrane phospholipids, which is a precursor for prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes. Aspirin does not inhibit PLA2 directly; rather, it acts downstream of this enzyme by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes that convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins and thromboxanes.

Phospholipase C (Option C) is involved in cellular signal transduction, where it cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) into diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol trisphosphate (IP3). These molecules act as second messengers in pathways regulating calcium signalling and protein kinase C activation.

Phospholipase D (Option D) is involved in lipid signalling pathways. It hydrolyzes phosphatidylcholine to produce phosphatidic acid, a precursor for several signalling molecules.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a previous history of Colle’s fracture came to the OPD with complaints of lower backache. On evaluation, her T score was -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition are false?

choices.text: Teriparatide should be started before supplementing with bisphosphonates
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

Explanation:

Bisphosphonates can be safely used for longer durations (typically 3–5 years) in most patients, with periodic evaluation to assess efficacy and risk of adverse effects like osteonecrosis of the jaw or atypical fractures.

  • The patient's history of a pathological wrist fracture, combined with her T-scores, leads to the diagnosis of osteoporosis, which increases the risk of future fractures.
  • Bisphosphonates are considered the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.
  • The most commonly used bisphosphonates include Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid.
  • While the duration of treatment may vary depending on the individual's response and specific circumstances, bisphosphonates can be prescribed for several years to maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • It can last up to 10 years, and beyond that, it increases the risk of femur fracture.

Mechanism of action:

 

Uses of Bisphosphonates:

Condition

Role of Bisphosphonates

Osteoporosis

Effective in preventing and treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, age-related, idiopathic, and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Paget's Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain, and improve secondary symptoms.

Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

Lower serum calcium levels, especially in severe cases.

Metastatic Bone Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions and reduce bone pain.

 

Teriparatide (Option A) is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and is often considered a first-line treatment option for severe osteoporosis. It stimulates new bone formation and is typically prescribed before bisphosphonates if the patient has severe osteoporosis or has experienced a recent fragility fracture.

Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day (Option C), as the recommended daily intake of calcium for postmenopausal women is generally 1200 mg. Adequate calcium intake is important for maintaining bone health and preventing osteoporosis.

Oral vitamin D3 (Option D) is given along with oral calcium, as Vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium absorption and bone health. Postmenopausal women with osteoporosis often require supplemental vitamin D to ensure optimal calcium absorption. Vitamin D3 is the preferred form of vitamin D supplementation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myasthenia gravis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations of excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day, ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing point to the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Clinical Features of Myasthenia Gravis

  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Muscle Weakness Patterns

Affected Muscles

Key Features

Ocular muscles

Mimics central eye movement disorders.

Cogan's lid twitch sign

The upper eyelid rises briefly after looking down for some time.

Shoulder girdle muscles

Difficulty in overhead activities like combing hair.

Respiratory muscles

Weakness may cause respiratory failure and aspiration risks.
  • Ventilatory support: Essential for severe respiratory weakness.
  • Ineffective coughing: Increases aspiration risk.

Incorrect Options:

Lamberton-Eaton syndrome (Option B) involves muscle weakness and autonomic dysfunctions like a dry mouth. The muscle weakness improves with use in contrast to myasthenia gravis.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option C) presents with weakness, difficulty in walking, fractures in ambulatory patients, lumbar lordosis, episodes of aspiration, nasal regurgitation, etc. The weakness does not improve on resting or exercise. It is also associated with intellectual disability and often presents in the first few years of life.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D) presents with a characteristic malar rash with musculoskeletal symptoms like joint pain with synovitis of more than 2 joints leading to deformities.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given intravenous medication for the same. Later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Benzhexol

Explanation:

  • Based on the history and clinical features, the patient was most likely given IV Metoclopramide, after which he developed extra-pyramidal symptoms of abnormal movements, and Benzhexol, which is an anti-cholinergic, can be used to treat the same.

Metoclopramide

MOA
  • Dopamine receptor antagonist; acts centrally as a prokinetic and anti-emetic.

Side effects

  • Extrapyramidal symptoms
    • Acute dystonia - occurs shortly after IV injection
    • Parkinson-like symptoms seen after weeks of therapy
    • Irreversible tardive dyskinesia - occurs with chronic treatment
  • Galactorrhoea
  • Methemoglobinemia

Management of extrapyramidal symptoms

  • Discontinuation of the drug.
  • Benzhexol - centrally acting anticholinergic agents.
  • Restores cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

 

Hyoscine (Option A), also known as scopolamine, is primarily used to prevent and treat motion sickness and nausea. It does not specifically target or treat abnormal movements.

Cyproheptadine (Option B) is an antihistamine often used for allergic conditions and appetite stimulation. It can sometimes be used off-label to treat serotonin syndrome, but it is not typically used for drug-induced abnormal movements.

Levodopa (Option C) is a medication commonly used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. It helps replenish dopamine levels in the brain. However, levodopa is not typically used to treat drug-induced abnormal movements caused by other medications.

questions.text: What is the dosing rate of a drug based on?

choices.text: Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration

Explanation:

  • The formula for drug dosing rate is Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration.
  • The equation for dose rate is based on steady-state concentration. When a drug is given repeatedly at short intervals, it will accumulate in the body until the elimination of the drug matches the intake of the drug.
  • Thus, steady-state concentration is the plasma concentration at which drug elimination = drug intake.

Steady-state concentration = dosing rate/clearance

Loading dose = Volume of distribution X Desired steady-state plasma concentration

Maintenance dose = Target plasma concentration X Clearance X Dosing interval

Bioavailability (F)

Dosing rate = Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Given antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation
Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, such as productive cough, tachypnea, and hypotension, align with the diagnosis of pneumonia.
  • The CURB-65 score of this patient is 2 (age >/= 65 and urea > 19mg/dl); hence, the patient can be considered for admission to a non-ICU setting for further management.

Treatment for Lobar Pneumonia

  • Treatment depends on severity; assess if inpatient or outpatient management is needed.
  • CURB-65 Score: Used to stratify patients with the following factors:

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1
  • Hospitalization Criteria:
    • CURB-65 score 1 or 2: Indicates hospitalization
    • A score ≥3: Indicates ICU admission and more intensive therapy. (Option B and C)
  • Empiric Therapy:
    • Outpatient: (Option A)
      • When no symptoms in the CURB-65 scoring system are present.
      • No comorbidities: Monotherapy with macrolides (Azithromycin, Clarithromycin).
      • With comorbidities (chronic lung/heart disease, diabetes, smoking, HIV): Newer Fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin, Gemifloxacin) or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., Amoxicillin) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient Non-ICU:
      • Newer Fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin) alone or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin, Ceftriaxone) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient ICU:
      • Combination of macrolide (Azithromycin) or newer fluoroquinolone (Levofloxacin) with beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin-sulbactam, Ertapenem).
      • If risk of aspiration, consider ampicillin-sulbactam or ertapenem; for Pseudomonas infection, use anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., Piperacillin-tazobactam) with anti-pseudomonal fluoroquinolone (e.g., Ciprofloxacin).
      • For MRSA, add vancomycin or linezolid.
  • Duration of Therapy: Typically 5 to 7 days, extended if clinical response is delayed.
  • Influenza Treatment: All hospitalized patients testing positive for influenza should receive Oseltamivir, regardless of illness onset.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent a nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acetaminophen

Explanation:

  • As this patient has recently undergone nephrectomy due to chronic kidney disease, Acetaminophen is the most appropriate postoperative analgesic.
  • It inhibits COX-3, increases endogenous cannabinoids, and stimulates TRP-V1 receptors, resulting in analgesia and antipyretic properties.
  • It is generally considered safe and well-tolerated in patients with chronic kidney disease.
  • Patients with chronic kidney disease often have reduced kidney function and impaired clearance of certain medications, including NSAIDs and NSAIDs, which can cause further kidney damage and potentially worsen renal function, so their use is generally avoided in this patient population.
  • NSAIDs cause impairment of prostaglandin-induced inhibition of chlorine reabsorption and ADH action, which results in salt and water retention. It also inhibits COX-2-derived prostaglandins, which regulate renal medullary blood flow, resulting in elevated blood pressure and increased risk of cardiac failure.

However, acetaminophen is considered a safer alternative as it is primarily metabolized in the liver and excreted by the kidneys in a non-toxic form.

 

Naproxen (Option A), Indomethacin (Option B), and Diclofenac (Option C), are NSAIDs that are not safe to be used in CKD.

questions.text: Which anti-hypertensive medication is suitable for administration to a patient suffering from renal insufficiency, exhibiting symptoms of significantly reduced urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure reading of 160/90?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amlodipine

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical presentation and findings in this patient, the most appropriate anti-hypertensive drug would be Amlodipine.
  • Calcium channel blockers achieve better blood pressure control in the long term. It can be used as an add-on therapy with other antihypertensive agents, and its once-daily dosing improves patient compliance.
  • Amlodipine is often well-tolerated and can be used in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Mechanism of action of CCB (Dihydropyridines):

  • It blocks the entry of calcium ions through the L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasodilation and a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance.

Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine

(Short-acting)

Primarily used for angina pectoris.

It is not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine

(Short-acting)

It is commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine

(Ultra-short-acting)

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine

(Long-acting)

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension.

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Aliskiren (Option A) is a direct renin inhibitor that can be used to treat hypertension. However, it is generally not recommended in patients with renal insufficiency, as it can further decrease kidney function.

Chlorthalidone (Option B) is a thiazide-like diuretic that is often used to treat hypertension. However, in a patient with very low urine output and pedal edema, adding a diuretic may not be the initial choice, as it may exacerbate fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

Prazosin (Option D) is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker that is used to treat high blood pressure. However, in this scenario, with symptoms of renal insufficiency and very low urine output, the focus should be on addressing the underlying renal issue and controlling blood pressure with other medications.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presented with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal oedema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Octreotide plus albumin

Explanation:

The patient likely has Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS), a complication of advanced liver disease characterized by renal dysfunction due to splanchnic vasodilation and reduced renal perfusion for which the best method of treatment is administering octreotide with albumin.

  • HRS is diagnosed based on clinical features, including worsening renal function, low urine sodium (<10 mEq/L), and exclusion of other causes of acute kidney injury (e.g., hypovolemia, nephrotoxicity).

Treatment of Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose Norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting
  • Octreotide is a synthetic analogue of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of various substances in the body.
  • When combined with albumin, it can help manage hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).
  • HRS occurs due to severe vasoconstriction of the renal blood vessels, leading to reduced renal blood flow and impaired kidney function.
  • Octreotide helps alleviate vasoconstriction, while albumin improves intravascular volume and renal perfusion.
  • The recommended dosage of albumin infusion in HRS is 1 g/kg per day, up to a maximum of 100 g/day, to expand intravascular volume and improve renal perfusion.
  • Higher doses (e.g., 2-5 g/kg/day) are avoided due to risks such as pulmonary oedema.

Incorrect Options:

Methylprednisolone (Option A) is not used in hepatorenal syndrome due to the potential risk of worsening liver function in patients with cirrhosis.

Heparin (Option B) is an anticoagulant and not helpful with HRS management as it raises the concern of haemorrhage.

Torsemide (Option C) is a loop diuretic and not suitable for HRS management because diuretics lead to a depletion of effective circulating volume, which is already low in cirrhosis, further increasing the renal hypoperfusion.

questions.text: Evaluation of a patient revealed the presence of a mid-diastolic murmur. JVP showed prominent a-waves. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tricuspid stenosis

Explanation:

  • The mid-diastolic murmur and the prominent a-waves on the JVP suggest the narrowing of the tricuspid valve, called tricuspid stenosis.

Tricuspid Stenosis

Aetiology

  • Congenital
  • Rheumatic origin (often coexists with mitral stenosis)

Pathophysiology

  • RA pressure ↑ , due to the diastolic pressure gradient between RA and RV, results in systemic venous congestion.
  • Restricted forward flow of blood leads to ↓ cardiac output.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue
  • Mild dyspnea
  • Venous congestion (right-side heart failure): Hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema and may lead to cardiac cirrhosis.
  • Physical examination:
    • Jugular venous distension with prominent ‘a’ waves
    • Auscultation: Mid-diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border
    • Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).
  • If mitral stenosis coexist
    • Pulmonary artery hypertension
    • Orthopnea due to pulmonary oedema

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray and ECG show features of RA enlargement
  • Echocardiogram: Thickened tricuspid valve with diastolic doming and increased pressure gradient between RV and RA.

Management

  • Medical management: To reduce systemic venous congestion symptoms
    • Dietary salt restriction
    • Loop diuretics
  • Surgical intervention: Valvular repair or Prosthetic valve replacement.

Incorrect Options:

Mitral stenosis (MS) (Option A) causes left atrial pressure overload, leading to pulmonary congestion and dyspnea, often with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. It is associated with a low-pitched rumbling mid-diastolic murmur with an opening snap but no prominent a-waves in JVP unless it is a severe case.

Mitral regurgitation (Option C) presents with a holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, which is not the given scenario. The JVP changes are seen only in severe cases.

Tricuspid regurgitation (Option D) is associated with a ‘C-v’ wave and steep ‘y’ descent in the JVP and has a blowing holosystolic murmur.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with pain in the thigh during walking. Investigation reveals the following finding as given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aortofemoral bypass

Explanation:

The condition, characterised by thigh pain during walking and a radiograph showing narrowing of vessels indicating blockage, is diagnosed as aortofemoral block, with the best surgical management being Aortofemoral Bypass.

  • It is preferred when the block extends to distal iliac arteries.
  • Grafts:
    • Knitted/woven Dacron (needs preclotting)
    • Collagen-impregnated Dacron/PTFE (does not require preclotting).

 

PTA with stenting (Option A), or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting, is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat narrowed or blocked blood vessels, particularly in the arteries. It is commonly performed to restore blood flow in peripheral arteries affected by atherosclerosis or other conditions.

Femoroiliac bypass (Option B), also known as femoral-to-iliac bypass or femoral bypass, is a surgical procedure used to treat peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the lower extremities. It involves creating a bypass graft to reroute blood flow around a narrowed or blocked femoral or iliac artery segment.

Aorto-iliac bypass (Option D), also known as an aortobifemoral bypass, is a surgical procedure used to treat severe peripheral artery disease (PAD) affecting the aorto-iliac arteries. It involves creating a bypass graft to restore blood flow from the aorta to the iliac arteries, bypassing the diseased or blocked segments. It is also done to treat Leirche syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What is the best agent to prevent future thrombotic events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral warfarin

Explanation:

  • Oral warfarin is the best agent to prevent thrombotic events in case of mitral stenosis.

Mitral Stenosis (MS):

  • Aetiology:
    • Primary Cause: Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis, accounting for about 40% of cases in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease.
    • Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute valve, cor triatriatum)
    • Mitral annular calcification with involvement of leaflets
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Left atrial myxoma
    • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation
  • Symptoms:
    • Exertional dyspnea, cough, and progressive limitation of daily activities.
    • Orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea can develop as MS worsens.
    • Atrial fibrillation (AF) often accelerates symptom progression.
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary Hypertension (Leading to RVH & RHF)
    • Atrial Fibrillation (Due to Left atrial enlargement)
    • Thrombus Formation: Stasis of blood in the enlarged left atrium, increases the risk of thrombus formation, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation.
    • Hemoptysis (Elevated pulmonary venous pressure - rupture of small veins)
    • Infective Endocarditis
    • Pulmonary Infections

Management of Mitral Stenosis:

  • Medical Management: Patients with mild symptoms may be managed medically.
    • Penicillin Prophylaxis: Essential for preventing rheumatic fever in risk patients.
    • Symptomatic Relief: Sodium restriction, diuretics, beta-blockers, and Calcium channel blockers help manage symptoms and control heart rate in atrial fibrillation (AF).
    • Anticoagulation: Warfarin is for patients with AF, a history of thromboembolism, or left atrial thrombus; INR target 2–3.
    • Cardioversion: For recent-onset AF, ensure anticoagulation for at least three weeks.
    • Infective Endocarditis Prophylaxis: Routine antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended.
  • Interventional: Considered if patients remain symptomatic despite medical management or if pulmonary hypertension develops/Severe MS (<1.5 cm²)
    • Balloon valvuloplasty
    • Mitral valvotomy/Mitral valve replacement

Incorrect Options:

Dabigatran (Option A) is an alternative anticoagulant but is not preferred as the first-line treatment as it has an increased risk of causing thromboembolic events.

Aspirin + Clopidogrel (Option B & D) is not approved for use in mitral stenosis to prevent thrombotic events.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition mentioned below?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts Fournier's Gangrene, a severe, progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial flora.

Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Cause

It is usually caused by mixed bacterial fora (Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). (Option B)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible oedema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localised tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

 

Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy (Option A), which is an incorrect statement as it is not required in Fournier gangrene.

Bilateral orchiectomy is generally performed (Option C) is an incorrect statement as Bilateral orchiectomy is generally not required in this condition, and testis is unaffected.

Compulsory urinary diversion is performed (Option D) is an incorrect statement as the urinary system is unaffected in this condition.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Recurrent

Explanation:

  • The given scenario, where a patient has a history of cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) for gallstones 2.5 years ago and is now presenting with obstructive jaundice and a gallstone in the common bile duct (CBD), indicates a case of recurrent type of Common Bile Duct Stones (Choledocholithiasis).

Types

  • Retained common bile duct stones
    • Detected within 2 years of cholecystectomy
  • Recurrent common bile duct stones
    • Detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy (Option D)

Clinical features
  • Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice
  • Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad
  • Biliary colic: A sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder, precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal, and can last for a few hours.
  • Darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools.
  • Steatorrhea, or fatty stools
  • Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver Damage
  • Biliary Stricture
  • Gallstone Ileus

 

MRCP of CBD stone

 

      ERCP of a distal CBD stone

 

Primary (Option A) forms inside the common bile duct (CBD), with brownstones being the most common type. These stones are often associated with underlying conditions such as primary sclerosing cholangitis or Caroli disease.

Secondary (Option B) are those that form in the gallbladder and later migrate into the common bile duct (CBD). The most common type is cholesterol stones, which can subsequently move into the CBD.

Tertiary (Option C) are formed within the bile ducts as a result of bacterial or parasitic infection.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Putty kidney

Explanation:

  • In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, the finding shown in the image is likely Putty kidney, a late stage of Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB), characterised by widespread calcification of non-functioning renal tissue, resulting in kidney failure.

 

Bladder TB:

  • Infection Progression: The infection spreads from the ureter into the bladder, with an early sign observable during cystoscopy being pallor around the ureteric orifice in the bladder.
  • Chronic Inflammation: This inflammation leads to the formation of tubercles in the bladder, followed by fibrosis.
  • Bladder Changes: The fibrosis results in a small, contracted bladder with significantly reduced capacity, often referred to as a "thimble bladder."
  • Advanced TB: In advanced cases, where the bladder is contracted, the ureteric orifices may appear as "golf hole" shapes.

 

GUTB involving the prostate:

  • Calcification: The affected area becomes calcified, resulting in a hard and nodular texture.
  • Testis: The testis is usually spared in cases of genitourinary tuberculosis.
  • Characteristic Feature: A distinctive feature of tuberculosis is the "beaded" appearance of the vas deferens, often accompanied by multiple discharging sinuses through the scrotum.

 

Investigations:

  • Urine routine and microscopy-pyuria with or without hematuria
  • Urine culture-sterile pyuria
  • IVU clearly shows the effects of GUTB on the urinary tract, such as:
    • The fuzzy or moth-eaten appearance of the calyces due to ulceration. (Earliest sign of renal TB)
    • Strictures in the ureters cause narrowing or blockage.
    • Hydronephrosis
    • A small, shrunken bladder ("thimble bladder") due to fibrosis
    • Gold standard for early genitourinary tuberculosis
  • CECT
  • Retrograde pyelograms (RGP)-visualisation of ureteral abnormalities and strictures

 

Treatment:

  • Antituberculous Therapy (ATT): The primary treatment for GUTB is a course of ATT (a short course regimen).

 

Nephrocalcinosis (Option B) is the widespread deposition of calcium salts in the kidney tissue, often associated with metabolic disorders like hypercalcemia or chronic kidney disease. While nephrocalcinosis may present with calcifications, it typically does not present in the same "putty" pattern seen in putty kidneys and is often more diffuse.

 

Staghorn calculus (Option C) is a large, branching kidney stone that takes the shape of the renal pelvis and calyces. It usually results from chronic urinary tract infections, often with organisms like Proteus species. While a staghorn calculus may be visible on imaging, it is not associated with the extensive calcification and kidney destruction seen in putty kidneys.

 

Psoas calcification (Option D) refers to calcification of the psoas muscle, which could occur due to past infections, trauma, or other inflammation causes. Psoas calcifications would not be related to kidney tissue and are not indicative of the changes in putty kidneys.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 25-year-old patient who has been experiencing abdominal pain and fever for the past three days, based on the provided chest X-ray taken in an upright position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

The case of abdominal pain, fever, and an upright X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm is most likely diagnosed as hollow viscus perforation.

  • The contents of the organ, including digestive juices and bacteria, can leak into the surrounding tissues or abdominal cavity, leading to a serious condition known as peritonitis.
  • Diagnosis: Free air under the diaphragm (upright plain film taken at the level of the diaphragm). (Option A)

 

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free gas in the peritoneal cavity, typically indicating a perforated viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer).
  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas is seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), but it is difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas.
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualisation (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas.
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.

 

Gastric volvulus (Option: B) occurs when the stomach twists around its axis, leading to obstruction and preventing the passage of food and fluids. It typically causes symptoms like vomiting, nausea, and distension, but not free air under the diaphragm, as seen in hollow viscus perforation. Imaging, such as X-rays or CT scans, may reveal an abnormal stomach position, often showing twisted loops.

 

Liver abscess (Option C) appears as a well-defined dark area on ultrasound and a hypodense lesion with a defined rim on CT. It may cause fever and abdominal pain but doesn’t cause free air under the diaphragm. Diagnosis is typically made with ultrasound or CT, which shows localised fluid collections.

 

Empyema thoracis (Option D) is an infection in the pleural space, causing fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It doesn’t cause free air under the diaphragm. On X-ray, it shows a loculated pleural effusion, with possible diaphragm elevation. CT reveals thickened pleura and fluid collections, while ultrasound aids in detecting and draining fluid.

questions.text: According to the CEAP classification, What will be the stage in this patient as the patient presents with the same problem again and again?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) C2

Explanation:

  • According to the CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology), the stage in this case is C2, as the patient is experiencing recurrent symptoms, indicating that varicose veins are likely the underlying cause, which corresponds to stage C2.

Feature

Classification

For clinical classification:

  • No signs of venous disease
  • Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)
  • Varicose veins (>3 mm )
  • Edema
  • Pigmentation or eczema
  • LDS or atrophic blanche
  • Corona phlebectatica
  • Healed venous ulcer
  • Active venous ulcer

 

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.
  • C0
  • C1 (Option B ruled out)
  • C2 (Option A)
  • C3
  • C4a (Option C ruled out)
  • C4b
  • C4c
  • C5 (Option D ruled out)
  • C6

For etiological classification:

  • Congenital
  • Primary
  • Secondary (post-thrombotic)
  • No venous cause identified

 

  • Ec
  • Ep
  • Es
  • En

For anatomical classification:

  • Superficial veins
  • Perforator veins
  • Deep veins
  • No venous location identified

 

  • As
  • Ap
  • Ad
  • An

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Reflux
  • Obstruction
  • Reflux and obstruction
  • No venous pathophysiology identified

 

  • Pr
  • Po
  • Pr,o
  • Pn

Pigmentation/Eczema:

Atrophic blanche:
