questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is foreign body in the esophagus, as suggested by the X-ray showing an object lodged in the esophagus, causing difficulty swallowing.

Category

Indications

Management

Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects

Immediate endoscopic removal

Urgent

  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours

 

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks

Observation

 

 

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) would cause symptoms like coughing, wheezing, or stridor, but it typically appears as an object in the trachea on X-ray, which is not the case here.

Artifacts (Option C) are typically caused by external factors like motion or poor technique during the X-ray, which would not show a clear foreign body in the esophagus.

Soft tissue calcification in the neck (Option D) refers to calcified structures in the neck, such as lymph nodes or blood vessels, but would not present as a foreign object causing swallowing difficulty.

questions.text: What would be your immediate course of action in managing a patient who is experiencing bleeding from the surgical site following a tonsillectomy while in the recovery room?

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a serious complication that can lead to airway obstruction and significant blood loss. The immediate priority is to secure the airway and control the bleeding. The best course of action is to:

  1. Shift the patient to the operating theater (OT) for better visualization.
  2. Remove clots to identify the bleeding source.
  3. Cauterize or ligate the bleeding vessel to achieve hemostasis.

This is especially crucial in primary post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage (within 24 hours of surgery), which is usually due to inadequate hemostasis during the initial procedure.

Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa (Option B): Incorrect because while IV antibiotics may be necessary in cases of secondary hemorrhage (after 24 hours, often due to infection), primary hemorrhage requires immediate surgical intervention rather than just packing.

Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours (Option C): Incorrect because anticoagulants would worsen the bleeding, and gargling is ineffective in stopping active hemorrhage. Waiting 24 hours without intervention could lead to life-threatening blood loss and airway compromise.

Do blood transfusion and wait and watch (Option D): Incorrect because while a blood transfusion may be needed in severe cases, it does not stop the active bleeding. Immediate surgical control is essential.

questions.text: What is a drug called Mitomycin-C used for in medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Subglottic stenosis

  • Mitomycin-C is an antineoplastic antibiotic that acts as a DNA cross-linking agent and is used topically in various medical and surgical conditions to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and scar formation. In ENT practice, it is commonly used in the treatment of subglottic stenosis to prevent restenosis following airway dilation or surgical intervention.
  • It is applied topically to the affected area after dilation or surgical removal of fibrotic tissue to reduce the risk of recurrence by inhibiting fibroblast proliferation and excessive scarring.

Rhinocerebral mucormycosis (Option B): Incorrect because the treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis primarily involves amphotericin B and surgical debridement, not Mitomycin-C.

Adenoidectomy (Option C): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in routine adenoidectomy. The procedure involves surgical removal of hypertrophied adenoid tissue without the need for an antifibrotic agent.

Tympanoplasty (Option D): Incorrect because Mitomycin-C is not used in tympanoplasty. This procedure aims to repair the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, and there is no role for an antifibrotic agent.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for a patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after undergoing a total thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

A patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after a total thyroidectomy strongly suggests bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerves supply motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except the cricothyroid).
  • Bilateral injury causes bilateral vocal cord paralysis in a paramedian position, leading to airway obstruction, stridor, and inability to extubate due to compromised glottic airway.

Superior laryngeal nerve injury (Option A): Incorrect because this nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle, affecting voice modulation and pitch, but does not cause airway obstruction.

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option B): Incorrect because unilateral RLN injury leads to hoarseness, not significant respiratory distress or extubation failure. The contralateral vocal cord compensates, allowing adequate breathing.

Hematoma (Option D): Incorrect because while a postoperative neck hematoma can cause airway compression, it typically presents with swelling, bruising, and respiratory distress within a few hours postoperatively. Immediate surgical evacuation would relieve symptoms, unlike bilateral RLN injury, which persists despite hematoma evacuation.

questions.text: A female patient came with complaints of nasal obstruction, loss of smell and foul smelling nasal discharge. On examination, presence of yellowish-green crusts in the nasal cavity along with merciful anosmia is observed. Which of the following additional findings may be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Roomy nasal cavity

  • The patient's symptoms, nasal obstruction, anosmia (loss of smell), foul-smelling nasal discharge, and yellowish-green crusts, are highly suggestive of Atrophic Rhinitis.

Atrophic Rhinitis is a chronic nasal condition characterized by:

  • Progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates
  • Formation of thick, foul-smelling nasal crusts
  • Merciful anosmia (patients are unaware of the foul smell)
  • Roomy nasal cavity due to atrophy of nasal structures

Nasal polyps (Option B): Incorrect because nasal polyps present with bilateral nasal obstruction, watery rhinorrhea, and no foul smell. They are soft, pale, and non-crusting, unlike the yellowish-green crusts in Atrophic Rhinitis.

Inferior turbinate hypertrophy (Option C): Incorrect because Atrophic Rhinitis causes atrophy of the turbinates, not hypertrophy. Hypertrophy occurs in allergic rhinitis or chronic rhinitis, which presents with congestion rather than a foul-smelling discharge.

Foreign body (Option D): Incorrect because a foreign body in the nose is more common in children and typically causes unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge, rather than bilateral atrophic changes seen in Atrophic Rhinitis.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lymphedema

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Lymphedema, a common complication after breast cancer surgery, especially when lymph nodes are removed or damaged, leading to painless arm swelling from lymph fluid buildup.

  • It is a frequent complication post-mastectomy or axillary lymph node dissection.
  • Risk factors after breast cancer surgery include the extent of surgery, radiation, obesity, infection, and pre-existing lymphatic issues.

 

Complications of Mastectomy:

  • Lymphedema (Option A)
    • Swelling is caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm or chest wall due to the removal of lymph nodes. (After MRM and axillary dissection).
    • Clinical features:
      • Buffalo hump: Refers to a fat pad that develops on the upper back, often associated with conditions like Cushing’s syndrome or prolonged use of corticosteroids. It is not related to skin pinching or lymphedema.
      • Square toes: The toes appear square-shaped due to prolonged confinement in tight footwear.
      • Stemmer's sign: Skin over the dorsum of the foot cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis.

 

  • Wound infection/Flap necrosis
    • Postoperative infections where blackening of suture line is seen (flap necrosis), if necrosed site note removed, leads to wound infection
  • Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome
    • Chronic pain in the chest or upper arm due to nerve damage or scar tissue formation.
  • Nerve Injuries
    • Long thoracic nerve (winging of the scapula)
    • Thoracodorsal nerve (weakened shoulder adduction)
    • Intercostobrachial nerve (dysaesthesia over medial aspect or upper arm)
    • Medial pectoral nerve (pectoralis muscle atrophy, loss of chest wall contour)
  • Lymphangiosarcoma (Option B ruled out)
    • Stewart-Treves syndrome - Cancerous growth in the lymphatic vessels, often associated with long-standing lymphedema.
    • After an average of 10.5 years following MRM and radiotherapy, the patient develops angiosarcoma.
  • Hematoma formation
  • Axillary vein injury or thrombosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Seroma
  • Shoulder dysfunction
  • Pain and numbness
  • Axillary hyperesthesia

 

Cellulitis (Option D) causes swelling, warmth, redness, pain, and fever, which are not described in this case.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase

Explanation:

  • The patient's severe abdominal pain and CT scan showing fluid-filled lesions near the body of the pancreas suggest an inflammatory process, diagnosed as Pancreatitis, with elevated serum lipase levels.

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  1. Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
  2. Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal.
  3. Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

X-ray Features
  • Sentinel loop sign:
    • Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localised ileus.
    • Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

 

Sentinel loop sign
  • Colon cut-off sign:
    • Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.
    • Significance: Suggests localised pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

 

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • It may underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  • Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  • Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

 

Serum GGT (Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase) (Option A) is elevated in liver disease, especially in cases of alcohol abuse, but it's not specific to pancreatitis.

CEA (Option B), carcinoembryonic antigen, is a tumour marker not typically elevated in pancreatitis.

Serum bilirubin (Option D) may be elevated in biliary obstruction or liver disease; it is not a primary marker for pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with prostate carcinoma presents to you with a PSA of 9 ng/mL with a small tumour focus. His Gleason score is 6. What will be your most likely management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Active surveillance

Explanation:

Active surveillance is the recommended management for a patient with prostate carcinoma presenting with a PSA of 9 ng/mL, a small tumour focus, and a Gleason Score of 6.

  • Purpose:
    • Predicts cancer aggressiveness and potential for spread.
    • Important for prognosis and treatment planning.
  • Scoring System:
    • Ranges from 6 to 10, based on gland appearance and differentiation.
    • Two most common patterns in the biopsy are graded and summed for the final score.

Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation and moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive and very likely to grow and spread quickly.

 

CA Prostate Management:

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option D)

For low-risk cases, regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy

(Option A ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

(Option B, C ruled out)

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

 

Hormone Therapy

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient who arrives at the emergency department with epistaxis, despite unsuccessful attempts to stop the bleeding by pinching the nostrils and nasal packing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

Epistaxis (nosebleed) that persists despite pinching the nostrils and nasal packing suggests posterior epistaxis, which is often due to bleeding from the sphenopalatine artery. The sphenopalatine artery is the main arterial supply to the nasal cavity, making it the primary target for surgical intervention in refractory cases.

Management Approach:

  1. Initial Management
    • Pinching nostrils (first-line conservative treatment)
    • Nasal packing (anterior and posterior)
  2. If Nasal Packing Fails
    • Endoscopic ligation or cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery is the preferred next step.
  3. If Epistaxis Persists
    • Ligation of the external carotid artery may be considered as a last resort.

Ligation of external carotid artery (Option A): Incorrect because sphenopalatine artery ligation is more effective and less invasive. External carotid artery ligation is reserved for extreme, uncontrolled cases.

Ligation of internal carotid artery (Option B): Incorrect because this is very high-risk, associated with stroke and severe complications, and is not required for managing epistaxis.

Ligation of maxillary artery (Option D): Incorrect because while the maxillary artery supplies the sphenopalatine artery, directly ligating the sphenopalatine artery is more targeted and less morbid.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate management for a patient with a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach involving the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver is Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy.

Treatment of Stomach Cancer

  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for gastric cancer.
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy:
      • Most surgical candidates receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve survival.
      • The FLOT4 trial found that the FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen offers a significant survival advantage over the ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (median overall survival: 50 months vs 35 months).

Types of Gastric Resection

  • Total Gastrectomy:
    • Involves the removal of the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.
    • Includes D2 lymphadenectomy.
    • Preferred for resectable gastric cancer.
  • Subtotal Gastrectomy:
    • It may be performed if the tumour is located in the distal stomach.
    • Involves Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative Surgery:
    • Considered for symptom alleviation in inoperable or metastatic gastric cancer.

Non-Surgical Treatment

  • Palliative Chemotherapy or Radiotherapy: Offered to patients with advanced gastric cancer.

 

Radical gastrectomy (Option B) would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible.

Whipple's procedure (Option C) is used for pancreatic cancer; this procedure is not appropriate here due to gastric cancer with liver metastasis.

Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D) would be considered for resectable localised tumours, but with liver metastasis, it’s not an ideal option for curative intent.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Temporal lobe abscess:

  • The CT scan shows a ring-enhancing lesion in the temporal lobe, which is characteristic of a brain abscess. The patient's history of chronic ear infection (chronic otitis media or mastoiditis) suggests that the infection may have spread to the temporal lobe, forming an abscess.

Key Clinical Features:

  • Fever, headache, vomiting → Systemic signs of infection
  • Irritability, confusion → Suggestive of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or local brain involvement
  • History of chronic ear infection → A common cause of temporal lobe abscess

Cerebellar abscess (Option B): Incorrect because cerebellar abscesses usually present with ataxia, dysmetria, and nystagmus, which are not mentioned in the case.

Subdural abscess (Option C): Incorrect because subdural empyemas usually show a crescentic fluid collection rather than a ring-enhancing lesion within the brain parenchyma.

Meningitis (Option D): Incorrect because meningitis would present with diffuse meningeal enhancement rather than a localized ring-enhancing lesion seen on the CT scan.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She had a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, abdomen auscultation revealed high-pitched bowel sounds. Investigations showed air within the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gallstone ileus

Explanation:

The patient, with a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years ago, presents with abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation, and investigations revealing air within the biliary tree, indicating Gallstone ileus.

  • A rare complication of cholelithiasis (0.4%) caused by the impaction of one or more gallstones within the gastrointestinal tract, is more common in the elderly and women.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • Acute cholecystitis→ erosion of inflamed tissues → Formation of a cholecystointestinal fistula→ Gallstone ileus
  • Small gallstones typically pass through the intestines, but stones 2–5 cm in size can become impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction.
  • Signs of obstruction include dehydration, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice. (Option A)

 

Diagnosis:

  • Plain Abdominal Radiograph:
    • Partial or complete intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree
    • Calcified gallstone with position changes on serial films (tumbling sign)
  • CT Scan:
    • Superior sensitivity (up to 93%)
    • Shows abnormal gallbladder with air, air-fluid level, or fluid accumulation with an irregular wall (Option A)

Management:

  • Management of intestinal obstruction
  • Enterolithotomy: The most common surgical procedure
    • A longitudinal incision on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of impaction
    • Gallstone is brought to a non-edematous bowel segment by gentle manipulation and extraction.
  • Cholecystoenteric fistula resection only if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.

 

Adhesive intestinal obstruction (Option B) occurs when scar tissue from previous abdominal surgery causes bowel loops to stick together, leading to obstruction. It typically presents with symptoms of bowel obstruction (pain, vomiting, distention) but would not show air in the biliary tree.

Ischemic enterocolitis (Option C) results from reduced blood flow to the intestines, often due to arterial blockage or low blood pressure. It causes diffuse abdominal pain, tenderness, and sometimes bloody diarrhoea, but does not cause the air in the biliary tree.

Diverticulitis (Option D) is inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon. It usually presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, and does not cause air in the biliary tree.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side. Vitals were unstable. What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space
Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical findings and X-ray confirm a right-sided Tension Pneumothorax and immediate management involves decompressing the pleural space by inserting a wide-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space.
  • It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology:

  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology:

  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation), and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features:

  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management:

  • Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line or the "safe triangle" via needle thoracostomy or finger thoracostomy. (Option A)
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

 

Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids (Option B): While needle decompression is the correct initial management for tension pneumothorax, IV fluids are secondary and do not directly address the life-threatening issue of air accumulation in the pleural space. The priority is to relieve the pressure with a needle insertion, followed by stabilization with fluids.

Intubation and positive pressure ventilation (Option C) are important for managing respiratory failure or compromised airways, but in the case of a tension pneumothorax, these could worsen the condition by increasing the pressure in the chest. The first step should always be to decompress the pleural space to relieve pressure.

e-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) (Option D) exam is useful for detecting pneumothorax, hemothorax, or internal bleeding, but in this case, the patient’s clinical signs strongly suggest a tension pneumothorax. Immediate decompression is needed before further diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

Explanation:

  • The medial bulge near the inferior epigastric vessels suggests a direct Inguinal Hernia, which protrudes through a weakness in Hesselbach's triangle and is treated with Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • It is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia). (Option C, and D ruled out)

Management of Inguinal Hernia:

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy:
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates.
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh.
  • Herniorrhaphy:
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures
    • Techniques:

Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates. (Option A ruled out)

 

Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

 

 

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair (preferred): Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. (Option A ruled out)

 

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair:
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

 

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair

 

 

TEP

TAPP

Procedure
  • Surgery done above the peritoneum
  • Surgery done beneath the peritoneum

Advantages
  • Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications.
  • Reduced risk of adhesions.
  • Larger working space
  • Better visualisation

Disadvantages
  • Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging.
  • A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

questions.text: A patient arrives after being involved in a motorcycle road traffic accident. The patient does not report any pain or injury. Upon examination, there is evidence of blood at the urethral meatus. What would be your subsequent course of action in terms of managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wait and watch

Explanation:

  • Blood at the tip of the urethral meatus suggests a posterior Urethral Injury, for which suprapubic cystostomy is a definitive treatment, but the initial management is conservative unless there are symptoms of urinary retention or significant pelvic hematoma.
  • It refers to damage to the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body.

 

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterisation, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance.

Management

  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterisation or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications

  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

 

Foley’s catheterization (Option A) insertion is avoided in the presence of blood at the urethral meatus, as it may worsen a posterior urethral injury and should be delayed until imaging confirms urethral integrity.

Nephrogram (Option C) is not the immediate step for managing urethral injury. Imaging, like a retrograde urethrogram, is important, but the initial evaluation should be followed to stabilise the patient and ensure proper drainage without causing further harm.

Suprapubic Cystoscopy (Option D) is for significant urethral injury, retention, or obstruction, but if the injury is mild or unconfirmed, a conservative wait-and-watch approach is preferred to avoid unnecessary procedures. It is reserved for severe cases or when other drainage methods are unsafe.

questions.text: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the Procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thiersch wiring

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown is Thiersch wiring, a technique for managing Rectal Prolapse by applying wires or sutures to support the rectal mucosa.
  • It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal

Management of Rectal Prolapse:

Non-Operative Management

  • Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema.
  • Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms.

Operative Management

  • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilization of the rectum.
Aspect
Abdominal Rectopexy
Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

 

Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Option A) aims to remove or reduce prolapsed hemorrhoidal tissue and restore normal anatomical position.

Well's procedure (Option B) is a rare procedure for rectal prolapse, but it involves resection and not the use of wires or sutures (shown above) as in Thiersch wiring.

Altemeier repair (Option D) involves the removal of a segment of the sigmoid colon and rectum through an incision in the perineal area.

questions.text: A patient, after a road traffic accident, presented with pain in the abdomen. The resident examined the child and found that vitals were stable, and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contrast-enhanced CT scan

Explanation:

A CT scan is a non-invasive tool that provides detailed images of abdominal organs and can identify injuries, bleeding, or fractures in patients with abdominal pain after a road traffic accident.

  • The most commonly injured organ in:
    • Blunt trauma abdomen is the spleen > liver.
    • Penetrating trauma is the liver.
    • Gunshot injury is the small intestine > large bowel > liver > intra-abdominal vasculature.
  • The most commonly injured part of the bowel in blunt trauma abdomen is the jejunum and the ileum.
  • The most commonly injured structure in seat belt injury is the mesentery.
  • First investigation done in blunt trauma abdomen: FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).
  • Investigation of choice for stable blunt trauma abdomen: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT scan). (Option A)

 

Retrograde urethrogram (Option B) is used to assess urethral injuries, especially with pelvic fractures or blood at the meatus, but it isn't the best initial test for abdominal pain with left lumbar tenderness.

Wait and watch (Option C) may be considered if the patient is stable with no immediate concern, but in trauma with abdominal pain and tenderness, proper investigation is crucial to rule out serious injuries.

Emergency laparotomy (Option D) is a major surgery and should be done only if there's clear evidence of a life-threatening condition, like active bleeding or peritonitis. It's not the first choice for investigation here.

questions.text: A little boy was playing in a garden. Suddenly, he collapsed and was rushed to the hospital. His friend who played with him in the garden informed the doctors that he ate one of the fruits in the garden post which he seemed to have developed these symptoms. He also had irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Datura, Physostigmine

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Toxins and Antidotes:

Toxicity

Antidote

Mechanism of action

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme

Opium

Naloxone

Opioid receptor antagonist

Organophosphates

Atropine

Pralidoxime

Muscarinic antagonist

Cholinesterase reactivation

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Replenishes Glutathione

Methanol

Fomepizole

Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Inhibits GABA receptors

Cyanide

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)
  1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.
  1. Sodium nitrate: causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
  • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.
  1. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

Datura, Pralidoxime (Option A) Pralidoxime, is an antidote used for organophosphate poisoning, not specifically for Datura poisoning. Organophosphates are a different class of toxic compounds that inhibit acetylcholinesterase, but they have different mechanisms of action compared to Datura alkaloids.

Yellow oleander, Digoxin and Yellow oleander, Physostigmine (Option C and D)

  • Yellow oleander (Thevetia peruviana) is a plant that contains cardiac glycosides, particularly Thevetin A and Thevetin B. Ingestion of yellow oleander can lead to cardiac toxicity, including arrhythmias, conduction disturbances, and cardiac arrest
  • Digoxin, is a cardiac glycoside commonly used in the treatment of heart failure and certain cardiac arrhythmias. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and overdose or toxicity can result in various cardiac manifestations, including arrhythmias.

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Incised looking laceration

  • The most appropriate identification for the lesion shown in the image would be Incised-looking laceration.
  • Split lacerations are commonly seen in areas where the skin is close to bone, such as the scalp, with minimal underlying soft tissue. Although the edges may appear sharp, the presence of tissue bridges confirms the diagnosis of a laceration rather than an incised wound.

Types of Laceration

  • Split laceration
  • Avulsion laceration
  • Stretch laceration
  • Tear laceration
  • Cut laceration

Types of Laceration

 

Split Laceration (Incised looking laceration)
  • These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object.
  • Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue
  • E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin.
  • Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds.
  • Also known as incised looking laceration.
  • These are not undermined and show tissue bridges.

Avulsion (Shearing Laceration)

 
  • Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments.
  • The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying."
  • This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin.
  • Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles.

Laceration (Option A) is a type of wound that is typically irregular, with jagged or torn edges. It is caused by blunt force trauma or tearing of the skin and underlying tissues.

Incised wound (Option B) is a type of wound that is caused by a sharp object or instrument, resulting in clean, straight edges. In the given image, the wound does not have the characteristic clean and straight edges of an incise wound.

Laceration-looking incised wound (Option C)This option suggests that the wound appears like a laceration but actually has the characteristics of an incised wound. In the given image, the wound does not exhibit the typical features of an incised wound, such as clean and straight edges.

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sweating

  • In the given scenario, with a body temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit, the symptom that is least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.
  • Heatstroke is a severe form of heat-related illness characterized by elevated body temperature.
  • Sweating is absent in heat stroke but present in exertional heat stroke

Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Stroke

 

 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure
  • Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness, due to hypotension (Option B)
  • Skin hot, initially wet, then dry (Option A)
  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia
  • Core temp > 40.5°C/104 F
  • Pupils contracted
  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction (Option D)
  • High fever
  • Absence of sweating (Option C)
  • Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children)
  • Subendocardial hemorrhages
  • Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

questions.text: A young teenage boy with a history of drug abuse had been instilled with a shot of intravenous cocaine at a party. He is rushed to the emergency room by his friends. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, and acute coronary spasm. Which of the following symptoms noted would go against the likely diagnosis of cocaine poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia

  • The symptoms of cocaine poisoning typically include diaphoresis (excessive sweating), headache, acute coronary spasm leading to myocardial ischemia (reduced blood flow to the heart), and agitation. Cocaine use usually leads to tachycardia (rapid heart rate) as one of its effects on the cardiovascular system.

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless (Option D)
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate (Option B)
  • Increase in temperature (Option C)
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction (Option A)
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.text: The phenomenon shown below is typically seen in the case of ?

choices.text: Case of suspension or hanging more than 72 hours
Case of immersion in water for 36 hours
Case of colliquative liquefaction due to immersion in hot water

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

  • Immersion in water for an extended period can lead to specific postmortem changes.
  • These changes include maceration of the skin, separation of the epidermis, and swelling due to water absorption.Additionally, there may be a softening and detachment of the skin, known as a "washerwoman's hands" or "glove-like" appearance.
  • Other features that can be observed include skin slippage, wrinkling, and a pale appearance.

Condition

Cause

Symptoms

Treatment
  • Immersion Syndrome (Trench/Immersion Foot/Hand)
  • Prolonged exposure to severe cold (<10ºC) and dampness (common in warfare, trenches, or sea immersion)
  • Affects extremities (feet, hands)
  • Cold, numbness, burning, cyanosis
  • Air drying, protecting extremities from trauma and infection, gradual rewarming by air exposure at room temperature (avoid heat, massaging, or moistening the skin)

Case of torture phalanges (Option A) Torture can cause various injuries and damage to the phalanges, such as fractures, dislocations, or soft tissue injuries. Torture-related injuries would have different characteristics and patterns than those resulting from water immersion.

Case of suspension or hanging more than 72 hours (Option B) Prolonged suspension or hanging can lead to characteristic postmortem changes, such as livor mortis (postmortem lividity), rigor mortis (stiffening of the body), and changes in the neck due to ligature marks or fractures.

Case of colliquative liquefaction due to immersion in hot water (Option D) refers to the process of tissue breakdown and liquefaction that occurs in certain conditions, such as prolonged immersion in warm or hot water.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Bhilawanol

 

Explanation:

The image of the marking nut is Bhilawanol-Semecarpus Anacardium

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning.
  • Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison.

 

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes).
  • Seeds:
    • Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
    • They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air.
  • Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum. Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine.
    • Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes, delirium, coma, and potentially death.
    • Fatal dose: Approximately 5–10 g (5–8 seeds).
    • Fatal period: 12–24 hours.
  • Treatment:
    • Rinse the affected skin with soap and water.
    • Apply bland liniments.
    • Provide demulcent drinks and symptomatic treatment.
  • Medico-legal Aspects:
    • Criminal Use: The juice can be introduced vaginally as a form of punishment for infidelity or applied to the cervical os for illegal abortions.
    • Malingering: The juice can simulate conjunctivitis or falsely substantiate assault claims, as the lesions resemble bruises

 Ricin (Option A) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

Abrin (Option C) is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

Calotropin (Option D) is a cardiac glycoside found in plants of the Calotropis genus, such as Calotropis gigantea and Calotropis procera.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post-mortem change shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Seen within first 12 hours of death
It occurs due to the accumulation of deoxygenated blood
It results due to bacterial activity
It is seen in case of lightning

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) It results from bacterial activity

 

Explanation:

The branching pattern along the blood vessels is typical of marbling, which occurs due to bacterial (Clostridium welchii) decomposition of hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin. This phenomenon usually appears 24 hours after death.

 

Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria (Option C) spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin (Option B), which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

questions.text: What is the appropriate term to describe a person who sits naked on their balcony, deriving sexual pleasure from observing others looking at them, while overlooking a park?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Exhibitionism

 

Explanation:

The behavior described in the scenario, where a guy derives sexual gratification by sitting nude on his balcony and observing people who look at him, is Exhibitionism.

 

Category

Description

Sadism/Algolagnia

Getting satisfaction by giving pain to a partner.

Masochism/

Passive Algolagnia (Option D)

Getting satisfaction by receiving pain from a partner.

Bondage

Combination of Sadism and Masochism.

Lust Murder

Murder acts as a stimulus for sexual arousal.

Urolagnia/Undinism/

Urophilia

Sexual arousal from urine smell, touch, or sight.

Uranism

Sexual gratification by fingering, fondling, licking, or sucking the genitalia of the opposite sex

Coprophilia

Sexual arousal from fecal smell and touch.

Sexual Oralism
  • Fellatio: Oral stimulation of male genitalia.
  • Cunnilingus: Oral stimulation of female genitalia

Exhibitionism (Option C)

Showing private parts.

  • Streaking: Running naked in public.
  • Mooning: Showing bare buttocks (Mnemonic: Moon resembles buttocks)
  • Flashing: Momentarily exposing body parts by quickly moving clothing (Mnemonic: like a flashlight)

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superfecundation

  • Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

 

Superfetation (Option A) refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant.

Suppositious child (Option C) refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own.

Atavism (Option D) refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the opposing lawyer asked the witness, “Did A kill B in your presence?” The witness said, “Yes”. Which procedural route would this type of question be permitted in the court of law?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cross-examination

  • Cross-examination is the correct procedural route in the court of law for this type of question.

Aspect

Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination) (Option A and B)

Cross-Examination (Option C)

Re-Examination (Option D)

Conducted By

Party who calls the witness (e.g., public prosecutor)

Opposing party (typically defense)

Party who called the witness

Purpose
  • Present all relevant facts
  • Provide expert interpretation if applicable
  • Challenge witness's credibility
  • Elicit favorable facts
  • Test accuracy

Clarify issues raised during cross-examination

Leading Questions

Not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile

Allowed (Sec. 146 BSA)

Not allowed

Nature of Questions

Open-ended questions to elicit narrative

Can include leading questions to control the narrative

Generally clarifying questions

Time Limit

Typically structured and may have time constraints

No set time limit; may last for hours or even days

Generally limited to clarification purposes

Judicial Oversight

Judge may intervene to ensure questions are relevant and not leading

Court can disallow indecent or scandalous questions (Sec. 154, BSA)

Judge monitors to ensure focus remains on clarification

questions.text: The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PDA

 

Explanation: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

Cardiac anomalies are observed in 50% of children infected during the first 8 weeks of gestation. The incidence of heart defects in congenital rubella syndrome follows this order:
PDA > PS (right > left) > VSD > ASD.

 

Etiology

Associated Heart Defects (Order)

Infections

Rubella Virus (German Measles)

Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) / Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Toxoplasmosis

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Metabolic Defects

Maternal Diabetes

Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGV) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) / Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Genetic Disorders

Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Turner Syndrome (45,X)

Coarctation of the Aorta > Bicuspid Aortic Valve > Aortic Stenosis

Noonan Syndrome

Pulmonary Stenosis > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) > Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Williams Syndrome

Supravalvular Aortic Stenosis (SVAS) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis > Aortic Stenosis

DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 Deletion)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) > Interrupted Aortic Arch > Truncus Arteriosus

Drugs

Thalidomide

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis

Lithium

Ebstein Anomaly > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
